Midterm 24%, Lab projects 36%, Final exam 40%
Midterm 0%, Lab projects 42%, Final exam 58%
They will automatically choose the highest mark of these two calculations.

My score: A- (Overall: 85.42%)
100 in all labs
79.2 in midterm and 74.9 in final
(P.S. I have no prior CS knowledge)

I studied hard for the midterm and I've watched all the lecture videos. You should finish all labs as skills related would be tested in the exam. Unfortunately, I've lost some marks because of some careless mistakes.

For the final exam, I started doing my revision 2-3 days before the exam, but obviously, I didn't get high marks. I spent lots of time understanding what's happening in Recursion.
reviews.comment_workload:
Acceptable, there are 8 lab exercises (from 0 to 7), but you only have to hand in 3 of them: Lab 2, 5 and 7).

There are videos demonstrating how to finish the lab exercises, so you can get full marks easily as long as you are careful enough when running the programs.

reviews.author: Jaib
reviews.title: Good course
reviews.comment_content:
Basics of Python.
Even if you do not have background on programming, you can still follow the course by attending all the lectures. The content is not really hard.
- Loops
- Turtle graphic
- List, tuples, and strings
- Slicing
- Function
- Operators
- Colours
- Timer
- Dictionaries
- File handling
- Recursion
and so on...
I personally liked the lecture. It was really interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is really funny. I liked his teaching style. You can easily concentrate on the lecture. Best teacher this term.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not sure about the grading yet because I haven't received the score yet. But I think it is quite fair. You can choose one of the two methods, one including midterm and other does not.
Lab is easy, you can just follow the video and think bit more to solve the problem. Only 3 labs to hand in, one midterm, and one final. However, final was way more difficult than midterm.

Mean of
Labs: 97.2, 98.1, 95.4
Midterm: 64.4
Final: 55.9
reviews.comment_workload:
Only 3 labs to hand in among 7 labs in total. It is not long, there is always skeleton code for you to work on, so you just need to follow the procedure.
You need to study midterm and final. Previous midterms and finals will be posted in the website, so you can try solving them. Midterm and final are all open notes, open python... but it is difficult especially part B.

reviews.author: Hting
reviews.comment_content: Interesting content, if you like programming or interested in computer, this is a nice course for you
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very clear, the tutor delivered the idea very well.
He is humorous  also.
reviews.comment_grading: Really need to understand all codes, even you did all the past paper that they provided, you still have no idea to do the final questions
reviews.comment_workload: Only three labs, one mt and one final, and it is not necessary to attend all the lectures, there are no participation marks. But I recommend you to attend all the lectures to have adequate understanding to deal with the exams.

reviews.author: haha1234
reviews.title: introduction to computer science
reviews.comment_content: David taught us a lot basic knowledge of python, like turtle, random, color change, graph, if while for structures...for me I learnt some C language in my high school so the content isn't that hard for me. For the exam, we can review our slices and labs during the exam. Also we can do the past paper so we can well prepare for the exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: his teaching style is quite interesting. you will not get bored at all. and TA is very responsible who will answer our question quickly
reviews.comment_grading: maybe good ..
reviews.comment_workload: no homework, just a lab every week. workload is relatively small

reviews.author: Auntie Johnson
reviews.comment_content: A very easy course for people who have learnt any kind of programming language before. It teaches python which is a basic language, so content is quite easy.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teacher is nice, willing to answer all questions you have.
reviews.comment_grading: Not quite sure about the grading yet, because I haven't received it yet, but I assume the grading is pretty good as most of the class are beginners in coding, so if you have some experience, you already have advantage compare to the others.
reviews.comment_workload: Only lab works which are writing some programs, pretty good workload.

reviews.author: pinerry
reviews.title: Excellent beginners course
reviews.comment_content:
Very basic and beginner-friendly Python course. Content include basic commands and variables, turtles, if-else statements, for loops and while loops etc. All are straight-forward and not hard to understand. The harder part starts at the loops and turtle. It may take some thinking to understand if you are not following the code closely. But in general its not hard.

The labs are very friendly as well. The TAs guide you step by step and explain things very well. You can ask questions after every part and they will answer and solve your problems very patiently. The content of the labs and assignments are quite fun as well. Good stuff.
reviews.comment_teaching: Sung KIM is one of the best instructors in this school. Very kind, passionate and humorous at the right time. It won't feel bored during his lecture. He will try his best to make sure you understand, especially if you don't have any programming background or have problem understanding the logic behind. 100% recommend. One of the biggest gems of this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
They have two types of grading system and will take the one with higher ending grade. Assignments are medium to easy difficulty. If you are following through it shouldn't be a problem to get full mark.

This semester's finals was replaced by an long but easy online open-book quiz. A couple days of time was allowed and pretty much everyone got a decent grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Some assignments and labs outside the lectures. Workload is not too bad. Time for assignments depends on your understanding and thinking of the course materials. Works are pretty easy in general and should finish quick.

reviews.author: anonymity
reviews.comment_content: Content is fine, basically taking about turtle graphic, file handling, and some game stuff.
reviews.comment_teaching: David teaches very good, very easy to understand even if you don’t have any programming background.
reviews.comment_grading: I think the grading this year is terrible. I got 1sd above mean in the midterm, full marks in labs, and a bit higher than mean in the final due to internet problems (really annoying), but I got B+ in the end which is not very satisfying.The final was killing everyone’s grade: the problems were very long, and it was impossible for anyone to finish in the exam. I guest in the end everyone was jumping the problems and guessing, which made the exam meaningless. The mean for final only 41.
reviews.comment_workload: Light.Only 3 hand-in labs.

reviews.author: LeekHA
reviews.comment_content:
The content can be divided into two parts: Basic statement and turtle.

You will know some statements like if, for, while, etc. At the end of this course, you should be able to write simple programs or games like Tetris with a user-friendly interface created by turtle.
reviews.comment_teaching:
If you don't have any programming experience, you will like to take the lessons. However, it is a little bit boring for students who have programming foundation.

Also, Instructors are very patient to answer your question.
reviews.comment_grading:
It is very easy to get B range, but you need to put a lot of effort to attain A range.

Homework 1(20%): 95/100
Homework 2(20%): 100/100
Midterm (35%): 84/100
Online MC test (25%): 92/100
(It should be an exam, but it is canceled and instead with an online test in this sem.)
Finally, I get B+.
I am not sure about the weight of those assignments and quiz, but they should be more or less the same.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not heavy. You can finish those assignments quickly because the teaching assistant has almost finished the program for you. You just need to follow the marking scheme to add, delete and modify some statements. When everything is ok, you will easily get full mark.

reviews.author: abudhabing
reviews.comment_content: Content seems to change every year. When I asked my friend who did com1021 in the previous semester, he said it's a topic they haven't learned before.
reviews.comment_teaching:
has a bad korean accent but not hard to understand the lectures
he also makes a lot of jokes during the lectures
reviews.comment_grading: not bad overall but the grading this semester was messed up cause of the change in syllabus from the protests and pass and fail requests.
reviews.comment_workload:
no workload for the lectures
only a fair amount of workload is given from the labs (2 assignments)

reviews.author: Wing1
reviews.comment_content:
The course is about python program, using some basic coding.
In this course, you will learn how to use turtle graphic to draw different pictures, commands.
The content is appropriate even you did not learn ICT in secondary school.
You will learn how to make a simple game in the end which is satisfying.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lectures are great, Gibson teaches slow with examples to make sure everyone understands what he is doing. While Lam, Ngok uses some examples outside the textbook to explain some hard concepts.
Both teachers are willing to answer your questions and explain briefly after lessons or through email.
The labs are useful, as the TAs would teach you step by step to write some programs which will be useful for your homework. They are patient with your query.
reviews.comment_grading:
The assignments are not hard, most people get full marks. So you have to do well in the midterm and final exam.You need to be careful to get good result,
There are two grading method, and you will take the better one. If you did not do well in your midterm, your final exam will count more if you do better.
You need to get 90% or more in total to get into A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is appropriate, there are 2 assignments,
midterm and final exam,and the exams are open book.
Parts of the assignments are taught in the lab, and leave you about 2-3 weeks to finish, which you will have plenty of time.
There is no attendance taking, in both lab and lectures. You don't need to hand in the code you write in the labs, but you might need the in your assignments.
There might be so bonus questions in the lectures, and the lecturers will choose students to answer some simple questions and the might even give you hints when you are wrong.
The bonus questions counts bonus points in your assignments if you don't get full marks in them.

reviews.author: mmmmmei
reviews.title: 实用好grade课
reviews.comment_content: Basic and easy Python language, the majority is teaching turtle graphics. It is more likely an introduction to programming, as you will know basic methods to handle date types, and functions. A very good foundation course and arouse you interest to study more about computer science.
reviews.comment_teaching: Gibson's teaching is very interesting and clear. He will provide many examples which are not covered by notes. A very passionate professor, reply email very quickly. Feel free to ask hime about assignment questions, he is very willing to answer your questions. Prof's accent is fine, but some TAs' accent is hard to listen.
reviews.comment_grading: B range grade is not hard to get. However, A range grade is a little competitive. But there are many Year3 and 4 who have base in programming to take this course to get A range grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not heavy.
But comp courses require you to be familiar with codes examples and to think about inside logic. So you need extra time to review and practice by yourselves after class. There are many examples provided by professors on the course webpage regarding to each topics. Strongly recommend you to write these codes again to get better understanding. For the assignment, each semester is different. But it is not hard to get full mark. The first assignment for our semester is easy but you really need to be careful for the details, also in the exam. For the second assignment is a little harder, as the knowledge is getting a little harder for the second half knowledge. But you can try go to ask professors and TAs. Some TAs are really nice to guide you to let you know your problems and give you insights. For the final, really need to be familiar with codes examples and structures. It is harder than midterm.

reviews.author: zzz11
reviews.comment_content: Some basic content of python that is very easy to understand even though you don't have programming backgrounds like me.
reviews.comment_teaching: Gibson is humorous and his teaching is very clear. If you already have some background in programming and don't care about the bouns points, I think you can skip all the lectures. Also, the lecture video is provided before the midterm and final.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is ok.
2 assignment + 1 midterm + 1 final
Basically, 90% of the assignment is already done in the lab. The remaining 10% is quite easy to finish so you should get full marks in 2 assignments.
Midterm and final are openbook, so the main point is understanding but not memorizing. Also, remember to have good time management in the midterm and final exam.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very light.

reviews.author: Daniel_
reviews.comment_content:
This course is for students who don't have programming knowledge before. Python 3.7 is used. The content is simple (except for the content of the last two weeks), focus during the lesson and getting an A would not be a problem.
The first few lessons would be boring if you have a programming background.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lesson is not boring because Gibson made interesting gags. You can feel his passion for teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
Since there is social unrest happened in the second half of 2019, the grading system is slightly changed.
Face to face final exam(open notes) is replaced by an online test.
Since it is very easy to get a full mark in the online test and assignments, getting an overall 100% is not that difficult.
You can get a 3% bonus mark which can be added to the final mark by answering Gibson's question in the class.

- I got 100% and obtained an A+
- My friend got 99% and obtained an A-
reviews.comment_workload: There is only two assignment throughout the whole semester. The TA will teach you how to do most of the assignment in the lab session. Just need around 1 more hour to finish the assignment.

reviews.author: rch
reviews.title: Easy if you have programming background
reviews.comment_content:
Basic, beginner knowledge of Python.

All course materials are available on the course website. See attachment for details.

They also have a book, but the lecture notes are more than enough. Spend your $250 elsewhere.
reviews.comment_teaching: Skipped most of the lectures, but from what I've seen from the lecs I did attend and email correspondence, the professor is very friendly and tries to help students as much as he can. Just approach him after lectures and he will be happy to answer your questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Everyone says this is a "leng grade" course, so manage your expectations. The mean for everything is always above 90, so any misstep will cost you 1-2 subgrades.

Due to the current situation, the department offered two new scoring methods:
Assignment 1/Assignment 2/Midterm/Final
Original Method 1: 15%/15%/25%/45%
Original Method 2: 15%/15%/5%/65%

Assignment 1/Assignment 2/Midterm/Online Assignment
New Method 1: 25%/25%/35%/15%
New Method 2: 35%/35%/10%/20%
Mean: 92.5/92.6/57.9/87
And there are "bonus lecture points" that can be added.

My scores: 100/100/92/96 + 1 = 99.4%
Grade: A

So those bonus points are really important if you want to reach for the stars!
reviews.comment_workload:
2 assignments + 1 midterm + 1 final (replaced by online assignment)

If you have previous knowledge in programming, there is basically zero workload. No attendance is required anywhere, and all materials (lecture ppts, assignment guidelines, labs) are available on the course website, and they will be more than enough to guide you through.  

If you don't know programming, the workload is still minimal since this is a beginner course. You're given most of the code for the assignment already, and everything else can be found and copied from the course materials, and you can also ask the TAs for help. As the midterm and final are open-book, you don't need to memorise syntax, so just try to understand what is going on and you'll be fine.

reviews.author: amyriad
reviews.comment_content: Quite suitable for both programming beginners and students with other programming backgrounds. The course introduce the Python language in an interesting with the use of turtle graphics so the codes can be more visualized and the programs can be more fun.
reviews.comment_teaching:
At the beginning of each class there is a short video about AI system doing different tasks written by Python language with suitable libraries (from Youtube), so students can understand how Python is useful in doing tasks.

The instructor introduces the language slide by slide in the course material. (https://course.cse.ust.hk/comp1021 (login required for students taking the class only, whose system is the same as comp1022q site)) and the video can be reviewed in that course site.

The bonus question worthing 0.4% is only asked once to a single student, so from Alex Lam you can only get at most 0.4% bonus point (different from Gibson where you can answer more than 1 bonus question to get more bonus points)
And Alex may guide you through all the steps in answering the bonus question even if you answer wrongly (not for Gibson side) and give you bonus point even your answer is some sorts of nonsense, so just raise up your hand after Alex's counting up from 1,2,3...
reviews.comment_grading:
2 Assignments, Mid-term and Final
Notes are allowed in exams (no matter you bring books or printed notes, number of pages is not limited)
Simple calculator is also allowed.

2 Assignments: 30% (15% each)
Exams: 70%
Percentages are explained below:
if Mid-term < Final: # if your mid-term score is not as good as that of final exam
    Mid-term = 10% # mid-term exam is calculated less
    Final = 60%
else:
    Mid-term = 25%
    Final = 45%

Statistics:
(Quite a lot get full mark in Mid-term)
Mid-term Exam: Avg = 76.2, SD = 20.6, Range from 28 to 100
Assignment 1: Avg = 90.5, SD = 25.9, Range from 5 to 100
Assignment 2: Avg = 92.0, SD = 27.2, Range from 10 to 100
Final Exam: Avg = 64.0, SD = 24.6, Range from 6 to 100
As you see the distribution is skewed as at most +1.5 SD can be acquired.

(100/100/100/100/+0.4) so A+

Reference grade boundaries (from other reviews):
A+/A about 96.2
A/A- about 93.2
A-/B+ about 85 to 90 (not sure)
B+/B about 80 to 83
B/B- about 68 to 69
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite Light.
Most codes required are already included in the lab notes, and there is marking scheme to follow so you can already check whether you have fulfilled all the marking part and calculate your assignment score.

For 2018-19 Fall:
Assignment 1: L-system (the images drawn are quite interesting)
Assignment 2: Pac-man (quite fun for this)

reviews.author: Jordanlee
reviews.comment_content: Content is easy understanding, suitable for students who have no computer and programming background. The course teaches basic Python programming. Including input, output, loops, functions though turtle graphic etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: David is a good tutor, he can speak fluent English. He give lots of programming example during lesson make the lesson interesting and more clear.
reviews.comment_grading: Is a good grade course for sure. I have no computer and programming background. My mid-term is slightly above the mean, and I can get 96% in the final exam and get an A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Nearly zero workloads. Do not have any assignment. Just a hand-in lab bi-weekly.

reviews.author: Kenneth Chan
reviews.title: Good course for learning basic programming and an A range
reviews.comment_content: Basic Python Programming. For example, variable declaration, for/while loop, if-then-else statement. Clear Notes.
reviews.comment_teaching: Actually I didn't attended all the lessons, but David is good at teach us thinking step by step. Overall I would highly recommend him.
reviews.comment_grading: Very Good, you can earn A range for above mean 1 SD,  and A+ for above mean 1.5 SD.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very Little.
Only 2 Assignment for writing a music player and a simple game. No attendance is taken so that you can simply refer to the video taken which is available on the course portal.

reviews.author: navI
reviews.comment_content: After all, the content of the course is easy, especially for those with little programming background and took ICT as an elective for HKDSE. What was being taught in the course is just introductory programming like FOR and WHILE loop. If you are with programming background and careful enough, this course will be a piece of cake for you.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr Rossiter is quite a good lecturer as he was able to give lecture with great intonation (in the mean that you won't speak in that way in daily life). With his funny and some anti-logical example, the atmosphere in the class is not boring at all.
reviews.comment_grading: You don't have to be panic if you didn't make a good trial in midterm, your midterm result will be eliminated if it lower your overall score in the ordinary scheme (scheme 1 is accounting all your results from assignments, midterms and final; scheme 2 is accounting only your assignments and finals). To conclude, what is important is carefulness.
reviews.comment_workload: There are only two assignments in the entire semester. Programming a music player and a game. Again, if you are careful enough, it is not difficult to score a full mark in both assignments.

reviews.author: Clau2304
reviews.comment_content:
- Two lectures per week, each lasts about one hour
- One lab per week
- No submission or grading is required for the labs besides the grading for the assignments.
reviews.comment_teaching:
- All the content is uploaded online for each week of the course.
- The teaching materials include ppts, pdfs and some code samples.
- The instructor for lab will provide all the necessary materials and guide you with some samples and instructions.
reviews.comment_workload:
- Labs and assignments can take a really long time to do (at least 1 week)
- Midterms and finals are hard so you have to study quite a lot.

reviews.comment_content:
Basic Python Stuff: logic, turtle, data handling, slicing, dictionary etc.
slightly differs every year.

reviews.comment_teaching: Professor ROSSITER explains the logic very clearly in detail. Fair

reviews.author: KlausGG2
reviews.comment_content: 学一些python入门知识，有一些基本概念，但是没有实用性。
reviews.comment_teaching: 教的很生动有趣，节奏略快
reviews.comment_grading: 好，我midterm只有34/100，但是final87/100，由于独特的算分机制，我在lab没拿到满分的情况下最后仍然收获B+。适合和我一样的摆烂人去学。但是A range好像很小，想拿A的容错率很低，基本需要lab满分，考试出错两题左右才可以。
reviews.comment_workload: workload不大，只有lab要做，可以gpt。你问我gpt完了那没学到东西怎么办？1021考试考的是手速，只要你可以手速够快，可以把考试题目照抄到python上跑一次就可以。那你又问你不爱玩电脑手速不够快怎么办？那你还是好好学习吧

reviews.author: bow1
reviews.comment_content: Pretty basic Python content, introduction to programming and logic basics. With any programming background in any other language such as C++, Java, etc., the course is very easy and new Python concepts/syntax is easily picked up.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching was good, instructor is engaging and content is relatively easy to follow along.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fair, and it is easy to see where marks are earned or lost. Tutors are very willing to help.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is fair, a mix of assignments/labs and exams. The labs should be easy if following along with lecture content.

reviews.author: Uno
reviews.title: Nice Beginning Course
reviews.comment_content: As the course name indicates, it is all just about basic python materials. It wasn’t too difficult although I haven’t took any computer programming course before. It is quite enjoyable tbh
reviews.comment_teaching: He is humorous and gives easily understandable lectures, though this doesn’t quite matter coz this course is flexible; you can enroll into any time and go to lectures from other professors.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading isn’t that bad. I got 70 sth in the midterm, and got 90 sth in the final, and got an A. I believe that finals were better than midterms for the recent few years.
reviews.comment_workload: Extremely low workload. You’ve only got three to four compulsory lab assignments to turn in during the whole semester.

reviews.author: Jervis
reviews.title: Great course
reviews.comment_content: Not too hard, basic Python programming syntax and logic. There are assignments throughout the course that you need to complete, usually with guidelines so the difficulty of the tasks is manageable to be honest
reviews.comment_teaching: David is quite good, charming voice and not just a ppt reader. Just pay attention in class (or not), then with slight practice and do the assignments then easy good grades.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair enough, but do be aware that the grading curve is a bit steep when it comes to the B range, I got B with a 90% mark for the final exam. And the assignment gradings are fine as long as you complete the tasks within the assignments.
reviews.comment_workload: Manageable, there should be time for you to complete the assignments during the semester. For me, an assignment usually takes at most an hour to finish.

reviews.author: ItsMeHello
reviews.title: so so
reviews.comment_content:
Basic python + turtle programming
List/ Function/ Operation those stuff
Logic is the KEY
reviews.comment_teaching: He's chill and friendly, he will be asking some questions during class to test your understanding. And he organize his classes pretty well, no overrun, start on time and end on time.
reviews.comment_grading: High curve. According to my experience, the average is like 75/ 76 out of 100, and the grade is like C+ or B- because there are many dailo in the class who's getting full score with ease or just making one mistake to guarantee 90 or above.
reviews.comment_workload: Just one assignment per 2 weeks. There will be one assignment counting towards grade and one not counting towards it. For me, it's absolutely light work.

reviews.author: Toaster
reviews.title: Entry level programming
reviews.comment_content:
It's basic level programming. For people who have programming experience (like me), this will be an extremely easy course for you.

The most difficult part of this course is not making careless mistakes, such as submitting a wrong version of your code or forgetting to remove testing values you put in. These will cost you a lot of marks in your homework. I strongly urge you to double check your codes and files every time before submission.

The exams tests you on two things: how well you understand the Python functions and structures, and your eye for detail. Of course, you will need to know how Python works to get a good grade. However, the exam questions often sneak in cheeky “mistakes" that affects how the code functions and change the answer.
reviews.comment_teaching: Didn't go to lessons. PDF notes provided on the course website were plenty.
reviews.comment_grading:
Being an easy course comes with a huge drawback, which is a ridiculously skewed distribution curve. If you want to get A+, you will need to obtain near perfect scores in both homework and exams. Making small careless mistakes can easily drop your grade a level or two.

Made one mistake in one of my homework and a final exam question. Got an A+, so still pretty decent grade.
reviews.comment_workload: One homework per 1-2 week. Tutorial and sufficient guidance material will be provided so it will not be very difficult.

reviews.author: Kenny486
reviews.comment_content: .The content are easy. It has online mode for people who want to choose online mode. Which is very useful and convenient.
reviews.comment_teaching: he teach the course and use a funny way to entertain us to learn to course
reviews.comment_grading: good the course are easy to do and learn. But you cannot lose one or two score and have a wrong. Because one or two questions is equal to 1 grade.
reviews.comment_workload: less workload and have 4 to 5 assignment only. And the mid-term only last 90 minutes and the final exam only last 3 hours.

reviews.author: Kirakishou
reviews.comment_content: Basic content of programming and use of turtle. It will be easy for those with background of programming.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very good instructor. He used a very funny tone to explain the contents in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading.
24% lab, 36% midterm, 40% final OR
42% lab, 0% midterm, 58% final

They will help you to count the highest among the two methods, so don't worry if you get a low grading in midterm. But you still need to work very hard to get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: 7 labworks but only 3 of them are graded. The workload is acceptable if you understand the course materials.

reviews.author: mattmatt_mm
reviews.title: Easy python content. Medium grading
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Python content like strings, array, turtle graphics, if-else, if-elif, and dictionary.

After learning from the course you can make yourself a small python game which is fun to play with
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor delivers content very well and can be easily understood. Also very engaging sometimes with jokes.
reviews.comment_grading: The midterms and finals are rushed. You can barely have time to finish all the questions that appear in the paper. But the grading is fine as the sd is very high. As long as you get above mean you can get a pretty good grade. Be careful with each lab. They play a major role in grading other than finals and midterms.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fine as there are three major lab assignment. Just follow the guidelines to finish it and you can get full marks.

reviews.author: /.ss
reviews.comment_content: Basic python programing. Beginner friendly. The challenge comes from the logic behide the code but not the code syntax.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is great. You can go to different classes without needing permission if you want to change professor. Lecture videos are also provided.
I mainly go to Gibson's class. He is a funny guy and can explain things clearly. He will do a lot of coding in class when teaching related topics. For me, it is the best way to learn. I know other professors will have different teaching styles so if one did not work for you, try going to different classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading base on hw and final exams. (mid term exam could be excluded from the grade calculation if the results are not good)
HW:
Most code are provided. The instructions gives a preaty good step by step guide on how to complete the program. You can test your code as much as you want before submetting. Therefore, you do not have to worry about careless mistakes on the code.
Exams:
2 grad calculating fomular can be used. One with midterm and the other don't. The better one will be used for your letter grade.
Both midterm and final are short ans questions. Basically no coding need to be done. Most questions only require you to understand the code provided and give out the results. Therefore as mentioned before, the exams are easy if you have good logic.
A important note is that the time provided is kind of lacking and not much time can be wasted. therefore doing past paper can let you get used to the question patern as soon as you start the exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
For me, the workload is very low. As I am able to understand the logic just from the lecture. Therefore, I can complete the hw without spending much time and had basically no revision for the exam.( I only do a few past papers, which is the most effective way to get used to the questions).
My understanding is that if you are good at logic, you have basically no work. If not, it takes a lot of work to truely understand it.

Basic operation with Python in order to write programs. e.g. a number guessing game, a music player, or a maze game.

reviews.comment_teaching: Rossiter is patient and responsible prof
reviews.comment_grading: Need some effort to get an A range since this course is not difficult and the grading is based on the distribution of exam scores/lab scores.
reviews.comment_workload:
Work load is relatively small compared to other introduction courses for engineers.

Only 3 labs and no hw.
Have final and mid-term exam.

reviews.author: Ho Jin
reviews.comment_content: Foundation knowledge about Python. This class contents were well organized and easy to fallow.
reviews.comment_teaching: You are allowed to watch other professor's lecture video. Therefore if you are not satisfied with the class you are enrolled in, you can just watch video recording of others. There is no attendance so you can just skip class and only watch video recording, However if you this is your first time attempting computer science, I would recommend you to attend TA sessions for help.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are quite a number of lab you have to finish and I personally thought that it was challenging. However, the guide-line and video recording usually goes through 80% of the lab, so as long and you spend time to work on it, you will get 100% grading. But there is mid-term and final exam, but i thought that it is easier than the lab and the questions are mostly related to the homework. So as long as you go though the labs before the exam, its ok.

Grading:
Lab 36%/42%
Midterm exam 40%/58%
reviews.comment_workload: It was adequate

reviews.author: Kiwi:o
reviews.comment_content:
The course content is as follows:
1. Introduction to Python
2. Turtle
3. Comments, Variables, and Text
4. Variables Types and 3 Operators
5. Making Decisions
6. Looping
7. Finding Repeating Patterns
8. Lists, Tuples, and Strings
9. Functions
10. Dictionaries
11. More on Turtle
12. Turtle Window Event Handling
13. File Handling
14. Programming with Objects
15. Recursion
reviews.comment_teaching: David is good as he not only follows the PowerPoint slides and reads them out. He demonstrated the program and gave chances for you to ask questions. His teaching style is interesting, so you can be more concentrated in his lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is terrible as the curve is very high. You cannot get A range even if you got full marks in all the lab assignments and midterm exam. It is because the weighting of the final exam is very high, so you need to be very careful in the exam. You lose 7-8 marks if you get one question wrong.

Overall, I got above 90 marks at the end of the course, but I still cannot get A range.

The midterm and final exams seem not to test the programming knowledge you learn in the class. In addition, there are so many words in the question but they are useless. It seems that you are doing a reading exam XD. The time you have is very limited, so you need to be very familiar with Python and find the key point quickly.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is nearly zero as you only need to hand in 3 lab assignments in the course. Also, attendance is not required in this course so you can choose to watch the lecture video whenever you want instead of attending face-to-face lecture.

reviews.author: BillySiu
reviews.title: good intro course
reviews.comment_content:
fundamental python programming

2. Loops
3. Nested Loops
4. Lists, Tuples, and Strings
5. Slicing
6. Functions

reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 24%, Lab projects 36%, Final exam 40%
or
Midterm 0%, Lab projects 42%, Final exam 58%
Open book exam(downloaded pdf and course website could be visited in the exam)
Only three lab projects will be graded, and the course grading will highly depend on the performance in the exam.
Final:
Mean: 71.6
sd: 20.7
Not easy to get an A range. A+ means 100% correct in the exam.
reviews.comment_workload: Low workload. A short lab projects every two weeks.

reviews.author: HU-HT
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Python Stuff
random.randint()
Turtle graphics
All of these are pretty easy to understand and learn for beginners like me. I would recommend owning a laptop so that you can try it during lecture.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is pretty good. He will sometimes show more examples to help us understand so I recommend attend his lectures. I am interested in programming because of his lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
The course gives you a chance if you failed mid-term exam.
12% Lab 1
12% Lab 4
12% Lab 5
24% Mid-Term Exam
40% Final Exam
OR
14% Lab 1
14% Lab 4
14% Lab 5
0% Mid-Term Exam
58% Final Exam
The course will automatically choose the highest one of the two to be your overall score.

My result:
100/100 Lab 1
90/100 Lab 4
92/100 Lab 5
88/100 Mid-Term Exam
100/100 Final Exam
Overall: 97.48
Grade: A+
I can understand why some people complained that they didn't have enough time to do all the questions in the exam. I managed to do all of them though.
I got terrible scores in mid-term exam because I made a terrible mistake on the first 2 questions. Thank you for having an alternative grading scheme that didn't count mid-term exam score. XD
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not large at all.
Only 3 labs are required to do. You can do the other labs for revision. You can also try it yourself after you learn all those commands.
Doing revision for the exam may be hard if you do it in the last minutes. It is not just memorizing all the commands. You need to know how to follow the logic in the code. Make sure you do all the past papers and understand why you are correct/wrong.

reviews.author: XZNNepNoire
reviews.comment_content:
Basics Python program skills.
This course is suitable for non-programing experiment students, and it is also one of the collage's required courses.
Overall, the content of this course is not very difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching by LAM, Ngok is quite good. Explaining the concept with both PPT and python.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite difficult to get a high grade.
Two kinds of scheme about the grading:
first one contains mid-term grade and another one does not.
reviews.comment_workload: This is a less workload course as there are 4 lab assessments in whole semester. About every two weeks finishing one assessments.

reviews.author: notmyname
reviews.title: DO NOT TAKE IF YOU HAVEN'T STUDIED PYTHON BEFORE!!
reviews.comment_content:
For context, I had never EVER learned python before. I am a business major with no CS experience so it was a HUGE HUGE mistake to take COMP 1021. Everyone in this course is on the STEM track and therefore extremely smart and tech-savvy.

The presentations are helpful, I definitely recommend attending every single lecture. I stopped attending midway and I think that's what caused my downfall. Ask a ton of questions whenever you can because you WILL be left hanging most of the time.

It gets a LOT more difficult after the midterm. Prior to the midterm its more basic, primary content. But towards the end of the semester it gets really really advanced and the pace of teaching is so so quick.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Rossiter is hilarious, I loved LOVED his accent and teaching style. He has a British accent and is quite animated at times.

He picks out students at random to answer questions in class just to put you on the spot a little bit. But no harm if you don't answer, a lot of people usually don't know.
reviews.comment_grading:
It's not bad per se, but if you get a bad grade, you'll be screwed. Because for most STEM students this course is basic, the curve is INSANE. I got around a 75% and only ended up with a C.

I got below 0.5 SD below mean on both midterm and final. I got 100% in the first two labs, and 60% on the third lab.

If you don't work hard and dedicate at least 4-5 hours to this course every week, you will be royally f'ed.

The grading is done two ways:
1. The midterm is worth around 30%, final 50% , and labs 20%
2. The final worth 60% and labs 40%

You should focus on doing well in the midterm so it doesn't all fall upon the final.
reviews.comment_workload:
There's no attendance grading so up to you if you wanna go.

There are 3 graded labs in the semester, all fairly self explanatory if you watch the lab videos. I screwed up on the last one about music production because i didn't attend those lectures nor did I go to the Lab TA for help. I cannot emphasize enough on reaching out for help.

There are 2 exams- a midterm and final. Both are quite difficult and very difficult to complete on time. I didn't finish both times. I recommend going through the examples online and the sample papers ESPECIALLY. Please do the sample papers if you want a good grade. Learn from my mistakes rip.

Very easy, hardest is probably turtle which was still very easy.

Professor is full-hearted, sums up confusing coding content down to chunks for us to better understand the content.

Labs for this course are amazing, they guide you through your work and lab, even if you do not understand the steps listed in the lab guide. TAs are very friendly.
reviews.comment_grading: Overall A+, full marks in finals, first 2 labs full marks, last lab 95%.
reviews.comment_workload: Low workload, 3 labs, one midterm and one final. reviews.author: Nevio
reviews.title: High mean, 1 mistake can cost you.
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Python programming. Notably, many concepts are thought via the Turtle library (which aside from its graphic representation, I don't see much use for learning Turtle into such depth.)

If you have basic programming background, this course should be not that challenging, you should focus on not being careless and carefully go over your lab's mark schemes before submitting. Topics around Turtle can be especially confusing as the syntax and some specific details can only be learnt by playing around with Turtle yourself.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor David speaks clearly and makes his fair effort of keeping the class enjoyable. He is able to teach concepts in very simple terms.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is generous but the high mean makes a single mistake costly.
There are 2 grading schemes. One including and one without the midterm exam.

Labs (36%/48%) = 100%
Midterm (24%/0%) = 100%
Finals (40%/52%) = 93%

Final grade = 97.2%, Awarded A+

On a side note, a friend of mine ended up with 96.9% final grade and was only awarded A, so I can say if you're aiming for A ranges, every mistake can be damaging.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only 3 labs spread across the semester, each can be done in around 2-4 hours
Thus, workload is relatively light

reviews.author: omo
reviews.title: Good grade course
reviews.comment_content:
Overall the content is interesting and easy to understand. The content before mid-term is relatively easy but a little bit hard after mid-term.

Techniques like global/ local variable, dictionary and recursion are important.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecture notes were released a week before the lecture. The professor is willing to answer your questions and explains the notes clearly during the lectures. Lam Ngok is ok.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading scheme:
1. MT: 24%, Lab: 36%, Final: 40%
2. MT: 0%, Lab: 42%, Final: 58%

My scores
3 Lab scores: 100, 60, 77
Mid term: 84/100 ( mean: forgot sorry:(, but the score of mean+1sd is 86)
Final: 93/100 (mean: 71)
At last, I got a B+(87%, scheme 2).

I recommend you not skip mid-term exam as it is easier than the final exam. Moreover, Lab assignments are extremely IMPORTANT. You should ensure to score full marks for all the lab assignments as I messed them up so i lost my A range. I did not attend the lab since it is not compulsory but you are able to seek help from TAs in that session. You probably will get A range if you score 1sd higher for both examinations. Be careful in the exams.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload. Only 3 labs are marked.
Do at least 3 years pp before exams, try to complete all the labs and recite the codes in your brain tho it is open book exam. The exam time is limited and no time for you to check your notes line by line.

reviews.author: Yksmih
reviews.title: Basic Python Programme Course
reviews.comment_content: Most are basic stuff like conditions and loops at the beginning(while, if). After that, different operators and lists are introduced. Lastly, text handling, dictionary and recursions would be taught. I think recursion will be a little bit hard to understand but this is the only thing that is confusing. Others are easy to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
David is a nice guy. His voice just made the whole lecture interesting. He is willing to answer your question and he will explain those codes in detail. In every lecture, he will pick some students to answer his questions.

They will provide some related past papers for your reference and revision.
reviews.comment_grading:
The number of questions for the mid-term and final exam is almost similar, like 17-19 questions, which are divided into 2 parts. Therefore, you can have time to rest after completing the first part. Also, you will type the answer in canvas and be given a pdf exam questions document.

I recommend registering for a quiet room to take the exam instead of doing it through zoom because the pdf could have some problems, so you cannot read the question and seek help immediately if you are in zoom.

Er...I don't know how the result is distributed.
my result:
Lab 100%
Mid-term 100%
Final 100%
overall 100%
Grade A+
reviews.comment_workload:
There are not many assignments. You only need to do a few labs. The labs have guidelines for you to follow so I think it is not hard to complete.

It is not a must to attend the lab session if you have no problem with your lab. I did not attend any of them, so :).

reviews.author: Willion

reviews.author: MDaf

reviews.comment_grading: Since a lot of people take this course, The grading can be a bit messed up, depending on the mean of the class. There are 2 grading schemes where one takes the mid-term exam into account while the other doesn't. So if u make even a minor mistake in the final but you got 100 percent in all other assignments and midterms then you could still drop from an A+ to an A or A-. There is no grading for attendance which is nice.
reviews.comment_workload: If you have previously done python the the workload will be nothing to u, but it could be a bit daunting for first-timers with no programming knowledge.

reviews.author: emmmmmmmma
reviews.comment_content:
introduction to python for people who barely know python.

The content is great for training your logic in programming.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Golin was super kind to answer all the questions, and explain everything clearly. It is very nice to start my programming journey with him.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grade:
The grading is friendly, if you screw up your midterm, your midterm grade will not count toward your score. However, the average score on the final exam is much higher than the midterm.
reviews.comment_workload: The first two compulsory labs were easy but the last one was quite challenging. I would suggest finishing it earlier, don't leave it until the last minute.

reviews.author: dayday
reviews.title: Easy course, grading could be better
reviews.comment_content: Content covers mostly basic coding with a relatively easy programming language - python. From if statements to turtle graphics and recursions. Frankly all the concepts are easy to understand except for recursions. However, recursions should be manageable after some practice.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very nice and teaches well. The lectures are also recorded and attendance is not required. Hence, you could learn at your own pace/time as needed.
reviews.comment_grading:
Honestly, the grading system is flexible and have two options. While the percentages may change based on semesters, the two options offer a chance to make up for some mistakes. The first option weighs all of midterm, projects, and final. The second option weighs only the project and the final.

The only reason I gave this course a B is because everyone gets full marks and its practically impossible to get an A+ if you make small mistakes. The small mistakes take a lot out of the entire mark because there are no partial credits and there are not a lot of questions.

The midterm and the final both were taken online and I suggest that you sign up for the quiet room if possible because it just gets rid of all the hassle to show your surroundings with the camera. Also, the exams are extremely easy because it allows for you to use the python program as well.

Bottom line: easy, but make sure there are no mistakes for A+
reviews.comment_workload: Very light. There were only about 6 labs (projects) throughout the semester, and there are practically no work to do for most labs except for the last two. Its guided kindly through videos and assignment links. It was definitely one of the easiest class taken as a first year student.

reviews.author: Colourful_black
reviews.title: Easy course, hard to A+
reviews.comment_content:
The turtle graphics are easy to learn but not really useful. It is an introduction course so they did a good job.

You learn different types of objects, basic logic, some file handling and turtle graphics (of course) in python.

I wish they could teach something like numpy.
reviews.comment_teaching: I have tried different instructors in different COMP1021 lectures. They are all good. You could skip all lectures and read the notes if you are familiar with computers. Those notes are well-written and you should be able to finish all lab quickly with help from google.
reviews.comment_grading:
The papers this year are relatively straightforward. Many people typed all the code into the idle instead of "thinking like a computer".
100% for all labs (36% weighted)
9x% for mid-term (24% weighted)
8x% for the final exam (40% weighted)
92.88% final score and A-
Need to be extremely careful to be A+
Make sure you have a good sleep the night before the exam since the time is tight.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload isn't that high. You spend around 1 to 2 hours reading the lecture notes weekly and 3 to 4 hours biweekly for the homework. It doesn't matter which lecture you are registered for, the lecture notes are clear enough. Labs are all virtual so you won't attend them unless you have questions that need to be answered

reviews.author: 刘明昊
reviews.comment_content: PPT is specific and understandable, so it is easy to review.  Interactive questions are good for practicing what you learned.
reviews.comment_teaching: Rossiter is nice. He always gives some examples that are not mentioned in the PPT.
reviews.comment_grading: As long as you avoid stupid mistakes, the grading is nice. I got an A because I lost a question in the final.
reviews.comment_workload:
not too hard
There is a lab with specific instructions every two weeks. It takes about one hour to finish every task.
There are some interactive questions for every lecture. They are not compulsory, but they are helpful.

reviews.author: SunLukeP
reviews.title: Very interesting and well-designed
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Python
Quite easy
You can look at others for the content

For the notes, they are also clear, so you can just look at the notes for people who hate attending lessons
The notes are good for revising too

Even if you register one section, you can attend other sections and watch the videos from these sections
Like I registered L1, but I always attend L4 and watched videos from other professors lol
reviews.comment_teaching:
Different professor have different teaching style
Some like to follow the examples given in the notes, some like to freestyle and type their own code in the lesson
You can attend lessons by different professors according to your learning style

For example, I attend Prof. Rossiter's lectures since the first one
He is the type of professors who like to type their own code in the lesson
His teaching is clear
The lessons are fun, and I enjoy them
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 2 grading system
Both system counted the 3 hand in labs and final
One counted the midterm
And another one didn't
Very flexible
And most importantly, attendance is not counted!

My grade:
Lab : 100/9X/9X ( I forget lol, but X>5)
Midterm : 100/100 (mean 62.1, sd 24.1)
Final : 100/100 (mean 71.3, sd 20.7)
Overall : A+

reviews.comment_workload:

reviews.author: JGH
reviews.title: Easy A range course if you are not a careless student
reviews.comment_content:
Simple and basic python.
This course uses the turtle library to help explain the concept of python coding.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Interesting!
I am a local student without ICT background.
The lectures are pretty fun and easy to follow. The professor will use extra materials apart from PowerPoint, which is pretty good.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 2 grading methods
i) 24% Midterm exam+ 36% Lab projects+ 40% Final exam
ii) 0% Midterm exam + 42% Lab projects + 58% Final exam
(The better grading option will be chosen automatically)

My grade: A+
7x/100 Midterm exam
100/100 Final exam
Lab projects: 100/100, 100/100, 90/100
Overall: 98.6%

The grading system is quite harsh. You have to get nearly full mark to get an A+.

Suggestions:
1) Spend some time reading through the materials (maybe right after the lecture, watching the lecture video)
2a) Try to get full marks in the final exam and lab projects
2b) You can type every single exam question into the python IDLE if you are typing fast enough. (at least in the semester)
3) Prevent any careless mistakes in lab projects and exams
4) Final exam = Lab projects >>>>>> Midterm exam
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is light. Only 3 hand-in labs will be graded. The hand-in labs are not too difficult, and you can be able to complete them by following the guidelines.

For exams, there are past papers on the course website. Just try your best to finish them, definitely helpful for understanding the exam materials.

reviews.author: lknetwork
reviews.title: Simple for people with programming background
reviews.comment_content:
Learning basic python using the turtle library

reviews.comment_teaching:
Attended 0 lectures so I'll skip this part
My frds that also enroll in this course said the lecture is fun tho so I'll give it an A
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm : 92/100
Final : 100/100
Lab : 100/100 (full marks on 3 graded lab)
Grade : A+

Instead of really challenging problems, the midterm and final focus on how careful you answer(which caused me to get a question wrong in the mid term)
The python code in the exams are not really complicated but the time is tight. Instead of tracing the code line by line, you should familiarize yourself with python so that you can "understand" what the code is trying to achieve to be fast enough.
reviews.comment_workload:
Overall workload is not high.
There are only 3 graded lab assginments throughout the whole course and the lab videos guide you through so each graded lab can be done in around 3hrs or so
Since I learnt programming before so I didn't really revise the midterm and final, the lab itself is enough for me to know the turtle library well

reviews.author: KevinP
reviews.title: Nice course, but not for grading
reviews.comment_content:
Python is really a good language for beginners, but be carefully if you want to get good grade in this course.
This course teaches basic stuff about programming with Python:
input-output, loops, else-if statement, dictionary, list, tuple, recursion

Better check the other reviews for the contents because I wrote this review in winter semester, but I forgot the details and I couldn't get the resources anymore lol
reviews.comment_teaching: I skipped all lectures except the first one. I mostly self-studied through the slides. Therefore, I can't really say much for the teaching quality. The prof did give us some extra revision materials before final exams though, which is a bit helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 2 marking schemes, one is counting midterm, final and lab scores, and the other one is counting only final and lab scores, so if you screw up in midterm, you can still get back up in final.

For mid-term exam,
- average 62.1
- standard deviation 24.1
- maximum 100
- minimum 7
I got 100

For final exam,
- average 71.3
- standard deviation 20.7
- maximum 100
- minimum 4
I got 93 (only 1 question wrong)

For the labs, I got full in all of three.

In total, I got around 97.3% which gets me an A+, but I know someone who got 90% only gets a B+, so obviously getting into the A range requires 90%+, which is ridiculous comparing to the other semesters.

The mean of the exams is so high, because the questions are mostly shorter and easier comparing to previous exams, plus people could literally type the program out to get answers, i.e. people with no or little programming knowledge can also get half of the questions correct. This semester's exams are literally just a typing speed test. Good luck to you all who are doing this course in the future.
reviews.comment_workload: only 3 hand-in lab, which are guided by videos and instructions on the website, throughout the whole semester, which is a pretty low workload I think

reviews.author: jeek

reviews.comment_teaching: His lessons are very entertaining. there is no way you are going to fall asleep if you attend the lecture in person, TAs are very helpful, for lab work you just need to follow the instructions written and watch the videos recorded by TAs, no need attend zoom lab sections unless you want to raise questions to TAs
reviews.comment_grading: You have to make sure you make very few mistakes in midterm and final. Depending on the grading method, lab work may be more important than midterm. Midterm and final are both conducted online and you have to do it on canvas, while recording your working area on zoom, super good grade!!!
reviews.comment_workload: Very few workload, you don't have to attend lectures, you can absolutely review lecture notes on your own and do everything by yourself, the website has everything you need including lecture video recordings, notes, interactive examples for you to try out, and even exam past paper system to attempt two weeks before exam periods that has a collection of at least 3 to 4 past papers with detailed explanations as guidance

I skipped all lessons except the first one

reviews.author: Dewa
reviews.comment_content: all of python basics. the things you can usually find when you search "How to code python" on google and they give you like course. It'll then use turtle graphics which tbh is mostly useless for later comp courses but i guess its for teaching the basics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor David is one of, if not the best teacher I've ever had. He teaches everything in very simple and easy manner, he gives a lot of examples, and he's overall a very energetic and nice guy. All his lectures have been great.
reviews.comment_grading:
There's 2 grading methods:
- 24% midterm + 36% lab + 40% finals
- 42% lab + 58% finals

They'll choose the better grade for you.

Labs are super easy. But because of that, average is usually high (like 80-95), so make sure you don't make any mistakes.

Midterm and finals is less of a coding test and more of an iq test. It's all logic with very little questions on syntax or just actual programming. It is entirely possible for you to just retype the code and get the answers for that if you have a fast enough typing speed.
reviews.comment_workload: There's around 8 labs, but only 3 of them are graded. It's very easy since all you have to do is follow the instructions given and write the final few lines yourself. A template is given so you don't even have to write code from scratch.

reviews.author: witty
reviews.comment_content:
Basic programming in python
if/ielse, for loops, list, turple, dictionaries, classes, function, recurtion, turtle graphics( moving and drawing, handling color, filling, text/number input and output, shape control, turtle window setup...)
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor actually teaches well and the course content is easy to understand. If you send an email to the professor to ask questions, he will always reply to you in time. But because the content of the course is relatively simple, the class is sometimes boring. If you have learned python systematically before, you may not need to attend classes at all, but if you are learning programming for the first time, listening to classes will help you a lot
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading methods（automatically take the highest one for the final grade)

Midterm 24%, Lab projects 36%, Final exam 40%
Midterm 0%, Lab projects 42%, Final exam 58%

The lab projects are usually easy if you attend all the lecture. But be extremely careful：You can only use what you have learned in lectures and labs, and program according to lab's instructions. The AI system used for scoring is sometimes rigid. It may not recognize codes different from the standard answer

The mid-term exam is very easy, but the final exam is relatively difficult. In general,getting an A in this course is quite hard. It is not enough to just listen to the lecture. You need to learn more and practise more after class
reviews.comment_workload: The past paper is on the website of this course. You can do some before the exam. There seem to be a lot of questions, but the types of questions are very similar

reviews.author: Bellooo
reviews.title: fair enough
reviews.comment_content:
Basic programming in python
If then else, for loop, while loop, list, class, array, dictionary, functions and recursion
Also Turtle graphic, which is for drawing things in python
I really do not like the turtle part.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Nice but I did not actually attend most of the lessons.
You can find the lecture videos online if you missed the lesson, or you can sit other lesson taught by other professors if you do not like your prfessor.
No attendance taken
reviews.comment_grading:
I was around 5 marks above mean and I got B.
I believe that mean is in fact lower than median since there are quite some people with programming background who gets very high or full marks.
The exam really needs you to be careful as we do not have any step marks, it is like MCs.
The exam is open book but we do not really have much time to look around for answer since the time is packed.
reviews.comment_workload:
Low workload for people with basic programming background, but it may be a bit difficult for people without any programming language to catch up..
I did programming (software development) in DSE and I only need to work a bit on turtle and recursion.

reviews.author: Jerryyy
reviews.comment_content: It's an introductory computer science course based on Python with turtle graphics. In this course, you're expected to learn basic programming techniques (for example nested if-else statement, for loop, while loop, to name but a few) and build-in functions on Python IDE. In general, I believe turtle graphics is a nice tool for beginners to understand programming clearly.
reviews.comment_teaching: Awesome, please don't hesistate to ask questions before / after lectures!!! Gibson and David are always ready and glad to answer your questions. However, please try your best to solve problems first before asking them, which helps improve your problem-solving abilities for exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grade: A-range (Overall 92 - 100%)

Tbh, the final exam for this semester is relatively easier than other semesters previously. Hence, if you aim A-range for this course, you're expected to score 92% or above. Please be careful, rmb to check your exam papers twice (or even more) before you submit.

Final exam:
- average 71.3
- standard deviation 20.7
- maximum 100
- minimum 4

Midterm:
- average 62.1
- standard deviation 24.1
- maximum 100
- minimum 7

Recommadation:
1. Try to get full mark in lab assignments (easy + manageable)
2. Explore extra project ideas in your free time
3. Review lecture notes beforehand (5-10 mins)

Good luck!!
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for this course is pretty light. Only 3 labs are required for submission. It is, however, advised to complete all lab assignments :) practice makes perfect.

reviews.author: Anvil
reviews.title: Should enrol for good grade
reviews.comment_content: Basic python stuff.  If/else, for loops, lists, dictionaries, basic classes, methods/functions, recursion, objects.
reviews.comment_teaching: Rossister is a fun guy. He will use different examples to illustrate the basics of programming. HIS ENGLISH IS VERY GOOD OMG
reviews.comment_grading: Very good grading. The mid-term is easy as it only requires dry run of the program. Even ppl without programming fundamentals should be able to finish the exam as it is basically an geometric test disguised as a programming test.
reviews.comment_workload: Only need to submit 3 labs out of 7 as I remember?? Those hand-in labs are required as mentioned on the course web page. Basically the lab session is only for you to chat with the TA to discover any problems in your lab. It's zoom lab only

reviews.author: Yobest
reviews.comment_content: The course mainly covers the basics of python programming as well as teaching turtle graphics. Topics covered include, but are not limited to, logic operators, loops, slicing, lists, tuples, strings, and recursion. There are powerpoint slides that help you understand the course materials as well as interactive programming exercises, so the content is fairly easy to comprehend even if you have no previous  knowledge of programming. Even if you fail to
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. Alex Lam is a easy-to-approach professor, as he is friendly and willing to answer your questions even after the lessons. He also reviews memes before the lessons start to help lighten the mood and engage with his students.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading system is written very clearly on the course' page. There are two ways to calculate your final grade: the first one includes your midterm grades while the second one only includes your final exam marks and assignment grades. The exams are not that hard, but if you are not careful and make some silly mistakes it could cost you a lot of marks.
Final exam:
- average 71.3
- standard deviation 20.7
- maximum 100
- minimum 4
Mid term:
- average 62.1
- standard deviation 24.1
- maximum 100
- minimum 7
I got a 92 in my final exam and a 77 in my midterm, so I used the second calculation method for my grades and got an A. A-range is not hard as long as you submit all your assignment and are careful, but competition is fierce at the top so getting A+ is not that easy.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite low, as throughout the whole term there were only three assignments. The other labs were optional, but some programs could be reused during the final exams, so it is encouraged to finish the labs on your own.

reviews.author: Christian_Chow
reviews.comment_content:
textbook (15chapters) + a few things that are not in the textbook (e.g RGB and changing the coordination system of the turtle window)

the official List of Topics
Introduction to Python
Introduction to Turtle Graphics
Comments and Text
Making Decisions (if, else, elif)
Loops (for, while)
Lists and Tuples
Slicing (same format as range() start, target, step)
Functions
Data Types
File Handling
Dictionaries (the key-value pair)
State Diagrams (the graph of making decisions)
Turtle Object Creation (turtle.[name])
Event Handling (click, drag, press...)
Stacks (did not teach)
Advanced Operators
Objects (which have attribute and behaviors)
Recursion

and some more (e.g. file handling)
reviews.comment_teaching: interesting and relative short lectures
reviews.comment_grading:

- minimum 4

Mid term:

- minimum 7

all labs are basically full mark
outcome A+

Read the textbook

reviews.author: judgcc
reviews.title: Basic intelligence filter
reviews.comment_content: Basics of Python (Uses 3.10.4), e.g. loops, functions, slicing, lists, strings and tuples, on click/drag events, understanding of nuances on how Python interprets your code that may lead to errors. Heavy emphasis on the use of Turtles
reviews.comment_teaching:
Every lecture is only 50 minutes, hot damn

Gibson’s great in just about every way - Clear English with a good tone, easy-going style of teaching with occasional humor, content is taught by writing code live to demonstrate examples along with powerpoint (which he never completely relies on). Will answer questions in Cantonese too after lectures.

No attendance needed for any lectures, you can also hop over to other professors’ lectures if you feel like it. Recordings for every lecture of every professor are uploaded to the course website
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading I suppose, but since this is a trivial course meant to be an intelligence filter, you better not fuck anything up :)

Mid-terms is ez

Finals is just slightly more difficult, the only thing to pick on is how constrained it is for time, a lot of us didn’t have enough time to finish every question.

Format of mid-terms and finals is done online by Zoom and Canvas, you read the program given for the question and it is either a fill-in-the-blank or MC for the missing part of code or the output given by the program
reviews.comment_workload:
6 Lab assignments are given about every 2 weeks, only 3 of them are mandatory to hand-in (guessing game, jigsaw puzzle, music system), there’s an optional lab session you can head to on Zoom to ask questions on the assignment, but it’s not needed, given how they will give you like literally 80% of the guideline and idea on how to finish the assignment on the course website every time

Guessing game and Jigsaw puzzle took 0 effort to get a 100% on, but Music system was the great filter in difficulty - If you were around on Goop at that time, you would’ve known how many people were asking for the code to finish the last part of the music system, I’d say that’s a skill issue tho :)

reviews.author: Blue science
reviews.comment_content:
This course should be named:
Introduction to Python OR Introduction to Turtle Graphics

I think it is not too good to start for students that would like to pursue their career in computer science since this is too easy. Students that are passionate in the field should be able to learn all the contents of the course in half a month instead of three months.

It is not bad for other students to learn some programming skills since this is indeed the trend of the Information Age.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think Prof. Alex Lam teaches quite well. His teaching can be understood really easily.

I don't know much to comment on because I already knew Python before I took this course but I see him answering questions using Cantonese, Mandarin, and English after class, so I feel like it wouldn't be hard for students with no programming background to understand.
reviews.comment_grading:
I have some background in programming so I think the course is not too hard to get a good grade. But it is still very easy to lose points in examinations due to carelessness. I didn't get full marks in the mid-term examination because of that. Luckily, the second scheme doesn't count mid-term, and I got full marks in all labs and final examinations so I get A+.

This semester's mean mark is so high for the final examination and turns out the cutoff is very very high. I would say I am just lucky enough to get full marks this time. But the grade is still very bad for most people.

I recommend you take the exams in the quiet rooms even if they give you the option to take that on Zoom (if you are just taking that yourself:)) because it is really easy to get mark penalties if you do it on Zoom.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are only three hand-in labs in the whole semester. They only took you several hours each even if you didn't learn programming before.

If you have learnt programming before and understand, you can finish them easily in one hour each, which is approximately zero workload.

Be careful about the deadline though. Don't miss the deadline for the hand-in labs. It would be an automatic zero if you miss the deadline. And check the marking scheme carefully so you don't lose points.

reviews.author: MavericK.17
reviews.comment_content:
To be honest, you would find it pretty easy if you learned some programming before the course. Don't think you could handle it if you took ICT in DSE. It is way not enough for this course.

To me, I had some coding experience in C in secondary school, meanwhile attended the school robotics team. Before the semester started, I simply watched a 4-hours beginner course of Python on YouTube during the summer. So, you can get a good grade for 100% sure if you have similar background.

For this course, what you really need to pay attention to is the coding part. You need to write codes step-by-step and by yourself. Don't ask your friends or your instructors at the beginning, ask Google instead. Therefore, you can learn better through your own thinking and searching process.

For the exam questions, just don't make careless mistakes.
reviews.comment_teaching: Instructors would put everything on the CSD website, including ppts, past papers, lecture videos, even a searching system which allows student to find different past paper questions by topic. Overall, you probably don't need to worry about the teaching.

reviews.title: not a good grade course
reviews.comment_content:
Easy python coding.
Including:
If else
While loop
Recursion
Use of Python turtles

reviews.comment_teaching: I just attend the first lecture, but I think it is quite good. You can attend any lectures you like. So, you can try the teaching style of different lecturers.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very bad.
There are two schemes
1 Exam + lab
2 Exam + lab + midterm
You will automatically use the highest scores scheme.
This year the exam has a hidden strict requirement that he never mentions. ( I argued with him and he replied repeatedly ' We mentioned the requirement' but didn't answer the real question. This time he use the camera requirement to deduct 10 marks, next time you may be penalized 80 marks as you use python 3.10.5, not 3.10.4. The exam details should clearly state every requirement and its penalty. He cannot argue with this point so he just said 'we cannot give you special treatment' and reduced the penalty for all students by half. But still, this unclarity should not happen. ) After the penalty(deducted 5 marks on the final), I got only 93.6/100 overall. And my grade is A-. If I didn’t get penalized, I should get at least an A. In addition, 77%（about mean） is C+, and 96% is A after the penalty.  So, this year the course is a bad grade.
reviews.comment_workload: 3 hand in lab assignments and each lab required 1-2 hours. You can easily get 100 in labs. No workload.

or

Standard deviation 24.1
Maximum 100
Minimum 7

reviews.author: bobo_biu
reviews.title: Short review summary
reviews.comment_content:
1. Demonstrate programming skills, with an emphasis on the Python programming language.
2. Write programs in interesting areas such as game programming, computer graphics and user interface design.

Exemplary:
1. The student is able to proficiently program in the Python language with no or very few errors, and is able to detect and fix bugs in the code on his/her own. The program can return the correct output on all input instances.
2. Given the application requirement for a specific area, the student is able to proficiently write a program that meets the requirement.

Competent:
1. The student is able to program in the Python language satisfactorily. The code may contain a few bugs, but the student is able to identify the majority of the bugs on his/her own. Given some further help, the student is able to identify and fix all the bugs. The program can return the correct output on most input instances, but may miss some special or bounda
2. Given the application requirement for a specific area, the student is able to write a Python program that meets the requirement satisfactorily. The program may crash or behave incorrectly under some harsh tests.

Needs Work:
1. The student is able to barely program in the Python language on his/her own, but with some help, he/she is able to write a program that behaves correctly on typical input instances. The code often contains bugs and the student is hardly able to identify or correct them.
2. Given the application requirement for a specific area, the student is barely able to write a program that meets the requirement.
reviews.comment_teaching: Under Gibson's teaching, it is truly easy and fun to learn about basic computer science. He is also patient to answer all the question from the students and give a hand when it is needed. Somehow we usually make mistake, he is still very supported and won't be nonsense.
reviews.comment_grading: I haven't been graded yet, but I have heard from other student that it wouldn't be very difficult to get a good grade in this class, which can also be seen according to the personality of the teacher Gibson. (He is not a very serious person and I assume that he may be quite nice in grading and care more about participation of the students.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload and the class is quite flexible due to the flexibility of the arrangement of class. The student can choose whether they want to put their mid-term grade into their final mark.
