reviews.author: RoundGlasses
reviews.comment_content: Content is pretty rudimentary. You learn about the basics of Python, which is useful. You will also learn about "Turtle", which really isn't going to be used much in the future, but alas. All content is available on the course website.
reviews.comment_teaching: The three main teachers (of my cohort) should be pretty much good. You can't go wrong choosing Professor Rossiter and Professor Gibson, as they use examples taken from outside the slides. Professor Lam Ngok uses the slides a lot more.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is pretty sketchy, and largely depends on your cohort / batch. Some batches get good grades, some batches get really difficult exams (which is pretty much what happened during my batch), such that the Average Score of this course varies wildly from cohort to cohort.

Generally, the midterm is easier, so you should try to get better scores here. I believe that the mean for Fall 2021 was around 75-80.

Labs are pretty self explanatory. You get instructions, you do them, done. They're straightforward, compulsory, and you pretty much shouldn't get anything less than 100 on the graded ones.

The final exam can vary wildly in difficulty depending on your batch. For all intents and purposes, I'm just going to tell about my cohort's exam. Long story short, it's quite hellish for people who just "get by" during the labs and stuff. The mean was around 40, but some people can get really high marks.
reviews.comment_workload: Lectures and labs are the only things you get. It's a normal workload. You get a whole week to do the labs, so that's pretty much doable. You do have to study outside of class hours if you want to get really high marks for the exam, but that's just it.

reviews.comment_grading:
Better go to the midterm cuz they will automatically choose the method for higher marks. Even though you mess up the midterm is still acceptable.

They will release the past papers with answers which is such a nice and warm action! If you want to get good results, finishing all the past papers twice is highly recommended. The first time helps you to understand the method and logic to complete that question type while the second time allows you to make sure how to utilize the principles and logic.

Most importantly, there will probably don't have enough time for you to finish every question. Hence, please try to time yourselves when doing the past papers to test your limit.

reviews.author: Sudha
reviews.title: AHHHH
reviews.comment_content: The content and assignments seemed easy and were super intriguing. I found learning about the coding language and trying out various exercises extremely fun, however, the final exam was most definitely challenging
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is good. Most profs are very lively and answer questions
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading for the assignments and the weekly labs are fair. Especially easy to ace and get high grades. I would say this is the part where most students get the grades because the labs are easy grades. The midterm is also pretty reasonable, but studying doesn't really help as much as you might think. The exam is definitely hard and challenging and does require a good understanding and ability to apply the content.

The curve is fair for the final and midterm and there are various grading formulas and the highest grade is chosen after all this. I think that is the bright side to this. Doing well on the labs and midterm would help you compensate for a shitty final.

For me the final went terribly, it was one of the worst exams I could ahve imagined. The irony was that i did infact revise and spend hours flipping through my notes and practicing. since my labs were all complete and I ended up with aa  100% there and my midterm was satisfactory, the final didn't hurt me too much. Thr main thing to remember is that the final and midterm are open book but it's not helpful because of the time constraints and the ppqs are way easier than the final.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is manageable. Weekly assignments but the lab takes no more than a couple hours. Other than that. there isnt' any homework or essays. The focus is purely on the final and midterm.

Attached to this review is the guideline or curriculum for the course, it gives a general idea of what the course covered and what is taught through the various labs and lessons.

The sessions are pretty long and attending them helps, but I would say that even if you don't attend them it is possible to do well in the course.

reviews.comment_teaching:
In my opinion, Professor ROSSITER taught well. His lectuers are very engaging as he open IDLE and use various examples to demonstrate instead of reading throug the lecture notes. He gave lectures passionately, which I think is very effective in keeping students' attention in online classes. He is humorous and explains the contents clearly and in detail. He also replies to emails. There is a textbook for this course, but I think lecture notes are useful and comprehensive enough. All in all, I think he is a great teacher.
    I think COMP1021 is a well-established course. The course website lists out all useful materials (lecture notes, examples, interactive examples, recordings, zoom video links etc.) in an clear and organized way. Pastpapers with answers and video explanations will be released before exams. Besides pastpapers, the interactive examples are also useful practices to make sure you understand what is taught.
    There are TAs to answer your questions every lecture. There are also lab sessions in which you can ask questions about the lab project. You can also ask about anything in the discussion part in canvas, so there are many ways to get help.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading is good...?
midterm:
- average 57.8
- standard deviation 22.5
- maximum 100
- minimum 5
final exam:
- average 74.5
- standard deviation 19.4
- maximum 100
- minimum 0
I heard that final exam in last semester is difficult, but perhaps due to the pandemic, this semester's final exam isn't.
There are two grading schemes and they will automatically use the best assessment for you.
• Midterm 24%, lab projects 36%, final exam 40%
• Midterm 0%, lab projects 42%, final exam 58%
100 in midterm, 93 in final, 100 in lab, A+
reviews.comment_workload:

The  lab project take some time, but as the TAs give most of the codes and detailed guidance on the lab page and there are so many venues for you to seek help, it is reasonable to aim for 100 in all of them.

reviews.author: Markus:)
reviews.title: A fairly decent course for first year students or anyone interested in COMP
reviews.comment_content:
An introduction to Computer Science which covers data types(ints, strings, bools), handling of data types via lists, loops, tuples, functions, etc. The course also goes into some operators such as the Modulus operator.

Basically, everything is centered around the turtle phylon graphics engine which is fairly weird as your gonna use it in this course and then never again. Why the course puts such a heavy emphasis on Turtle graphics is a mystery to me & if I'm honest I'm pretty sick of seeing it. All in all a pretty decent syllabus but if you've not used/heard of the turtle graphics engine before id get familiar with it as all of your Labs are linked to it one way or another.
reviews.comment_teaching: I liked Wilfred a lot, he's a very good teacher who does a good job at explaining the workings of the code. He strictly explains the examples from the Lecture presentation so take that as you wish. He answers emails fairly fast & has a pretty good accent for UST standards (cough cough math department).
reviews.comment_grading:
Labs:
Grading for this course was all over the place and fairly poor overall. The labs make up between 36% & 42% of your final grade which is very heavy given that basically everyone gets 100% on them. The grading for most of the labs is automatic so make sure to read the instructions carefully.

Midterm:
The midterm was pretty easy making up 24% or 0% of your grade.  Since the average is fairly high I studied for it and got a satisfactory grade.

Final:
The final is HELL and is more of a reading comprehension exam than anything else. It makes up between 40% to 58% of your grade so you definitely don't want to mess that one up. The explanation for the questions is extremely long so your gonna have a serious advantage if you are a fast reader & can type fast aswell. I personally wasn't able to complete the final because I'm a fairly slow reader and straight-up didn't have enough time to read the last 2 questions.

Grading formula:
The only reaming thing about the grading in this course is that it uses 2 formulas to calculate your grade & takes the higher result of the 2 as your final score.

Formula 1: Midterm 24% , Lab 36%, Final 40%
Formula 2: Midterm 0%, Lab 42%, Final 58%
reviews.comment_workload: As stated before the only real workload is the labs, take your time with those to make sure that you will get full marks. Furthermore, I learned a lot through challenging myself with little projects which was a fairly fun way to learn.

Midterm 24%, Labs 36% and Final 40% OR

reviews.author: chilboi_pillboi
reviews.title: Really enjoyed the course
reviews.comment_content:
The content is very comprehensive. It covers a lot of the basics and it definitely trains a programming mindset. The focus will be on topics like if/else statements, loops, functions, lists, dictionaries, recursion, and a brief intro to objects. Things like these are gonna pop up in other programming languages so it really gives you that mindset. There is also a large focus on using Turtle Graphics, so make sure you're familiar with that.

They definitely teach you from zero and assume you don't have prior knowledge in programming, so don't worry if you don't know programming but want to enroll in this course. I didn't know programming before this course and the contents were quite easy to grasp.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Sung was amazing. Some other reviews on here complain about his accent but I think it was fine. It sounded kinda cute too. Sung makes his lectures interesting and I've never slept in his lectures. I couldn't say the same about other lecturers. Sung also interacts with the class by asking us questions. He also does demonstrations in class which makes what we're learning very clear.

Big props to David (course coordinator) too and actually the whole COMP1021 team for making all the course materials readily available online. The revision materials are super comprehensive, super neat, and super easy to find. There are also lots of interactive exercises on the website for us to familiarize ourselves with the concepts we've learned and put what we've learned into practice, which is very nice because education is supposed to be two-wayed.

If you are a fast learner, I'd definitely suggest Sung. He doesn't assume you have prior programming knowledge, but he goes through content faster than David and Gibson. He also teaches extra things that might help improve your programming skills, which is a bonus if you're thinking of learning more COMP in the future. But if you are not a fast learner and think you're bad with things like programming, I'd suggest David and Gibson. I've sat in their lectures before and they go through concepts slowly, but more clearly. They're probably the pick for people who think they might struggle.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two grading methods: 24% midterm + 36% lab + 40% final OR 42% lab + 58% final.

I'd definitely suggest taking the midterm because the midterm is often a lot easier than the final.

For lab assignments, the mark scheme is very clear so it is not hard to get 100. But then again almost everyone gets 100 for lab so it doesn't give you much of an edge.

The final is kind of like the be-all and end-all. Even though the exams are online and open-book, they make it purposefully short so Googling your answers would be a waste of time. The final had a mean of like 48 so I guess a lot of people tripped up on that, not because the questions were hard, but because of the time.

I will not reveal my grade but I have to say I was quite happy with what I got, considering I have no programming background prior to taking the course.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is better than other courses. You get lab assignments, but they don't really take that much time. I've spent more time worrying about other courses than COMP, which shows the workload is reasonably light.

reviews.author: nillius
reviews.title: human aptitude / geometry test disguised as programming course
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Python stuff. If/else, for loops, lists, dictionaries, basic classes, methods/functions, recursion.

Also, Turtle graphics (a library where you draw pictures using "turtles", which are basically just brushes/pens which you move around using code).

Content should be extremely easy if you've done any form of programming before. But be careful in Python with data types since it's type-optional (and type hints aren't taught or provided in exams)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Alex Lam (my professor) is good at teaching and repeats things to make sure things are clear, since programming concepts are often unintuitive at first and require reinforcement when first encountering them.

However, the lectures for me were a waste of time as I already knew programming. I skipped most of the lectures so I can't say much else about the teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading methods.

24% midterm + 36% lab + 40% final
OR
42% lab + 58% final

There are 7 labs + one intro lab, 3 of which are graded out of 100.

Labs are easy, but be extremely careful and check each case carefully as often there are no partial marks and one silly mistake causing your program to crash in a test case can cost you 20% of the lab score. (true story D:). The labs usually have a mean of 90-100 with s.d 8-10.

The midterm is fairly easy, as long as you're somewhat careful and double-check your answers. If you've done programming, you should have at least half the time to check your answers. Exams are done remotely this semester. Mean was 71.9 with s.d about 21.4.

However, the final is hell. There is barely enough time for you to check your answers. The questions are extremely weird and try to trick you, for example by multiplying a number by 2 but they made the number a string instead of an int. You have to be extremely careful. The mean this semester was 48.57 with s.d 19.29.

Alternatively, you can see the final as a typing test and just type out all the code they don't let you copy. If you are fast enough at typing (at least 90-100wpm) then this is actually a viable option for you, and makes the final much less stressful.

My scores:
Lab 1 - 80%
Lab 2 - 100%
Lab 3 - 100%
Mterm: 90%
Final: 100% (after grading change)

Overall: ~97% (definitely enough for A+)

It is quite difficult to get an A/A+ even if you've already programmed before, because the exams basically are a human aptitude test or a geometry test disguised as a Python exam. There are only one or two questions where you use Python to solve a problem. They purposely make the tests tricky and weird because too many people going into this course can already program so they had to "fix the curve" somehow
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is extremely light.

7 labs + 1 intro lab, 3 of which are handed in and also graded. Non-graded labs do not have to be done but I recommend at least skimming them as they often re-use lab content in the final exams.

The actual labs are easy, as long as you know how to read instructions and do some basic programming.

reviews.author: wqaed
reviews.title: Basic python but difficult to score High
reviews.comment_content:
This course teaches Python 3 using turtle library. You can think of it as teaching programming with the help of graphical representation. Most of the concept will be represented by pictures within the ppt or using example programs.

Lecture:
No attendance is required, 1.5 hours(or 1hr forgot) per lecture, 2 lecture per week. with 1 lab but is not mandatory to attend if you don't have any questions to ask.

Materials, content:
1. basic syntax (indent, variable naming restriction)
2. printing things to console.
3. variables (Gibson teaches this concept pretty well with a gentle learning curve throughout the course)
4. if else (using graphics on the screen, so wont be a problem if you understand logics)
5. loops (for while)
6. File Read write
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gibson teaches python in a fun way by providing examples outside the reading materials. Even if you dont read the ppt beforehand you should be able to understand most of the concept within the lecture.
You can ask questions after class using email any time, but never use canvas, as they might not be able to receive your questions.
You can also ask question in class and he will answer you by modifying the in class example he created, should be enough for most students to understand the concept.
reviews.comment_grading:
Better be prepared to get a B or C if you dont have programming experience. If you dont have any experience, try to get full marks on **all** hand-in labs. (total 3 out of 5)
If you are familiar with python, watch out for variable name and don't trust the comments within the exam or midterm, they can be fake.
reviews.comment_workload:
workload is acceptable for a intro course, inexperienced students should be able to finish the labs with the help of TA within 5hrs.
The 3 hand-in labs are distributed in alternative weeks, each will have 7 - 8 days to finish depending on which day you have lab.

It should be noted that content is closely related to logic, so those who are not familiar with programming may take more time or some help to clarify the logic involved.
reviews.comment_teaching: Clear and flexible teachings, and do not leave gaps with missing knowledge. While notes are equally helpful, the instructor (or at least, my instructor) does not strictly follow the notes but is still able to clarify concepts.
reviews.comment_grading: Doesn't really take much for good grades. Open-book assessments and fast typing would probably give you an A.
reviews.comment_workload: Barely any workload, only a few "lab" assignments needed to do over the whole semester, and actual "lab" sessions can be skipped if you don't need help. Dynamic schedule, you can practically ignore the provided timeslots and attend another lecture or lab session as suggested by my instructor. (defo do not suggest you to skip lectures especially if you aren't certain with your abilities)

reviews.author: FabianGer
reviews.comment_content:
Basics of Python 3.9 and turtle module as a light graphics libary (you are most likely not going to use turtle after this course).

The python includes If/else, for loops, lists, dictionaries, basic classes, methods/functions, recursion. All in all it's pretty beginner-friendly. Thus, it's absolutely easy for anyone with programming experience. In this case you only have to learn the libary (and some state diagrams).
reviews.comment_teaching:
LAM Ngok is a good teacher, he is willing to answer your questions, but lectures might be boring and slow for a person with previous knowledge. You can skip the live, and use a higher speed for the video.
The TA is very helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is really fair.

There are 2 ways of grading:
24% midterm + 36% lab + 40% final
or
42% lab + 58% final.
They will automatically choose the better one for you.

The lab assignments are not hard, most people get full marks. So you only have to do well in the midterm and final exam. Even though the mid-term can be ignored with latter grading method, I wouldn't recommend it as the average result in the mid-term is way better than in the final exam.
90% or more in total will get you into A range.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is pretty light. There is a lab each week but only 3 labs are graded. You don't need to attend the lectures if you don't want to.

reviews.author: Newstarts
reviews.title: Gd grade course even that you have no ICT/Coding background
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Python knowledge (I really don't know why they use the introduction to "CS" not the "PYTHON" as the title)

Turtle drawing
Basic Loop
List and string
Logical function (if, while, for, True or False)
Easy math formula in python and basic text skill (Print ("Hello World :)") )
(I am sorry that the order didnt follow their syllabus becuz I just write it by my memory)
reviews.comment_teaching: I love David! His lessons are quite interesting that he will never follow the ppt and he will give us a lot of examples for practice! The lesson is funny enough to catch ur eyesight I think.
reviews.comment_grading:
For me I think it is a gd grade course I think.

I am really an keyboard idiot I think since that I still dont know how to play online games by using keyboard (I am typing very slowly for this review TwT)

I got 0.8sd higher than MT but lower than FE for 3 pts because he adjust the standard of the FE for twice and I didnt get any benefit from it (At first I was above mean for 3 pts)

The LAB I get all of them for Full Mark (It's easy for everyone if you watch the videos of the LABs, right? Because the MEAN is about 98 ^-^)

Finally Grade: B+ (My fri get 3 pts lower than me in the final grade and he's still B+ too and I think the range is quite large)
reviews.comment_workload:
Light enough that every week you only need to pay less than 3 hr (Including both the review and the lecture time) to handle all the knowledge.

Three LABs in two months are needed, although u cannot cheat by copy others, you still can ask TAs and frds of the logic. But you can handle it by urself easily in no more than 4 - 5 hrs .

reviews.author: sdfedghrfdhsdgf
reviews.comment_content: Python for beginners, very easy to learn and understand
reviews.comment_teaching: Easy to follow，the teaching was fun, the speaking was really clear even use speed 2x
reviews.comment_grading: Good grade, make sense. There are two marking method, you can skip the mid term if you do not want to attend. But Final Exam is a must. You can get full marks on all labs cus there are tutorials teaching you how to do the lab got a B with two below mean exam
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very low, only few Lab with tutorial, twice a month.

reviews.author: Kanav
reviews.comment_content: If you have any experience with coding before the content is not too heavy and should be easy to get a good grade. But if you have no experience, can be a bit difficult as every small mistake can bring your grade down a lot.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is really nice and explains everything in detail. Easy to understand him and gives great examples and revision materials.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is very fair and based on a curve. There are two pathways, one including the midterm scores and the other not including the midterm scores. They choose the best pathway for you.

There are labs every week but only 4 labs are graded and its easy to get full marks in them as you can test it as many times as you want before submitting it.

Attendance is not graded. Midterm is fairly easy but the final exam is far more difficult.
reviews.comment_workload: Not too much workload. The labs every week are not compulsory but they are helpful and recommended to do. The labs are great practice for the midterm and final exam.

reviews.author: DarrenT
reviews.title: Good
reviews.comment_content: It is not about programming, just logic games. You can understand and attain good grades if you have a normally-functioning brain. I mean, just the lectures. For the exams, your brain acts like an audrino running 3A games. Good Luck!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gibson is good, cuz he uses many examples during lessons.
And mainly cuz of he offers zoom lessons, so I like him...
reviews.comment_grading:
Please get as high marks as you can in the assignments, as they are so simple, and the mean is 9x. (avoid minor mistakes!)
The mid-term exam is fine and easy, so it only contributes so lil percentage to your final grade T.T
There's another scoring scheme to exclude the final, which I strongly do not suggest.
The final is so dang difficult. Not difficult actually, but it's impossible to complete all questions (I completed 60% only lmao)

All assignments full mark, midterm 9x per cent, final just mean
got A-
reviews.comment_workload: 0, I mean, only 3-4 assignments, each spends you about 2 hrs. So good

reviews.author: jc01
reviews.title: easy course for beginners
reviews.comment_content: Nice for beginners, but a bit too easy for those who learned any programming languages before. Not so much content for beginners. It is easy to follow
reviews.comment_teaching: Easy to understand and has recordings in every lecture, very convenient. The lecturer expresses well to follow in every lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading methods.
1. Mid 24%, lab 36%, final 40%
2. Mid 0%, lab 42%, final 58%

mt and final reach the mean and I got a B
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite small.
You just need to finish three labs only and if you already understood the things taught in class. That's not very much.

reviews.author: wnYPXmoYnH3KH7
reviews.comment_content:
Not too hard even if you don't have prior programming experience
Mostly basic programming logic, Python syntax and then some turtle graphics

The programming concepts taught will be relevant in the future if you do more programming (can't say the same about turtle graphics)
reviews.comment_teaching:
imo reading lecture notes is sufficient (esp. if you have programming experience)
But if you are confused Prof. Rossiter does a very good job explaining the course materials
They also provide 6(? I forgot) past papers before midterms/finals
reviews.comment_grading:
3 labs + midterm + final
Does not take attendance
Midterm/finals were open book + you could run any code you wanted (you weren't allowed to copy some code but you could type it in yourself)
Labs/midterms were very easy but finals were much harder
If you mess up during midterms you can go all in on finals and still get a good final grade


FYI:
All 3 labs: 100/100
Midterm: 100/100
Final: 71/100
Final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Very low
Only 3 hand-in labs (i.e. roughly 1 lab per month)
90% of the lab tasks are taught step by step through videos on the webpage so it's very easy

You can do the other labs yourself to familiarize yourself with Python syntax/turtle functions if you want
Exams are open book but it helps to be familiar with the turtle functions to save time

reviews.author: cliff.wmf
reviews.title: hellish final exam with good grading
reviews.comment_content:
Course content include:
1. random
2. turtle graphics
3. if statement
4. while loop (infinite while loop /nested loops)
5. for loops with mod (%)
7. lines/ tuples/ strings
8. slicing/ global and local variables
9. dictionaries/ functions/ logic

Lecture:
twice per week, with each lecture 50 min on zoom
there will be a two hours lab session once a week
No attendance needed. Content will be based on ppt on course website https://course.cse.ust.hk/comp1021/
Textbooks are recommended to students (《Interactive Python Programming for Beginners》) but you do not need them for your exam as the course materials are sufficient to deal with exams

Assignment:
Only lab projects once a week (three hand-in labs and other labs which are not compulsory to hand in)

Exams arrangement (open-booked for python/ notes)
1. conducted via zoom (you can apply for seats for exams since the professor will book some rooms)
2. uses canvas system
3. exam papers sent thru outlook
4. exams are divided into two parts with toilet breaks
5. Midterm exam: first part has 7 questions and 2nd part has 5 questions with 25 mins in each part
6. Final: each part has 9 questions with 40 mins in each part
7. some question may need to use python or IDLE while use of papers are welcomed.
8. practice exam will be held before mid term only, which is not compulsory for participation

There are some revision materials offered by the course so don't worry about past papers.
Besides, you can download past papers in petergao.net
reviews.comment_teaching:
The course offers some online zoom session and some f2f session. Overall speaking, David is a good professor who uses various examples to explain concepts. David Rossiter and Lam Gibson are recommended by many students.

I took the zoom course with professor David Rossiter. I didn't attend many class since it was too early and I want to sleeeeeeeeeeeep.
reviews.comment_grading:
there are 2 assessment for grading:
1. midterm 24%, lab projects 36%, final exam 40%(recommended, since MT is so stupidly easy)
2. Midterm 0%, lab projects 42%, final exam 58%
(the assessment with the highest score will be used)

For labs, the means are very high (over 90%). Pretty easy to get full marks. If you don't know about the codes you can ask TA during lab session.

midterm exam stats:
Maximum: 100
Minimum (except zero): 10
Mean: 71.9
SD: 21.4

Final exam stats (revised):
Maximum: 100
Minimum (except zero): 4
Mean: 48.57
SD: 19.29

My scores:
full mark in all three labs and mid-term exams;
Final exams revised: 28 + 45.56 = 73.56
grade: A

basically, the mean is roughly B grade so it is a good grade course. one SD higher in final and midterm exam guarantees an A range.

For reference, I didn't take ICT in DSE
reviews.comment_workload:
very low workload since i only do compulsory hand-in labs

For revision, I complete all past papers twice and study the notes. Be careful for any careless mistakes in mid-term exam.

Final exams is hard as fuck. you need to rush through everything in order to complete the whole exam paper and EVERY QUESTIONS ARE SO BLOODY HARD LIKE WTF ARE YOU OUT OF YOUR MIND????

tips: When doing final exam, DO NOT SPEND TOO MUCH TIME READING QUESTION. You should focus on the codes and sometimes you can even skip some useless codes. Try to find the codes that only matters to the answers.

Good luck.

reviews.author: EddieL.
reviews.title: Easy for someone who has programming background
reviews.comment_content:
Use python to teach basic programming, e.g. if, else, while, file handling
Teaches turtle graphics. It is quite interesting to learn as it actually draw something instead of just letters and numbers.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I just attended the first two lessons and I skipped lessons after that. Based on those lessons, I think Prof. Gibson Lam is good. His analogy on the topics is easy to understand. His tone is interesting so you are not likely to fall asleep.I think the pace is a little slow. Teaches 1-2 topics in a 50-minutes lessons. But maybe the reason is I already learned some basics before.

I think it is more efficient to learn the content by reading the notes or learn it using other resources online like YouTube
reviews.comment_grading:
2 ways to calculate score, take the higher one
1. Midterm 24%, Lab projects 36%, Final exam 40%
2. Midterm 0%, Lab projects 42%, Final exam 58%

Midterm
Mean: 71.9
SD: 21.4

Final
Mean: 47.57
SD: 18.98

What I got
Lab: full
Midterm: full
Final: 77/100
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Low
Only 3 lab, which has teaching video to guide you through and clear marking scheme that you can see what you need to do
Give you a week to do
Takes about 1-2 hours to finish

reviews.author: m****6
reviews.comment_content:
Basic stuff of Python:
- Beginning to Python (loops, lists...)
- Coordinate system
- Data type
- Dictionary
- File handling
- Function
- Object
- Recursion
- Turtle
etc.

The course mainly focuses on teaching you how to code with Turtle, not Python itself. It's only a introductory course so don't expect much about Python itself would be taught.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gibson does not just read out the ppt, but build examples of how to build such a program in the ppt/interactive excessive LIVE.
He is also willing to answer to students' requests and questions.
Very good in terms of teaching and support to students.
reviews.comment_grading:
VERY GOOD GRADE
Two tracks:
1. Midterm included:
24% midterm + 36% lab + 40% final
2. Midterm excluded:
42% lab + 58% final

The grading system will automatically choose the track that gives you the highest mark

Lab: basically everyone got full marks because they are so easy, mean is ~98 for most of the hand-in lab(assignments)

Midterm: not that difficult, but very easy to lose mark because of careless mistakes
Max: 100, Min (except zero): 10, Mean: 71.9, SD: 21.4

Final: It's quite challenging and you basically won't have enough time to finish everything
Max: 100, Min (except zero): 4, Mean: 48.57, SD: 19.29

My scores:
Lab(assignment): full mark (100, 100, 100)
Midterm: 75/100 (because of careless mistakes, +1SD -> ~mean)
Final: 72/100 (~ +1.2SD)
Overall: ~83.76% (A)
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light workload

Lecture: 1 hour, 2 per week (no attendance, no quiz)
Lab: optional (you only have to attend the lab if you have any problem with the assignments)
Homework: a total of 8, but only 3 of them are hand-in assignment and counted towards your final grade (greatly recommended to do the non-hand-in ones as well as they might be related to your midterm/final content)

reviews.author: ypl
reviews.title: 答題機器
reviews.comment_content:
– Teaches you the basics of programming (python)
– Gives you an introduction into the ways of thinking
used by programmers
reviews.comment_teaching: You can type your questions in the chat box and TA will answer you
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 24%, Lab projects 36%, Final exam 40%
or
Midterm 0%, Lab projects 42%, Final exam 58%
Score Mean SD
3 hand-in lab full marks
MT: 100 71.9 21.4
Final: 72 48.57 19.29
Finally I got an A for this course
Exam 前會release 幾年的PP
一定要去MT MT簡單好多
兩個exam都分part 1 2
每部分40分鐘 MT每部分8題 Final 9題
完全唔夠時間做 題目的description又長又雞肋 對答題冇幫助 但唔睇又唔知個programme做緊咩
我覺得自己係答題 而唔係programming
reviews.comment_workload:
total 8 labs only 3 hand-in labs
it is quite time-consuming
I recommand you to finish all labs at least give it a look
the non-hand-in lab question may appear in the exam
I didn't do the Lab 6 so I couldn't answer one MC question in the final

reviews.author: abcd1234
reviews.comment_content: Content is quite easy to handle. Midterm's question is easy , but final can be hard.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is quite good. You can change your teacher by walk-in
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is great. Two routes can be chosen for your grading.
1. Including midterm, all assignments, Final exam
2. Not including midterm but more weight on Final exams and assignments.

The elastic grading can provide you time to adapt to the content. Even you don't have experience in programming, you have one more chance to do well in the Final.

Midterm:100/100
Final:76/100
Assignment:100/100
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: Low workload. Only 4 assignments needs to do. They are easy to do.

reviews.author: hyink
reviews.title: COMP1021
reviews.comment_content:
See others for the content.

Teaches about basic computer programming starting from dealing with strings, integers, doubles, booleans etc... and recursion at the very last lecture.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching of the course is really flexible. There were zoom video recordings available during this semester and students were able to pick any sessions and instructors they wanted to listen to.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 2 grading systems. They will automatically score on the higher grading system. The final takes up a greater proportion than the midterm (also you can skip the midterm if you want). However, the final is much more harder than the midterm. One standard deviation above on the final will guarantee you an A range (assuming you got a score on or above the mean on midterm).
Just don't skip lectures, submit your labs on time, and prepare the final exam at least 2 weeks before (do the practice exams the professors provide you) then you will do fine.
reviews.comment_workload: One lab for each week. There are total 3 labs that you need to submit through out the semester. Not really a lot of workload compared to other courses.

reviews.author: Ahzzzz
reviews.comment_content:
(please refers to other post for the lists of topics)
From the perspective of a person who have no background knowledge about coding, this course is indeed pretty easy to understand and to follow. More importantly, it grants you with a sense of satisfactory while your are studying as the your progress can be seen by the output of your code.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Lam is a decent teacher. He has great accent and is willing to help.
However, his teaching style is to go through the notes and stick with the Power Points while showcasing you with some example codes. So, if you are a fast learner and want to learn more apart from the course materials, he may not be your suitable teacher.
Also, sometimes his lesson may go slow and as the lecture I am attending is online only, the lesson will get boring pretty soon.
reviews.comment_grading:
There is in total two grading schemes for this course in this semester, one involves in mid-term while the other does not.
Scheme 1: Lab 36% Midterm 24% Final 40%
Scheme 2: Lab 42% Midterm 0% Final 58%

However, having the second grading system does not mean that you can treat midterm as nothing or skip midterm.(though they really allow so)
It it important to notice that FINAL IS POSSIBLY MUCH HARDER THAN  MIDTERM. And this applies in this semester in which the final is pretty horrifying.

For your reference here are some statistics:
Midterm: mean = 71.9 SD= 21.4
Final: mean = 48.57 SD = 19.29

Update:
Get an A at last with 95/100 in midterm and 71/100 in final

Still, for this course, the grade is indeed pretty good. Having a midterm and final mark higher than one SD than the mean can give you an A range while lower than the mean by a little still can give you a B range. And if you pay enough effort, A range is not hard at all.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not heavy.
You get 8 labs to work on in total. There will be videos guiding you through the codes nearly step by step and only three of them are hand-in labs. Each lab costs around 0.5-2 hours and you can skip the non hand-in labs if you are really lazy.(not recommended as labs are related to exams)

reviews.author: Angez
reviews.comment_content:
It's more like painting than math, just some cute turtles moving around. The graphical interface enables beginners to get immediate and intuitive feedback.
The only bad thing is the exams. Personally, I don't think they test logic for the most part.
If you want to do well, just remember:
You are not using Python.
YOU ARE PYTHON.
reviews.comment_teaching: It's easy to understand for beginner. His accent is very good, clear and slow, people who do not speak English can easily understand.
reviews.comment_grading: Surprisingly good. There are always a lot of people with programming basic in the computer class. I thought the competition would be very fierce, but A range seems to be big. Although I didn't get most of the exam questions right, I still got satisfactory grades.
reviews.comment_workload: Just several labs, almost no workload.

reviews.author: Vincentchan9839
reviews.title: print("Hello world! COMP1021 is the BEST course to learn Python and get excellent grade!!! 😆")
reviews.comment_content:
This course is very easy for those who have taken HKDSE ICT before. Python is no doubt much easier than the programming language (i.e. C language) I have taken in secondary school. If you have taken ICT in secondary school like me, then I have to say congratulations, you would probably grasp all materials really quick without much revision.

(The website of the course is the following one:

https://course.cse.ust.hk/comp1021/

)

This course involves the following things:
-2 lectures each week, 13 weeks in total
-8 labs (include both 3 hand-in labs and 5 non-hand-in labs)
-1 practice exam (help you to get familiar with the format of midterm exam, it does not count towards your final grade)
-1 real mid-term exam
-1 real final exam

Here is the syllabus:

-Course Details; Getting Started with Python

-Beginning to Program Python

-Introduction to Turtle Graphics

-Making Decisions

-Loops

-Basic Turtle Graphics Summary; Example of a Nested Loop

-Using For Loops; Using For Loops with Graphics

-Midterm Details; Lists, Tuples and Strings

-Handling Repeating Patterns; More on Loops

-Using Logic; Slicing

-Slicing, cont.; More on Lists and Strings

-Functions; Dictionaries

-Handling of Data Types

-Turtle Shapes; Creating Turtles; Clicking and Dragging Turtles

-Handling Key Presses; Clicking on the Turtle Window; An Example Game - Circles Game; Large Turtle Graphics Summary

-More on Functions

-More on Operators

-Text and File Handling

-Final Exam Details; The Coordinate System; Understanding Colours

-State Diagrams; Objects

-Objects, continued; Recursion

-Recursion, continued


Here are the names for the 8 labs in this semester:

Lab 0: Hello World and Introduction to Turtle Graphics
Lab 1: Guessing Game
Lab 2: Turtle Sketchbook (*Hand-in Lab)
Lab 3: Fireworks
Lab 4: Jigsaw
Lab 5: Amaziograph (*Hand-in Lab)
Lab 6: Music System
Lab 7: Robot Thinking Game (*Hand-in Lab)

***For the reason of why the first lab is called Lab 0, it is because everything in Python starts from zero. You should get used to this when you are enrolling in this course. 🤡🤡🤡🤡🤡🤡🤡🤡🤡🤡🤡🤡🤡🤡🤡🤡
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Gibson Lam is one of the best local professor I have seen in my very first semester for me. He is a funny guy that his humorous teaching style will definitely attract you to attend his lectures and learn something new.

He also answers my emails really quick (within a few hours). He can clearly explain the solutions to my questions. Therefore, don't afraid to ask him if you have any questions related to Python programming.
reviews.comment_grading:
Extremely good! This is the easiest course for me to get A+ so far! 😄

There are two grading method:

i)
Midterm exam: 24%
Lab projects: 36%
Final exam: 40%

ii)
Midterm exam: 0%
Lab projects: 42%
Final exam: 58%

The professors will automatically choose the highest mark of these two calculations.

Here are some statistics from my professors:

Lab 2 Turtle Sketchbook: (Full mark:100)
Average (excluding zeros) 97.8
Standard deviation (excluding zeros) 8.8
Minimum (excluding zeros) 8
Maximum 100

Lab 5 Amaziograph: (Full mark:100)
Average (excluding zeros) 98.2
Standard deviation (excluding zeros) 11.4
Minimum (excluding zeros) 5
Maximum 100

Lab 7 Robot Thinking Game: (Full mark:100)
Average (excluding zeros) 97.9
Standard deviation (excluding zeros) 8.5
Minimum (excluding zeros) 25
Maximum 100

Midterm exam: (Full mark:100)
Maximum: 100
Minimum (except zero): 10
Mean: 71.9
SD: 21.4

Final Exam: (Full mark:100)
Maximum: 100
Minimum (except zero): 4
Mean: 48.57
SD: 19.29

Here are my result:

Lab 2 Turtle Sketchbook: 100/100
Lab 5 Amaziograph: 100/100
Lab 7 Robot Thinking Game: 100/100
Midterm exam: 100/100
Final exam: 79/100

Grade: A+

Please bear in mind the final exam is much, much, much harder than the midterm exam. That is why I cannot score full mark in final exam only.

For your reference, here is my 2021 HKDSE ICT result:

ICT: Level 5*

I took Elective 4 Software Development in HKDSE ICT and C language was the programming language I learnt in senior secondary school.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only three hand-in labs, one mid-term exam and one final exam are counted to your final grades.

There are also five NON-hand-in labs that you can choose to attempt or not. Also, some interactive examples that you can try for each lecture. If you want to get a very good grade like me, I suggest you finish them all.

reviews.author: Areion
reviews.title: Good for the starters
reviews.comment_content:
Teach how to use python from zero to kind of understand how the programs work.
The course is mainly focused on how the computer thinks and how to follow the code instead of writing code yourself. But some labs need us to write part of our code.
Labs are not necessary unless you have questions. As long as you can finish the lab work and submit it on time, don't need to go to labs.
reviews.comment_teaching: Well, Professor Wilfred is very kind and very nice. But mostly reading the PowerPoint and using the codes given by the CSD, so for most of the part, reading and studying PPT will be very helpful. However, the professor will tell the important part and some demonstrations do help understand the content.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading schemes, one of them don't count the mid-term at all, so don't need to be that worried if the mid-term is bad. However, mid_term will be much easier than final. I got 100 in mid-term while only 70 in the final.
My overall grade is about 88% which gets an A. However the exam this year is very hard. So, I reckon that 90% is about the A range.
The exams are not about writing the code but giving you the code and kind of decoding it. So the logic is very important.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only need to think of lab and review. It is very easy to get a high grade if pay attention in class.
The labs are very easy, there are videos to show you how to do it and many hard parts and setting up has already been written by the professor before it is sent to students. Only some parts need to be filled in.

reviews.author: AP2112

reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_workload:
Lab projects: only do 3 projects
Since I skipped all the class, I take 1~2 hour to learn everything on ppt for doing the lab

reviews.author: szh
reviews.title: Introductory course to python programming
reviews.comment_content:
In this course you learn python programming from scratch, so it starts off with the basics, such as setting up IDLE on your computer.
The main topics in this course were:
- If statements
- For/While Loops (and nested loops)
- List, Tuples, Strings and slicing
- Data types and operators
- Functions
- Dictionaries
- Text and File handling
- State Diagrams
- Recursion
- Turtle graphics:
    - Moving/rotating turtle, drawing stuff with it
    - Objects
    - Creating turtles
    - Interacting with the turtles/turtle window

All in all, you could say the labs test your ability to apply programming concepts and follow instructions, while the exams test your ability to be perceptive and solve problems within time constraints.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor teaches in an interesting way, as he doesn’t completely rely on slides and may often use his own examples or explanations. The slides are anyways quite simple and easy to refer back to when needed. There are regular polls in class to help you ensure that you are understanding the concepts, while the TAs are available to answer any questions you may have about exams/labs.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 2 different grading schemes:
Mid term 24% Final 40% Lab 36%
MT 0% Final 58% Lab 42%

The labs are relatively easy so the mean is quite high (between 90 and 100%)
The mean for midterm was a little less than 80%, while the mean for the final exam was around 47%.

Since this course is quite easy for all the people who have done programming before, in the exams there are many long questions with code that cannot be copied, so you have to mainly use critical thinking/problem solving skills.

It becomes easier to miss certain parts of the code, and since there was barely enough time to recheck, I made a few silly mistakes in both exams. It is important to read the code to make sure you don’t fall for any of the trick questions, as you don’t get partial marks for any of them - if you get a question wrong you lose all of the marks.
reviews.comment_workload:
For someone who has done programming before, the workload is not that high. There are only 3 simple hand-in labs, all with instructions or videos to guide you step-by-step. You can do the labs at your own pace, and even finish and hand them in before the scheduled lab sessions (personally I never attended the lab sessions).

The other labs are ones that you can do in your free time, they are not compulsory, but knowledge of what they are about may help out in the final exam.

Revising for the exams is not hard as they provide past papers and interactive examples for you to work on and play around with.

You are also free to attend other lectures, the schedule for this course is quite flexible.

reviews.author: anyeongg
reviews.title: too much turtle not important in life
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1: Getting started with Python
Week 2: Beginning to Program Python and Introduction to Turtle Graphics
Week 3: Making Decisions and Loops
Week 4: Nested Loops
Week 5: Using For Loops (with and without graphics) and List, tuples, strings
Week 6: More loops, repeating patterns, logic and slicing
Week 7: More on lists and strings, functions and dictionary
Week 8: Handling of Data Types // Midterm
Week 9: More on turtles (shapes, creating turtles, clicking and dragging)
Week 10: More on Functions
Week 11: More on operators, text and file handling
Week 12: Coordinate systems, colors, state diagrams and objects
Week 13: Recursion
reviews.comment_teaching:
Labs every week but only 3 of them have to be submitted.

Hand in labs are
Lab 2: Turtle Sketchbook
Lab 5: Amaziograph
Lab 7: Robot Thinking Game

Hand in labs increase in difficulty over time.

Lectures are kind of basic, hard part is to implement concepts on practice questions given to prepare for midterm/final. For this semester there are 1200 students, hence 12 lecture sections which all have recordings posted on the course website. There are also code examples and interactive review tasks given for each topic. More interactive review tasks are given to prepare for midterm/final exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
For this semester, there are two grading schemes.

First grading scheme: Midterm 24%, Lab projects 36%, Final exam 40%
Second grading scheme: Lab projects 42%, Final exam 58%

Midterm is not very difficult but got a bad grade due to lack of preparation. So doing some past papers are recommended just to predict how difficult the midterm will be.

However, final exam is quite difficult. Two parts, 40 minutes each. 9 questions, which may be too much.
reviews.comment_workload: Overall workload is not too high. Only 3 labs to submit, and if you have some basic python knowledge then it should be fine. I learnt Computer Science in high school, and I know everything expect for turtle graphics.

reviews.author: ccychiu1125

Basic Python knowledge and concepts, with python turtle.

reviews.comment_teaching: I didn't really joined in on the lectures since I already have some prior knowledge in python. In the very few lectures I had listened to for recap, KIM is really kind and willing to answer questions. Sometimes he teaches using examples outside of PowerPoint.
reviews.comment_grading:
2 grading schemes:
24% Midterm  60% Lab  40%Final
  0% Midterm  42% Lab  58%Final

No attendance is required.

Lab is simple, plus you get to change your code until the submission deadline.

Midterm is highly recommended, very easy, it could really save you some marks.

Then there is hell: The final! It is way difficult than the midterm. A few questions look more like a reading comprehension and they could take up to 2 pages long. The syntax of codes displayed in the questions could be a bit tricky too. Together with the short examination time(40mins), it's easy to rush, lose some detail, and get stuck. I didn't have anytime left to check my work, losing around 15 points to carelessness.

All Labs=100/100 Midterm=92/100 Final=56/100
Overall mark ≈ 80 (Feeling like a B/B+)

Gotta pay attention to the " "s...

Update: Got an A-, lucky enough :)
reviews.comment_workload: There are only 3 Labs to deal with. The rest is for revision, which didn't help me that much in the final, no time to fully process every question... :(

reviews.comment_teaching:
The style of teaching is quite flexible
It's not required to attend class and video recordings from all lectures will be put on the course website for revision so you can compare which lecturer's way of teaching is more suitable for you. Even if you don't tend to attend lessons, you can compare them easily by viewing the ppt about course details. They make a diagram to let students know the characteristics of each lecturer lol

In my opinion, I would recommend everyone to attend Gibson's lesson as I found that he can manage to explain theories short yet clear. He talked in a straightforward manner and you could easily understand what the theory is about. But other teachers are nice too.
reviews.comment_grading:
There's two grading system, the school will help you select the one that is best for you so don't worry too much if you have screwed up one exam.

For the assignments, most people would get high scores as it's not difficult and if you follow the instructions in the video provided, you would not run into a big problem

I think both midterm and final have a certain degree of difficulty for me as a newbie. The programs in the questions are always long and after you have spent time looking over the meaning of the program, you are already exhausted. I would say this course require a lot of logical thinking which you need to try to train yourself to think fast and carefully.
reviews.comment_workload: Nearly no workload at all. Just 3 hand-in labs

reviews.comment_content:
Basic programming content such as if....else, turtle graphics, loops, lists, strings, and tuples. Functions, objects, data types, and file operations were also included.
Did not include some more advanced features such as list comprehension or lambdas.
Since the content is very simple if you have learnt programming before, and still quite easy even if you haven't, this is a rather good course for fulfilling the QR Common Core requirement.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor was a nice person. He was willing to explain concepts to you after the lesson if you do not get it.
To be fair, if you know programming you will skip most lectures out of boredom if anything else.
From the few lectures I've attended, he seems responsible and provides review of concepts learnt in the last lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two grading schemes, and the one which yields the better grade for you will be adopted.
Scheme 1: Midterm 24%, Lab projects 36%, Final exam 40%
Scheme 2: Midterm 0%, Lab projects 42%, Final exam 58%
The midterm and the assignments were not difficult. As a result, most students scored a high grade, and the mean for the assignments were above 95% in all cases.
I have included the topics of the assignments for your reference.
Lab 2: Python Sketchbook (Learning how to use turtle)
Lab 5: Amaziograph (Event handling and lists in Python)
Lab 7: Robot Thinking game (Solving a maze with simple logic)
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload was low.
There is no compulsory attendance, and you can skip lectures at your leisure.
The midterm and the final are both held online, and is "open-internet", i.e. you can search up whatever you need, just do not communicate with others. If you are familiar with the concepts, but forgot the syntax, you can just search it up.
The assignments, on average, take around 1 hour to complete if you have prior programming experience, and is not very difficult even if you don't have it, as the videos included can easily guide you to the solution.
Even if you can't figure it out, you can ask for help from the TAs in the Lab support sessions, and they are more than willing to help you.

reviews.author: easymoneysniper
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Python programming. Everything is very straightforward. The course focuses on fundamental programming concepts like data types, operators, loops, lists, functions and etc. It would be super easy for students with programming to understand the course content, not so difficult for students who don't have programming experience though.

Pay more attention to loops, functions and recursion. Make sure you are very clear about how they work on Python, otherwise you may struggle in some of the labs and the exams. Also pay more attention to Python-specific content like difference between lists and tuples, slicing, dictionaries and turtles. These concepts would be frequently asked in exams.
reviews.comment_teaching: Rossiter's accent is very clear and loud. He sometimes tries to make jokes in class, many of them are interesting but some are not to be honest. He explains most of the concepts very clearly in an interesting way. Try the practises in class and time yourself that would definitely help. 50-min lectures so not really demanding.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two schemes:
1. Mid term 24%,  Final 40%, Labs 36%
2. Mid term 0%, Final 58%, Labs 42%

Everyone got very close scores in labs (I believe around 90% students got full marks in all labs), so you cannot outperform others with labs and don't be excited seeing full marks in labs.

Mid term is fairly easy, score high in mt to guarantee a good paper grade.

Final is of course more difficult. Final this semester was obviously harder than past papers (maybe because it was online exam). Practise how to trace codes to save time and get correct answers in complex questions that mix different concepts together.
reviews.comment_workload: The labs are extremely easy and you don't need to start from scratch. Follow the instructions and it won't take much time. The last two labs might be a bit more challenging but they are good for practising before final. Do it yourself and don't copy from others.

reviews.author: HotDawggy
reviews.comment_content:
This course gives you a basic and introductory look at Python.
Teaches you things like for, while loops, if statements, also Turtle graphics. They also provide a lot of notes, pdf, and sometime even interactive examples. The labs are actually interesting and fun.

If you have any programming experience before this course, even if it's another language, you should be able to get by with a breeze. If you have close to no programming background like me, the content is actually perfect to getting you started on Python.

Whether or not the knowledge taught, especially Turtle graphics, will be useful in the future is honestly debatable, but the course does set a good foundation for programming and it certainly teaches you the logical thinking that programming needs.
reviews.comment_teaching: David was straightforward, clear in his teaching, and sometimes he's quite humorous in his lectures, joking about the content or the TA. It did make the course a lot more enjoyable from what could have been a dry and maybe daunting experience for some.
reviews.comment_grading:
This course in spring 2020-2021 was conducted online and I've already forgotten a lot of the specific details so beware xD.

I believe there were 4 hand-in labs and they were easy to get full marks in, given the amount of instruction and guidelines. The most complex lab I would say is the robot getting out of a maze because it does require a clear, logical mindset because you are dealing will a lot of if-statements, and the code also had to be robust enough to complete most mazes (They test your code by giving the robot random mazes). You also get quite some time to complete these lab. So generally speaking, you should be able to get high marks here.

The mid-term and final on the other hand were quite challenging.
Most questions revolves around code analysis. So basically you have the decide whether that given code will execute without error, what that output might be, etc. We were allowed to copy and run certain codes given, but more challenging questions forbid that. You really have to understand what most line of codes are doing and how they interact with each other, while painting a picture in your head of what the output might be (because it often involves Turtle graphics) to be able to do more challenging questions.

I would say the time given in these exam was quite limited, but it is possible to do all questions with enough practice of coding stuff / doing past papers.

I'm not exactly sure about grading, but it might be heavily skewed by people who already have programming experience.

In the end, I got full marks on all labs, except the robot maze one.
I got only 1 question wrong in mid-term and full marks on final.
So I got A+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was light, the labs were easy to do within a week's time and the labs were already helping you practise for the exams. However I would say your grade is proportional to the amount of time you spend revising / practising / programming (whatever you plan to do).

reviews.author: PTactician
reviews.comment_content:
Basic programming concepts taught using Python language, like input/output, variables, logic operators, if statement and loops, data structures, recursion. If you have taken ICT in secondary school you would've already learnt almost everything.

List of chapters:
Chapter 1: Introduction to Python
Chapter 2: Basic Turtle Graphics Programming
Chapter 3: Comment, Variables and Text
Chapter 4: Variable Types and Operators
Chapter 5: Making Decisions
Chapter 6: Looping
Chapter 7: Finding Repeating Patterns
Chapter 8: Lists, Tuples and Strings
Chapter 9: Functions
Chapter 10: Dictionaries
Chapter 11: More on Turtle
Chapter 12: Turtle Window Event Handling
Chapter 13: File Handling
Chapter 14: Programming with Objects
Chapter 15: Recursion
reviews.comment_teaching: Gibson is a very fun and good lecturer! He is very passionate about the teaching material and his voice is very clear in the lesson. He manages to keep everything fun and engaging for all students. Even if I had learnt most of the concept already in secondary school he still managed to make the lesson interesting for me! Definitely recoomand Gibson as best lecturer!
reviews.comment_grading:
For a student who had already studied ICT in secondary school or someone who are interested in STEM, the assignment and exam question won't be hard for you. There isn't really tricky question meant to trick you into losing marks and all the question makes sense.

Also there are two grading system that are meant to assist students who slip up in midterm. You don't need to worry about getting a very bad grade even if you perform badly at midterm.

Grading scheme 1:
Assignment 1 + 2: 25% + 25%
Midterm: 35%
Online assignment: 15%

Grading scheme 2:
Assignment 1 + 2: 35% + 35%
Midterm: 10%
Online assignment: 20%

The better grading scheme will be automatically used for you to get the best result.

Also there are bonus marks for student who answer question in lecture for a maximum of 3 marks.

I get full marks in both assignment 1 + 2 and the online one. For midterm I get 90/100. I also get 3 extra marks for answering question in lecture. Got an A+ so I would say it is very good grade course.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very light. There are lab session but they don't require attendence and are just glorified copy and paste work where you follow the lab assistance's code.

The two programming assignment are basically the same thing. You can copy almost all of the program code from the lecture note. Since the skeleton code is provided, it is basically fill in the blanks until you get the results.

You have ample time to finish the little things that you need to do and you can easily get full marks just by getting the needed output.

reviews.author: mindy_1207
reviews.comment_content: The course teaches basic knowledge about programming using python 3.8.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is great. The prof taught in a clear and organised way. Besides, he didn't focus too much on the ppt. Instead he used lots of interactive examples which made his lessons fun and really easy to follow.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two grading schemes.
(1) midterm 36%, lab 24%, final 40%
(2) midterm 0%, lab 42%, final 58%
The higher mark of the above calculation will be chosen.

The grading is good. I got 95/100 in midterm (mean=72.4, sd=23.2), full score for lab projects, and 91/100 in the final (mean=60.59, sd=22.28), and my final grade is A+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is relatively light. I knew nothing about programming before taking the course but I had no difficulty following the course. As for the assignments, there are 7 labs (lab 0 to lab 7). Only three of them are hand in labs, so the schedule is pretty flexible. In sum, it won't be hard to get a good grade if you put effort into it.

/
Lab projects: 100/100

Final: 91/100 (mean:60.59  SD:22.28)

reviews.author: KTZ11
reviews.title: A simple and fun programming course with nice grading
reviews.comment_content:
This course teaches basic programming with Python using turtle graphics, which is a Python library that allows you to draw things.
Refers to other reviews for more details of the course.

The content of the course is really simple and straightforward. In most lectures, you only need to learn a few lines of new functions, and you can understand everything easily just by looking at the lecture slides. The only topics that take a little more time to understand are object and recursion.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cecia is a nice lecturer and she teaches every topic in the course with great details and lots of examples, so you can understand everything easily even if you have never tried programming before. She is also willing to answer questions patiently after class. The lectures are a bit boring though because the explanation of things takes too long, especially for topics which are not hard to understand.
reviews.comment_grading:
There is 2 grading scheme for this course:
Midterm 24%, Lab projects 36%, Final exam 40%  or
Midterm 0%, Lab projects 42%, Final exam 58%
The final score would be the highest out of these two calculation methods.

Lab projects: They are just simple programming assignments, and for the 7 lab assignments only 3 of them are hand in labs that count for grades. For each of the lab would provide a step-by-step explanation of nearly everything on the website. Also, you can ask for help from the TAs during tutorial sessions to finish those Labs. This result in a very high average score for the Lab projects:
lab 2 average 97.4
lab 4 98.4
lab 6 90.9
Since the significant portion of labs in grades and the high average of the labs, it is very very important to hand in the labs on time. Missing one of the labs would cause a drop of at least 2 subgrades.
(Btw remember NOT to share your lab codes with your classmate and friends, I heard that some people have their lab score voided with grade penalty in addition because of code plagiarism)

For the exams, they are open book and you can visit the course webpage look for notes, also we are allowed to use Python during the exam. Some of the codes can be copied while you need to manually type the codes for some. Having fast typing speed is definitely an advantage in the exam.

Midterm exam covers the first half of the course and is quite simple, for most questions you can just type the code provided and then obtain the answer. here are the stats:
Maximum: 100
Minimum: 13
Mean: 74.6
SD: 17.9

The final exam covers everything and is significantly more difficult than the midterm, not only due to the increased difficulty of the last few topics, the complexity of the questions also raised a lot. There is a question that requires you to copy a large chunk of code by hand, and there are also questions that provide you more than 20 options and ask you to pick the correct one. This makes the whole exam so demanding. The average of the final is notably lower than the midterm. Stats:
Maximum: 100
Minimum: 0
Mean: 60.59
SD: 22.28

Overall I think the grading of this course is great. I got a full mark for labs, +1sd for midterm, and +1.8sd for final. Finally get an A+
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is near nil. The first two labs only take around an hours to finish and the last one takes 2 hours. Also the exams are open book, which means you only need to briefly know the functions taught, without the need to memorize them.

reviews.comment_grading: I got a B grade in the end. It is a good grade but if you want to have A range,it will be hard for people who have no programming background.

reviews.author: 雪下梅零落
reviews.comment_content: As an introductory course, it will provide adequate and appropriate contents for a new programmer. This course is based on Python, which is thought to be easier than Java or C++. For myself, it is very friendly and easy to learn. All the contents in midterm and final will be covered in lectures(if you don't skip them). By the way, never try to skip any lab works regardless of whether you need to submit it. It's an essential way to finish a program (at least a part of it) by yourself.
reviews.comment_teaching: Gibson LAM is a very perfect instructor in this term. He will demostrate all the commands shown in the ppt(unless it's too simple). I think his English is easy and comfortable to follow and his lectures were not boring at all.  And TA Jimmy Wong was also very kind and answer our questions about almost everything.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab works make up approximately half of the grade. But it is easy to get full marks as you can test your program before submission. (Do test it several times or you may find that you get a 0 grade if the main program crashed)

Midterm won't be calculated in the total grade if you haven't perform well and it will make your grade lower, i.e. your grade will depend on lab and final only in this case.

I have heard that the exams were quite easy in previous semesters, but it's absolutey not that case in 20-21 fall term. In fact, we received an gentle email after final by David Rossiter which said "I don't think you need me to tell you that it's a very hard exam!".  But for me, I admit it's a little hard and time was not enough to answer all the questions, but it never beyond the workload. Well, not so bad.

My grade: A+
Lab: 3 *100/100 for three submissions in total
Midterm: 87.5/100  (Mean: 64)
Final:91.45/100 (Mean: 55)
[for reference only]
reviews.comment_workload:
I think the workload is fine and appropriate. We have discussed basic commands, turtle graphics, data structure, functions and objects, file input and output(a little hard and not covered in the final).

Basically, lab works(once a week) will help you remember most of commands discussed in the lectures. But you will also need to review lecture notes for preparing exams. I hadn't done extra exercises beyond those provided by the course. Maybe I should do so.

reviews.author: Leon2002
reviews.title: An interesting but difficult course for beginners.
reviews.comment_content:
Python programming
Turtle graphics is used as a teaching aid to visualize the code.
Textbook: Interactive Python Programming
for Beginners written by Gibson Lam and David Rossiter
Content:
0. basic python commands: print(), input(),
1. turtle commands: turtle.color , turtle.forward(), turtle.backward(), turtle.goto(,)......
2. list, tuples, dictionaries
3. for loops, while loops, nested loops
4. if statements, operators
5. handling events: drag events, click events
6. file handling
7. slicing
8. Object-oriented programming
9. recursion
10. functions
11. timers
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Lam was a good teacher. Aside from the examples provided in the course notes, Prof. Lam gave extra examples he created by himself to demonstrate the concepts explicitly so that beginners could understand the idea of programming and the functions of the commands.
The TA, Jimmy was helpful. He replied to students' questions in lessons immediately and gave students additional knowledge to satisfy their curiosity.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two ways in calculating the final grade.
1.Midterm 24%, Lab projects 36%, Final exam 40%
2.Midterm 0%, Lab projects 42%, Final exam 58%
The highest mark of these two calculations will be automatically chosen.
The final exam was difficult because the higher-ups of HKUST pressured the course to do harder exam.
I suggest beginners to practice coding daily(try playing with the code examples provided in the course notes  e.g. inserting commands, deleting commands, try doing some python coding online test on various websites etc. ) if they want to attain A range. They should also do more past papers, which will be provided by the professors before the midterm exam and the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
There were 8 labs in total.  Some of them were hand-in labs.
The labs were challenging . As a beginner , the labs required much more efforts and time to finish.

reviews.author: p4pi
reviews.comment_content: Teaches about basic python programming. The content taught before mid-term exam is relatively easy, and it only gets a bit hard when recursion was taught.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor ROSSITER has a great way of teaching how to code with interactive examples instead of only reading out pages from  a powerpoint.
reviews.comment_grading: The two grading systems for your final cga of this course is really generous. One of the grading system weights your mid-term results much higher so that you can still get a good grade even if you did bad in finals.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is really little. You only have to do lab assignments like once every 2-3 weeks.

2 Grading schemes:

If you don't perform well in the midterm, the 0%Midterm grading schemes will help you a lot.

reviews.author: sty
reviews.title: Introductory course for programming with python
reviews.comment_content: Interesting course; taught using interesting examples; taught by interesting prof.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Lam is passionate about what he's teaching, and his classes are easy to follow.

TA Kevin was also ready to help at all times!
reviews.comment_grading:
[INCLUDED]
Labs are very manageable:
they do take some time, but the course-web guides you through it, so you shouldn't have too many problems getting full marks on them. There is a marking scheme for every lab, so make sure you double-check your code every time before you submit it.

The midterm was relatively easy and short:
Make sure that you familiarize yourself with the concepts taught, so you don't run into any time problems during the exam.

The final exam was in comparison much more difficult:
Same as the midterm: MAKE SURE that you familiarize yourself with the concepts taught, so you don't run into any time problems during the exam.
To solve some of the questions of the second part of the exam, some "out of the box"-thinking is required. Prepare for that by writing your own code snippets when revising, fiddling around with the code, and trying to solve similar problems through different approaches.

[NOT INCLUDED]
There is no ATTENDANCE:
For people who have some sort of coding experience, most of the time, it is absolutely sufficient to look over the PPTs only. But let me stress it again, don't underestimate the final exam!
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload consists ONLY of the labs:
There are only 5 labs, which you have to hand in, but also finish the other labs, just to make sure you know what's up ;)

good luck :)
