reviews.author: William Lee
reviews.title: Easy Homework,Hard exam
reviews.comment_content:
Turtle,not python.
• Lectures
– Lectures are used to give solid introductions
to the topics, with lots of demonstrations
– Then the labs are for you to explore the subject in depth
• Labs
– We will have 6-8 lab sessions
– These are a major part of the course! 3 x 12% = 36%/
– 3 lab projects will be handed in for marking 3 x 14% = 42%
• Midterm exam 24%/ 0%
– An open book/open notes midterm exam
– More details will be released later in the course
• Final exam 40%/ 58%
– This will be another open book/notes exam
reviews.comment_teaching: I recommend you to save more time and then learn by yourself.
reviews.comment_grading:
You should be careful and try your best to get full marks of your LAB and try to train your speed of reading codes or you won't be successful in the exam(or even very bad grade).It may be easy to get B grade but it depends on how you perform in your exam and it depends on your speed of reading codes,your logics and if you be careful enough.

At the End of Semester
• The first way we assess you is this (more midterm %):
Midterm 24%, Lab projects 36%, Final exam 40%
• The second way we assess you is this (less midterm %):
Midterm 0%, Lab projects 42%, Final exam 58%
• We will automatically choose the highest mark of these
two calculations
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not high.But it depends on how much time you spend on your LAB and how much time you spend trying different examples he gives to you.

reviews.author: williamlus
reviews.comment_content: The teaching content is rather easy, oop is just simply mentioned but not examined (e.g. class...). And some advanced topics are also not included(e.g. lambda function).
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is very interesting. Gibson would explain every concept clearly. It is very friendly to beginners.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is good. Making 1~2 mistakes is acceptable to get A+. (>_<)
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is acceptable. The Tetris Block is the last homework and it requires time to design and debug. But overall, the workload is relatively light. More individual practice and study are recommended if you want to master Python and get good grade.

reviews.author: Edyis
reviews.comment_content:
I had taken DSE ICT before, so I understood the logic of programming pretty easily. This course taught you the basics of Python, which is a beginner-friendly programming language. The hardest part for me to understand would be the dictionary and recursion part, but this would be in the last part of the course.

I did go through all the given past papers. But since the exam changed to be online, it was much different and in some way more difficult as well. Although you are allowed to use Python, you won't have enough time to think.
reviews.comment_teaching: Gibson is a funny and friendly professor. He would stay behind the lectures to answer questions. TA Jimmy is nice too, he would answer questions clearly during the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading mainly consists of the midterm, labs, and final exam. They have 2 calculating methods and they would choose the best marks out of the 2 so you won't need to worry about that. The labs are easy to get full marks by following every instruction. I did ok for the midterm, but I didn't do very well for the canvas exam. But, I think the grade is lenient. I only got 1 question correct for part A of the final, which is 40% of the exam. I still got B+.
reviews.comment_workload: It is light. You have labs every week, but only 3 of them are graded. All you have to do is to watch videos and follow what Jimmy said. Every code is given to you except for the last 2 labs.

reviews.author: sonia.lee
reviews.comment_content: its all about python 3, i did not know about this but took the course. content itself was pretty fun
reviews.comment_teaching: all i can say is he is such a great teacher, all of the lectures he gave were all clear but exams are just hard as hell
reviews.comment_grading: actually i expected d for my grade but i got b+ so just don't give up with the exams eventho you feel like u don't understand a single shit
reviews.comment_workload: there were many different labs and practice questions for students and previous midterms/finals were give. not all of them were graded, only 3 labs are important throughout the course.

reviews.author: kurwa
reviews.comment_content:
Some fundamental knowledge in programming, such as conditions, loops, data types (strings, tuples, integers, etc.), data structures (arrays, tuples, dictionaries), classes, recursion, through the means of Python

Oh, by the way, you have to draw a lot, I mean a lot, with Python turtle. Because, you know, unique feature of Python.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I attempted all of the Dimitrios' lectures because I have nothing better to do.

All of his lectures were conducted through English. As English isn't his first language, he spoke with an accent, but this did not affect clarity at all (at least to me).

He explained every topic clearly with the aid of course materials from the course website and some of the codes written by himself for the course. Besides, he often engage students by asking questions, and answered those asked by them.

And speaking of TA, my boy Jimmy is a big cool guy, very helpful in every scenario. He was present in every lecture. He answered most questions put forth by students (during and after class), and taught us some out-syllabus knowledge occasionally
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two grading schemes in this semester:
1. Labs 36%, Midterm 24%, Final 40%
2. Labs 42%, Midterm 0%, Final 58%
They will pick the scheme with the highest over score

Probably graded by curve. Getting about 90% in this semester would grant you an A grade

For the midterm exam of this semester, here are the statistics.

Average: 64.4%
Standard deviation: 21.5%
Maximum: 100%
Minimum (excluding zeros): 2.5%

For the final exam of this semester, 1 of the weakest questions in each part (part A and B) was removed, and the marks of 1 question was granted to every student unconditionally. Here are the statistics.

    Average ~55.9%
    Standard deviation ~20.5%
    Maximum 100.0%
    Minimum ~8.6%

It was, arguably, the hardest exam in recent years in COMP1021. But don't worry, the pressure will only push the difficulty to a higher level.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light

There are a total of 7 lab assignments, only 3 are required to hand in.

They are rather easy, and Jimmy would guide you step by step for every hand-in lab assignment.

reviews.author: wete
reviews.title: Best Course Ever
reviews.comment_content:
This course will teach you everything about python from the very beginning until basic OOP.
In this course you will study:
1. Conditions
2. Loops
3. Turtle module
4. List, Tuple, Dictionary
5. Recursion
5. Basic OOP (class, etc.)

The contents are easy to follow.. so you don't have to worry about it that much.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. David Rossiter is the best professor in this course, no cap, as he explains things very thoroughly and very detail.
reviews.comment_grading: This course grading system is bell  curve. The grading are from lab assignments, mid exam, and final exam. If you get bad score in the mid exam but excellent score in the final exam, the mid exam score will be ignored. If you want to excel this course, it's better for you to take basic python lesson beforehand. You can take either courseacademy (pc) or SoloLearn (mobile).
reviews.comment_workload: This course provides a lot of exercises and previous exams for us to practice. There are only 3 compulsory lab assignments and every one of it use turtle modules. We are given 1-2 weeks to finish every assignments and the professors and TAs are willing to answer every question in the canvas QnA section... so you don't have to worry.

reviews.author: Haven
reviews.title: Good at all
reviews.comment_content: It’s mainly about basic python coding and python turtle coding . You will have chance to try out how to use python logic to do coding and make a very basic form of games or some useful tools. It’s rather easy and the lesson were teaching a rather little content each time . Although sometimes there will be three notes together once but mostly times will be only 2 or even one note. And each note only explain one theory . So it will be easy to handle. However there will be some non hand-in labs. Better done it also because these labs contain contents not included in the lessons. Although those knowledge are very little(just a few codes) but still better do it also because it will be included inside the final and midterms
reviews.comment_teaching: Rossiter David was my instructor this year. But actually the course does not take any attendance and encouraging you to attend any sessions you want to try out which instructor you like most. Rossiter teach us in a active way which gives his own explanations then how the notes say and mostly using the python IdLE to explain and try out the theories . He’s not teaching very fast . There will be having enough time to drop notes. You can study the notes before the lesson(actually it’s easy to understand and easy to be read) which can let you understand the course more easily.
reviews.comment_grading: The grades are based on two calculating method , one is only include final and labs . Another one is containing midterm also. It will be auto selecting the most highest mark among both of the calculating method so even if you failed the midterm you just need to do well in final will be fine
reviews.comment_workload: 3 hand in labs in medium size, actually there are step to step guide and also templates for the start of the lab. So many people getting full mark for all labs. If it’s really hard to understand the guides. There are still  TA session out of class so you can ask questions . It will be useful if you really have problem in it

reviews.author: mei you qian
reviews.title: Not bad for programming beginners but issa stress
reviews.comment_content: Basic python programming, mostly on syntax, lists, objects, functions, turtle turtle and turtle. All of the labs were on turtle.
reviews.comment_teaching:
They tried to make it generally interesting and understandable. 2 50mins lectures every week with optional labs for Lab Assignments.
Gibson was a great teacher with a cheerful tone and atmosphere. No attendance required but I mostly attended his lectures as his explanation was very helpful (since I know nothing about programming).
TA Jimmy was also very helpful, answering questions in class as well as in the Lab sessions.
reviews.comment_grading:
ALL EXAMS ARE DAMN HARD (especially the final exam)

- 3 labs (36%)
- midtem (24%)
- final (40%)

I got
- 94, 100, 100 for labs (first lab slightly below the mean)
- 84/100 for midterm (nearly 1sd above, mean=63)
- 65/100 for final (0.5sd above, mean =44 ish)

Ended up with a B+. Not bad at all for UST!

Competition was not so fierce anymore as online exams are considerably harder, lowering the mean.
reviews.comment_workload:
If you don't have programming background, lab & revision are stress

For labs, you do have to put some time crying over errors but you get there eventually (sometimes you don't even know how you solved it)

Midterm is doable; not much to revise since you're only halfway through. But midterm was not easy at all. It's open notes and you can use python but if you didn't understand, it's no good.

Final is the real trap card activated. It's cumulative so you gotta revise everything which is a lot. It tests your programming ability and you can't just put codes and run the program. For some questions you gotta download videos or texts which is chaotic.

reviews.comment_teaching: The prof speaks in a playful tone during the lectures, so I guess it's nice to have his lectures. I personally didn't attend any of the lectures so I couldn't say much. TAs are helpful, for those of you who need help, don't hesitate to email them.
reviews.comment_grading:
This is an online semester, two grading systems are applied.
• Midterm 24%, Lab projects 36%, Final exam 40%
• Midterm 0%, Lab projects 42%, Final exam 58%
They will automatically pick the formula in which you score higher.

The midterm and final were conducted through Canvas, and for some reason, the midterm was delayed for half an hour. Someone accidentally started doing the quiz during that time, some were complaining that they couldn't access the quiz even it was near starting time, so the situation was quite chaotic.

Because they do not want students to cheat, the exams were made really hard intentionally. It is not comparable with those you see in past papers.
Because of that, the general performance was not good, therefore they made some marks adjustments in the final. They removed the weakest question for every student in both parts A and B. I wouldn't say it's fair for those who got it right.

statistics:
Midterm-----
Average 64.4%
Standard deviation 21.5%
Maximum  100%
Minimum (excluding zeros) 2.5%

final-----
Average ~55.9%
Standard deviation ~20.5%
Maximum 100.0%
Minimum ~8.6%

reviews.author: Kemist
reviews.comment_content:
An introduction of python, course content is very easy but if you're a beginner of programming, effort is needed for getting an A range as there are many dailos in this course. The course has its own website and the resources on it are very useful for preparing your exams.

Chapter 1 Introduction to Python
Chapter 2 Basic Turtle Graphics Programming
Chapter 3 Comments, Variables and Text
Chapter 4 Variable Types and Operators
Chapter 5 Making Decisions
Chapter 6 Looping
Chapter 7 Finding Repeating Patterns
Chapter 8 Lists, Tuples and Strings
Chapter 9 Functions
Chapter 11 More on Turtle
Chapter 12 Turtle Window Event Handling
Chapter 13 File Handling
Chapter 14 Programming with Objects
Chapter 15 Recursion
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr Chan is probably a local lecturer and her English is quite good, at least better than many profs from other courses. TA Peter is willing to answer all the questions very seriously. Examples will be demonstrated in the lectures, which makes the concepts easier to understand, so attendance is encouraged. However, if you're talented or have programming experience, there's not big difference in reading lecture notes by yourself and attending lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is very good. There are two grading methods:
1. 24% Midterm, 36% Labs, 40% Finals
2. 0% Midterm, 42% Labs, 58% Finals
Honestly mt is way easier than final so study hard for the 24%. But for me, I didn't do well in mt and studied hard for final so my score is a little bit weird
[Mean and Stdev](Copied from another review lol)
Lab 1: Mean 97.2% Stdev 9.3% Max 100% Min 20%
Lab 2: Mean 98.7% Stdev 11.7% Max 100% Min 5%
Lab 3: Mean 95.4% Stdev 11.4% Max 100% Min 20%

Midterm: Mean 64.4% Stdev 21.5% Max 100% Min 2.5%
Finals: Mean 55.9% Stdev 20.5% Max 100% Min 8.6%
Background of me: dropped ict in f4 and knew nothing about programming.
I got 63(-0.1sd) in mt and 69(+0.65sd) in final, two labs full score and fked up the final one, only 70/100. Got a B+ finally. If I can do this everyone can get an a by studying hard. Don't give up easily.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only three hand-in labs so the workload is very light. However, If you don't study a lot before exams you'll fk them up so you still need to put some effort into it.
Ask questions on canvas if you don't know how to do.

reviews.author: Unk
reviews.comment_content: A basic introduction to Python language. Lot of it involves around turtle graphics. The course is easy, even if you don't have a coding background. The lecture notes are very descriptive and helpful. Lecture notes include a lot of examples. They have a book as well for the course, but the lecture notes are more than enough.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Alex Lam is really passionate about teaching. He said he was the happiest when teaching us lol.. even though no one is turning on the camera and no one speaks. The TA Jimmy is really good too. He answered all the questions in chat, with very detailed and more advanced explanation than provided in slides. Course web is very helpful, all slides and notes are there.. Past papers are also provided for practice.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two grading methods:
(They will calculate the highest mark for you)
1.midterm 24%, lab 36%, final 40%
2. midterm 0%, lab 42%, final 58%

Some statistics for the Midterm exam and Final exam:

Midterm:
Average: 64.4%
Standard Deviation: 21.5%
Maximum: 100%
Minimum (excluding zeros): 2.5%

Final:
Average: 55.9%
Standard Deviation: 20.5%
Maximum: 100.0%
Minimum: 8.6%

For my grade:
Labs: 100%
Midterm: 92....%
Final: 90%
Letter Grade: A+

The grading is really generous, questions worth so much and you need to be really careful doing it. 1 question can be around 8 points out of 100. Since it's online, can use IDLE in exams, thus the questions are made much harder. The only one that boosts my CGA this first semester :'(
reviews.comment_workload: Very very light. No homework, and no need to practice coding that much, just need to understand the basics. Graded labs are easy to follow because videos of it is provided and you only need to type whatever Jimmy is typing, and you can get easy 100 every lab.

reviews.author: ht226
reviews.title: Online finals are rough
reviews.comment_content:
You're introduced to Python by the turtle module. Everything before midterm is fairly easy. Things involved include (but not limited to):
If/Elif/Else
For/While loops
Strings/Lists
random module

Post-midterm content gets difficult really quickly. I suggest spending more time on recursion because it's kind of a difficult concept to wrap your head around. You'll definitely want to study hard if you want good grades.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cecia Chan is kind of like your average teacher. Nothing special, but she does try to make the lesson sound more interesting, and she goes through examples clearly.
Gibson Lam is lively and provides very interesting examples during lectures. You'll probably be entertained by his lectures. I've only watched two videos of his lectures and found them very useful.

Lessons involve quite a bit of demonstrations, so it's not overrun by powerpoint-reading like some other courses. Their English is fluent and can be understood easily. Overall, my experience with this course's lectures are positive and I think they're of a high quality.
reviews.comment_grading:
They have two grading methods (best one will be chosen):
Labs 36%, Midterm 24%, Final 40% or
Labs 42%, Midterm 0%, Final 58%

Scoring full on labs aren't really difficult, just make sure you be very careful and test more possible cases. Lab averages are really high though because a lot of people score full.

The midterm exam wasn't difficult in my opinion, and this seems to match what other people think. It might not be as easy if you don't have any programming experience, but I don't think it's very harsh on beginners.

The final exam was hellish. Rossiter did say that they were pressured to do harder final exams (understandable, since we have access to Python, which makes everything easier), so past papers didn't really reflect the difficulty of the exam. There was an error with one of the questions and they gave us marks for that, which helped a bit.

Here's a bit of statistics from this semester's exams:
Midterm: Avg 64.4%, SD 21.5%
Final: Avg 55.9%, SD 20.5%
*weakest question in each part of midterm/final were removed iirc

Grades for reference:
Lab 100%
Midterm ~90%
Final ~60%
Letter Grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Personally I found the workload acceptable.
The lectures and (online) labs aren't compulsory and you can go to whichever session you please, so it makes managing your schedule easier.
I managed to finish all 3 hand-in lab projects and scored full without attending a lab session. It takes quite a bit of time, but the instructions given on the website are more than enough for you to complete it.
There are other labs and you're encouraged to go through them yourself, but you could skip them if you really don't have time. the only annoying part about labs is that **the hand-in date depends on your lab day while the materials are released on the same day for everyone. That means people who have assigned lab sessions on Friday essentially have a few more days to work on their programs than those assigned to Monday sessions. Definitely start early because:
1) It's not something you want to deadline-rush
2) You should try to secure 100% in all labs because most people do

No attendance is required.
HOW~WE~VER (Rossiter's tone lol),
I strongly recommend you to attend Rossiter's or Gibson's Lectures. (See "Teaching")
----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----

reviews.comment_teaching:
Very good in terms of the course material and online teaching.

Most of the lecture notes are clean and concise.
Some of the tricks are listed there for exams, so take a look at them before doing past papers.

Professor Rossiter makes every lecture interesting. Perfect teaching style as an introductory course.

So do not miss any Rossiter's Lecture. You will regret not attending such a great lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Excellent Grading

For the labs, almost everyone score full marks.
(Remember to take a look at the marking scheme to ensure you did everything right.)

For exams, both midterm and final are divided into Part A and Part B. Personally speaking, Part B is much harder than Part A.

Be careful with time management since I got stuck on a question in Final part B and did not have time to complete the rest of them.
reviews.comment_workload:

Again, remember to look at the marking scheme to ensure you did everything right since the mean exceeds 95/100.

reviews.author: BruhMoment
reviews.title: Basic Programming Course
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Python stuff.

If loop/For loop/ While loop etc
They mainly use Python Turtle Module to teach such logic

After midterm, difficulties start to increase. They teach event handler/OOP/Recursion

You can learn a lot from this course
reviews.comment_teaching:
I only attend 6 lectures coz I think read ppt is OK for me.
But he teaches quite well. His speaking tone is fine in 50 minutes lecture. TA is helpful too.

All course material will upload to the course web. So you basically do not need to attend lectures if you can handle them by yourselves.

You don't need a coursebook. Lecture notes are enough.
reviews.comment_grading:
This course uses 2 grading scheme.

1.Lab 36% Midterm 24% Final 40%
2. Lab 42% Midterm 0% Final 58%
They will calculate the higher score and grade your course.

For Lab session, you can basically get a full mark. (Mean>90%)

The midterm is okay if you revise the material. It consists of 2 parts. You can use Python and copy the code in Part A. But you cannot copy the code in Part B. You can still run Python in Part B. Because of technical issues, one of your weakest questions is dropped out in Part A.

BUT FINAL IS HELL. Questions are challenging in order to distinguish the students' level. But they drop out one of your weakest questions for both Part A and Part B.

I got full mark in Lab and Final, so A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
As a 3 credit course, the workload is quite light. All you need to do is understanding lecture notes. Do 1 lab every week. Then revise for final and midterm.

But be careful in midterm and final, students are so competitive. If you are very careless, you may wrong with 1 or 2 questions. Then you may lose 1 subgrade. Good luck.

上面提到有3份assignment , 全部都係寫program, 但係唔使驚, 大部份都有哂guideline 同 教學片教你點做, 甚至你真係唔識做嘅話, 可以去attend lab session, 我個人就未去過lab session, 因為真係好易做
一份assignment 大概做6個鐘左右, 聽落好多但係你一個sem 淨係做3次 所以都好少野做
Mid-term 好易 有讀就知
final 難到癲 不過有温應該都ok

reviews.author: WAKKA
reviews.title: Need to study more and really need to understand how the coding works
reviews.comment_content: 內容清晰簡單，而且prod rossiter真係會好解釋比你聽點做，但係好考你係咪真係理解啲coding係點運用，final嚟講online final可以話係特別難，有時做完pp都冇咩用，同埋要仔細研究lec notes example，同試吓trial and error，落唔同coding睇點樣影響個coding運作，我個人就冇porgram底(因此考得特別差)，所以真係要多啲時間去理解，但係得3個月比你去學，建議搵多啲同學同入大grp交流吓，避免爛grade，同啲Lab 一出即做，你唔會估到佢哋會有幾難同要幾多時間理解。

reviews.author: Siddarth
reviews.comment_content: It is a bit advance if you are brand new to coding, and mainly revolves around turtle graphics which are in my opinion interesting but have no direct real life application. However, for someone like me who has some java experience I think the content is relatively straight forward.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is quite slow in my perspective. However, my view is slightly biased based on having coding experience, and the quality of teaching is still quite high.
reviews.comment_grading: In my semester there were two grading scheme. The first system involved Lab, Mid-term, Final. The second system was Lab, and Final only (which was the system that was used for me). The system that gives you the highest grade.
reviews.comment_workload: If you don't find the lab tasks too challenging, then the workload should seem very light for you. However, if you are new to coding the workload can feel very high.

reviews.author: skrskrskr
reviews.title: Good course if you only want to touch the surface of the coding world
reviews.comment_content: Python language, mainly focus on turtle. Not that useful for those who are really into coding aspect, but it would help you equip a very basic concept of programming, just not much for the application side. For/While loop is one of the most important elements learnt from the course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good delivering skills, good english. Alex is willing to answer questions and even overruns the lectures sometimes. Some student would find it's a bit fast after midterm, but probably because of the difficulty increases.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading to me is not good, I used the scheme which only counts the final (final 58% and lab 42%). I score full mark in lab and 87.14% in final, overall grade is around 92.5%. But guess what, I just got an A, I would accept if the mean is like 70 or 80, but the mean in final was 55.9, SD around 20, scoring 1.5SD above. Therefore, getting an A+ in HKUST is not really an easy thing to achieve, good luck to you who will register this course.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is fine, just three labs overall. The last lab about robot is a bit challenging, make sure to ask more, watch videos and think more. Some questions in the lab appear in the final. If you pay attention to the lesson, it would take you less time to revise for the finals, even without any background knowledge. But if you did not attend lectures, it would be tough because the final exam is really challenging, you cannot score high even you revise well by doing past papers.

reviews.author: yeet420
reviews.comment_content:
I had very minimal programming experience before this course and found it quite easy to understand.

- Loops
- Turtle Graphics
- Lists, tuples, strings
- Slicing
- Functions
- Operators
- Understanding colour
- Using timers
- File handling
- Dictionaries
- Recursion
reviews.comment_teaching: Great professor, makes content easy to understand through lecture notes and example programmes. Very upbeat and makes it easy to pay attention in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
2 methods are used to calculate your grade. You're automatically given the higher mark between the 2

- Method 1: 24% midterm / 36% hand in labs / 40% final
- Method 2: 0% midterm / 42% hand in labs / 40% final

Midterm and final were open book, open internet online exams. Final is very difficult mostly due to a fairly short amount of time to answer all questionsand needs a very thorough understanding of the course concepts.

Remember to do all your labs - most people get 100 so if you miss one you'll fall way behind when it comes to the final grade.

I got:
Miderm 75 (Mean 66, SD 21.5)
Final 83 (Mean 55.9, SD 20.5)
Labs 100 (Mean 96.9, SD around 10)

Overall grade: 90% with method 2, final grade A so seems pretty fair.
reviews.comment_workload:
8 lab assignments throughout the semester - roughly once a week excluding the first 2 weeks, the week of the midterm and the final week of the semester.

3 hand in labs - mandatory and make up part of your final grade

5 to help explore the contents of the course which they don't check but I'd recommend you do them do them to help your understanding of the course.

2x Lectures and 1x lab in a week but it's not necessary to attend the lab, the TAs will be online if you have and questions about the course

Make sure to do all the labs and try to get 100% on all as most people do. Not scoring highly on you labs will put you at a serious disadvantage

reviews.author: ECEkiu
reviews.title: 唔算好grade,但唔會爛grade
reviews.comment_content:
主力教python
if同loop各樣都最基本既都會教
今年有七份lab,只有三份要交
每份有起碼一半有得抄,其餘都唔難
除左最後一份要諗多少少

頭兩份已經唔記得要做咩,太易
最後一份係機械人行迷宮,基本上係跟住條片再寫返if case就搞掂,唔係考program
係考你諗咩

Mid-term正常難度
Final 地獄級
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gibson 世界第一,係今個sem咁多個入面教得最好

雖然唔關事,但如果你要讀phys1112,千萬不要reg Wong Kam Sing堂,世界級教授
教左同無教係無分別
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid term踩mean
功課滿分
Final 低一個SD
最後拎B-
有朋友mid term低2個SD
功課滿分
Final 低一個SD
最後拎C+

拎靚grade唔易,但唔會爛得太勁
可以放心一戰
reviews.comment_workload:
得七份lab,3個要交,聽聞之前係2份
唔洗交既lab"自律"去做就得,佢地唔會理你做唔做,但有Q&A環節,你可以入去問下TA點做

基本上2~3week 先要做一份功課,workload都唔會大得去邊,可以放心

reviews.author: AlChae
reviews.comment_content: Very useful contents and easy for beginners to start with cs. Python is very easy to understand and use compared to that of Java or C++ languages.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Rossiter is  just awseome! He gives out many examples and never makes us bored. Each lectures were very useful.
reviews.comment_grading:
Labs were extremly easy but a tiny single mistake might bring you down to below average so you have to be extra careful. Midterm exam was easy as well but final was a bit tough (you can tell with the standard deviation).

Midterm 24%, Lab projects 36%, Final exam 40%
OR
Midterm 0%, Lab projects 42%, Final exam 58%

Lab 2:
Average: 97.2
Standard deviation: 9.3

Lab 5:
Average: 98.1
Standard deviation: 11.7
Minimum: 5
Maximum: 100  

Lab 7:
Average: 95.4
Standard deviation: 11.4
Minimum: 20
Maximum: 100

Midterm exam:
Average: 64.4%
Standard deviation: 21.5%
Maximum: 100%
Minimum: 2.5%

Final exam:
Average: 55.9%
Standard deviation: 20.5%
Maximum: 100.0%
Minimum: 8.6%
reviews.comment_workload: Not much things to do. Only 3 labs which takes around 2 to 3 hours each. If you watch all the videos and tutorials it will be very easy to follow. Also many of the codes are given so the actual amount of workload is less than it looks.

reviews.author: Asagami Fujino
reviews.title: Great
reviews.comment_content:
Contents are quite easy, you can actually learn all of them within 3 days! (And you can choose any lecture you want)
It's just about basic programming knowledge and Python syntax. If you're familiar with Python, you can just skip all the classes (however, you may miss the chance to talk with the TA in class)
However, from another point of view, this course teaches too little. It also introduced some bad programming habits (like the use of `global`)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gibson's class is quite interesting (though most of the time I'm talking with the TA in chat lol)
TA Jimmy is also a very nice person and he's really helpful and interesting.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading policies, if you are confident in your final, you can skip the midterm.

Hand-in labs (ie assignments) are not difficult, so it's easy to get 100%
Mid-term is somewhat difficult, but it's possible to get 100%.
Final is hell! And the sem's final is the most difficult one (as the profs say so)! However, since the instructors are god, they just give us the full credit for a problem for free (cuz the problem is not showing properly lol). They also removed 1 weakest problem from each part (there're 2 parts in the final, same as mt), meaning that if you got one question wrong in each part, you can still get 100%(which is my case)
Got A+ in the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
Near 0.
Only 3 hand-in labs, each takes about 2 hours.

reviews.author: Error404
reviews.title: interesting programming introduction course
reviews.comment_content:
結論 : 大部分都係ict compulsory 嘢, 小部分Ict elective D 嘅嘢

# Sorry for my poor English !
Emphasize a lot on turtle graphic
basic programming skills
If you learn DSE ICT, this would be easy, most of the content are taught in ICT compulsory part, some are taught in elective D.
The most difficult part is recursion and the concept of object

Purchasing textbook does not help a lot as notes will be provided and those notes are clear. Professor did not use textbook also.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Interesting teaching
often make jokes during lessons

His explanation skills is great that should be able to be understood by everyone
reviews.comment_grading:
結論：小心careless

Hope these facts will help you
not sure about final grading but should be great.
btw final is much more difficult than mid term

have two ways of calculation for marks:
method one : Lab 36%  Mid term 24%  Final 40%
method two : Lab 42% Mid term 0% Final 58%

mean of Lab:

Mean of Lab 5: 98.1%
Mean of Lab 7 : 95.4%

Mid term:

My info in case you want to know :
DSE ICT 5* (elective D)
All lab, final : 100%
Mid term : 88.92%
Final grade: A+

be ware of careless mistakes !!!
reviews.comment_workload:
seven labs in total
three hand in lab (Turtle sketchbook, Amaziograph, robot game)
lab can be done for 1-3 hours

Super low when comparing phys1112 :(

reviews.author: JangJackzel
reviews.title: Good Course If You Want CSE Major
reviews.comment_content:
If you are a complete beginner and want good grade, take this course since most students taking this course are beginners unlike COMP1022P where there are full of experts. But, prior knowledge will help so find tutorials on YouTube; it's full of them.

Chapter 1 Introduction to Python
Chapter 2 Basic Turtle Graphics Programming
Chapter 3 Comments, Variables and Text
Chapter 4 Variable Types and Operators
Chapter 5 Making Decisions
Chapter 6 Looping
Chapter 7 Finding Repeating Patterns
Chapter 8 Lists, Tuples and Strings
Chapter 9 Functions
Chapter 11 More on Turtle
Chapter 12 Turtle Window Event Handling
Chapter 13 File Handling
Chapter 14 Programming with Objects
Chapter 15 Recursion
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Rossiter is simply osm.

He prepares his own materials for every lecture and he teaches flawlessly and engagingly. Really enjoyed taking his lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two ways for grading:
1. 24% Midterm, 36% Labs, 40% Finals
2. 0% Midterm, 42% Labs, 58% Finals

They will automatically take the higher one between the two.

Get that 24% for the midterm. Try as hard as you can. Just think that the second scheme doesn't exist.

It's not that difficult to get full marks in labs.

Professors try their best to give good grades to students. For midterm, they removed one weakest question of every student in Part A and for final, they removed the weakest question of every student in both Part A and B.

[Mean and Stdev]
Lab 1: Mean 97.2% Stdev 9.3% Max 100% Min 20%
Lab 2: Mean 98.7% Stdev 11.7% Max 100% Min 5%
Lab 3: Mean 95.4% Stdev 11.4% Max 100% Min 20%

Midterm: Mean 64.4% Stdev 21.5% Max 100% Min 2.5%
Finals: Mean 55.9% Stdev 20.5% Max 100% Min 8.6%

Got full marks for everything, so A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload.

There are 7 labs in total and only 3 are hand-in labs. It took around 3-4 hours or less each for all 7 labs. I have a little programming background (learned C, C++ and Java before Uni) so it might take a few more hours if you are a complete beginner. But all instructions are given for each lab. So if you just carefully follow the instructions, it is quite straightforward.

Midterm is much much much much much easier than finals so do make sure that you take the midterm seriously. It will help a lot for your grades.

Some questions in final demand you to make a program to get to the answer. Even if they don't, knowing how to make a simple program to find the answer helps a lot. So try to get familiar with programming in Python so that you know what and how to code in different occasions.

It's about understanding than memorizing. All course materials and even the internet are accessible during both final and midterm but they are not so useful due to limited time, so try to memorize all functions and grammar.

reviews.author: Rolaaa
reviews.comment_content:
Basic instruction to python.I think the aim is to generally show you what programming is in some funny tasks(in a very simple and easy level.I think that's suitable as ccc but somehow too simple for ppl going to major in cs/ce)and arouse your interest in it.

ps:If you have programming experience no matter in which language,personally I suggest you take 2011/2012H directly.I'm a bit regret :(

pps:If you choose to take the course,I suggests that you try to figure out the universal theory of how programs work and how to communicate with computer through your whole study,so that you can make full use of the course ;)
reviews.comment_teaching:
David is sooooooo humorous(perhaps this makes the course seems even esier and less regrete in taking it).The teaching is clear and accurate.Worth mentioning,the TAs are sooo kind,hard-working and skilled.The course wbesite and the Q&A board are developed quite well,providing self-study ppl like me good study experiences.

In a word,the whole teaching team and teaching system are efficient,friendly and excellent.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two ways,in which the midterm is counted or not besides lab and final.

I think you can get almost full mark in each task as long as you take them seriously and strictly conformity with the requirements and instructions.(even though you do not take all the lectures)

But as most of the task are simple,you also need to be careful with the risks that making a few tiny mistakes could lead to your below the average.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite light.The total time you need to spend maybe at most a lab and two lectures a week since in the lab you can go over(or self study lol)or get trained of all what you've studied in lecture.(If you are not interested in exploring more things about python by yourself with the help of TAs ;)

reviews.author: Sankalp
reviews.comment_content:
Basic introduction to programming with python, included:
Basic python syntax
Input and output
if/elif statements
loops: for, while
nested loops  
lists/arrays
recursion
Do not need any prior experience with python.
The assignments were coding assignments with the skeleton code give. For me, the assignments were about building a recursion based art gallery that prints out patterns and making a Tetris game.
The labs were very simple, with the TA assisting you in making sure the lab task was finished before you leave the lab.
The attendance for this course is not recorded, hence is not mandatory (but if you are a beginner I would heavily advice to attend every lecture as it makes life much easier when revising for exam later into the semester).
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching was not bad, however it could get a bit dull at times.
If you actively participate in class, you will find his teaching to be better. Furthermore, it is also best if you ask and try to remedy any inquiries or confusions you may have with the professor actively.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading was fine but mean of the course was quite high due to the course material being relatively easy for students with experience in programming. Hence actual beginners might have to put in extra effort to stay at level with the mean grade of the course.
There is a limit to how many students can be within the A/A+ range, and this limit is not that large, making it even more competitive.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is adequate for a 3 credit beginner level course. The course included:
- Final exam
- Midterm exam
- Weekly Labs (very easy)
- Programming assignments

reviews.author: TR
reviews.title: Appropriate introductory course to Python.
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1 Introduction to Python
Chapter 2 Basic Turtle Graphics Programming
Chapter 3 Comments, Variables and Text
Chapter 4 Variable Types and Operators
Chapter 5 Making Decisions
Chapter 6 Looping
Chapter 7 Finding Repeating Patterns
Chapter 8 Lists, Tuples and Strings
Chapter 9 Functions
Chapter 11 More on Turtle
Chapter 12 Turtle Window Event Handling
Chapter 13 File Handling
Chapter 14 Programming with Objects
Chapter 15 Recursion
reviews.comment_teaching: Rossiter is a good lecturer. He explains things in depth and gives a lot of examples. He's also quite light hearted which makes the lectures fun and interesting.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two ways of assessing students and they'll take the higher of the two -
1. 24% Midterm, 36% Labs, 40% Finals
2. 0% Midterm, 42% Labs, 58% Finals

Midterm
Average - 64.4%
Standard deviation - 21.5%
Maximum - 100%
Minimum (excluding zeros) - 2.5%

Final
Average - 55.9%
Standard deviation - 20.5%
Maximum - 100.0%
Minimum - 8.6%

Me:
Midterm - 91.67%
Final - 79.14%
Coursework - 100%
Final grade: A

The midterm was definitely easier than the final. The final had a lot of difficult questions (more difficult than the practice questions they gave us) and there wasn't much time to complete them. However, if you work hard on the midterm and the labs, they may be able to pull your grade up.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload it quite light. We have 6-8 labs which were mostly straightforward. The TAs gave most of the code for the labs besides the last one. Out of those 6-8 labs only 3 are to be handed in for marking.

reviews.author: 好難諗個名
reviews.title: Nice prof, not difficult content
reviews.comment_content:
Interesting and not very difficult for people who have not learned computer before.
Two assignments are not very easy. But Gibson will explain the key points on lectures and you can ask him or TAs.
reviews.comment_teaching: Gibson is a nice professor, he explained the content interesting and I can easily follow his path.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are many people who had learned python before so it was difficult to get A range if you did not have any computer base.
I got B+ finally.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not very heavy workload
Only 2 assignments and 2 exams.
But the tutorial is needed unless you have enough knowledge on computer.

reviews.author: E723
reviews.title: Not that easy
reviews.comment_content: All  about Python which actually is an interesting thing. Basic programming language and animation are taught in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gibson is really an excellent lecturer and he loves making jokes during the lecture. His lively teaching will never bore you at all and noobs can understand the lecture easily. His accent is definitely clear so no matter locals or international students can understand the content.
However, in a restricted course time, it is really hard to fully familiar with all those content and use them correctly. For example,my assignments require me to use python turtle and loops to make pictures and a functional tetris game. Seriously, you must attend all lab or else you may not be able to do your assignments alone as it is really difficult for beginners like me.
reviews.comment_grading: I studied this course during fall sem, due to some reasons the final exam was cancelled and assignments were required to submit for grading. Honestly, the mid term was SO DIFFICULT and thus my score was horrible. Therefore, the final assignments really saved my ass. I think the grading is not that good for people who have little understanding on programming because it is more about how you can use those programming language accurately and recite the content you learnt is meaningless.
reviews.comment_workload:
Personally, the workload is not heavy at all as long as you attend all lab classes which teach you how to do your homework. You can just copy all lines showed in the lab and then mostly your assignments will be done. If you wanna score high in mid term and final, you have to practise more instead of just reciting lecture notes!
No group project, quiz, essay and presentation so the workload is low comparing to other courses.

reviews.author: Michael_Ng
reviews.comment_content: This course will teach fundamental python. The content is quite easy for everyone, even without any programming base. But it would be boring for people who are already familiar with python.
reviews.comment_teaching: I have only attended the lecture twice. Reading the lecture notes will already make you familiar with everything about the course. The lectures are quite interesting though, but it is quite a waste of time if you can read the lecture notes by yourself.
reviews.comment_grading: The lab reports are extremely easy to achieve full marks, just be careful and follow every step. The midterm is also very easy to achieve high marks. However, be careful about the final exam which is totally different from the midterm. Overall good grade course.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is extremely low. Just a few lab reports are needed, and no homework or quizzes.

reviews.author: lijmmm
reviews.title: Good Course for people without comp background
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Programming Language:
Loops, turtles, stacks, L-systems, strings, functions, stacks, timers, operators, and so on. Have labs every week which gives you different tasks to work on.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching was quite good. The teaching environment was fun and casual. Prof. Gibson was really nice, he was willing to help you and answer your questions. Btw his accent was good.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was fair. You just have to finish all your work. Two assignments take over 50% so you have to do them seriously. Final takes only 30% but also important. Although I got below mean during midterm, but I still got a vB+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light. You only have two assignments during the whole semesters and you have two weeks to finish each of them.

reviews.author: Dc528
reviews.title: 好course
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Python (Turtle,Loop, Range...).
因為初學都叫有野要背, 但喺內容算得意, 有畫下圖, 唔洗計數, 學Python套邏輯就可以.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor個tone幾好, 唔會眼訓(每堂1hr), 節奏算快
解釋都清楚
TA Jimmy都好nice, 好有耐性
Zoom個chat room都有好多互動, fun
reviews.comment_grading:
算靚grade
彈性計分方法,可以考MT或者唔考, 唔考啲比重落咗去Final
但MT比較簡單, Fina就l難
Lab: 100/100 (容易滿分, 有片教)
MT: 93/100    (Mean+1.x SD)
Final: 5x/100 (Mean+1.X SD)
Overall: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
每個禮拜一份Lab, 每份做兩個鐘到, 算輕鬆嘅
有時仲有非Hand-in Lab可以唔做

reviews.author: borische
reviews.comment_content:
basic things about python
for example string arrays etc
reviews.comment_teaching: ok, understandable, the instructor explain quite clearly and can teach things on time, his english is understandable as well
reviews.comment_grading:
pretty easy honestly
consist of mid-term, final and assignments
since we cant go to campus the finals became online assessments which is pretty easy
for the assignments, just watch out for some minor stuff as it can be overlooked quite easily.
mid-terms are easy as well
reviews.comment_workload:
very light
every time i did it just before the deadline so no worry!

reviews.author: 54D
reviews.comment_content: Fundamental programming concepts and techniques in Python 3. Uses Turtle to apply what you have learnt. For this semester, the course was cut short.
reviews.comment_teaching:
For lectures, fun professor and very nice. Remember to get your bonus points by answering his questions!

For labs, standard quality. You are free to do whatever you want in labs provided you don't play video games, but you must attend them.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fine. The materials, the assignments and exams are all quite easy, especially for students with programming background. Study a bit and perform well in exams, then you will easily secure a A- or above. Do not submit assignments late or you will regret deeply.
reviews.comment_workload: Light. The course encourages you to spread your assignment workload across multiple weeks and provides labs to guide you through everything.

reviews.author: b2
reviews.comment_content:
The content is very basic python programming and it is taught in a manner which is very easy to understand even for beginners. For anyone with any experience in programming, this should not be an issue at all.

My only (small) issue with the content is the fact that it focuses mainly on turtle graphics within python programming. While this may be enjoyable for new programmers, it may feel slightly boring for those who have had some programming experience.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Rossiter teaches the content in a very fun manner with a lot of class interaction even in the online mode. This was one of the few actually enjoyable courses I took last semester (online) as most other courses failed to make the class fun enough when switching to online teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
The course uses 2 grading schemes: 36% lab assignments, 23% midterms and 41% finals OR 44% lab assignments and 56% finals.

DO NOT take the midterm in a relaxed manner just because "it doesn't count even if I mess up". The midterm is extremely easy compared to the finals. The mean of the midterms is closer to about 80 whereas the mean of the finals was actually closer to 40. So even if you are well above the mean in the finals, you may fail to get A range since most people will be scoring a higher raw mark in the midterms.

I got 89 in midterms and about 60 in finals and ended up with an A.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much work handed out in class other than the lab assignments which must absolutely be submitted in time as they are a big part of your overall grade.

reviews.author: MasterFreedom
reviews.comment_content: Easy stuff. Do not required any knowledge of programming. The teaching and notes are easy to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Nice and kind instructor. Interesting lesson. Sometime he will make jokes during lesson.  You can ask any question about the course after the class.

Sometime he speak a little fast, but you ask him to slow down.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good grade. Just pay attention during lessons is enough. Sometime may have questions during lessons to let us earn bonus mark.
This term is quite special. Mid-term is normal paper test but open book. The final only need to finish some assignments.
reviews.comment_workload: Low workload. Just attend tutorials and the TA will teach almost 90% about the homework. Pay attention and follow him is enough.

reviews.author: nth
reviews.comment_content: 都係基本programming 野，都係教loop function無咩特別野

reviews.author: Olivia123

reviews.comment_teaching: Rossiter is very humorous and the class is fun. His English is good and easy to understand what he said.
reviews.comment_grading:

↑copied from slides

***no programming background, afraid of tech/computer stuff

so do your best in midterm and labs cuz they are really not difficult, and during final exam, it's okay if you failed to finish it, calm down, don't waste your time on one terrible question (unintentionally did this...maybe spent 15 to 20 min for the very first question, still did not get the correct ans and made myself more nervous), just move on :)
reviews.comment_workload: a few labs only, not difficult, but DO start earlier and ask tutors in tutorials sessions if that makes you feel better

reviews.comment_grading: if you give adequate effort then you get adequate score. basically you get the score as much as you try

reviews.author: Flora6293

There will be 5 labs in total.

There are two different grading systems, professor will help you calculate the best result.
reviews.comment_workload:
Mid-Term
5 labs
Final Exam

reviews.author: Kelvin Y
reviews.title: Gibson is the best
reviews.comment_content: Python programming course that teaches you the basics of programming. Good course to start with if you want to try out programming.
reviews.comment_teaching: Gibson is a really enthusiastic teacher, he really makes his classes engaging and enjoyable as much as he can. He once took out his own stuffed turtle to illustrate how a Python Turtle can move. He also tries to add jokes, not a lot of people react but it's his effort that makes it good.
reviews.comment_grading: I forgot how well I did for individual grades but I got a B+ in the end for basically doing all the labs and assignments fully plus some, but not a lot, of studying.
reviews.comment_workload: I found the assignments and labs to be pretty easy but there are a few. But they help a lot to practice which you need in programming so I think the workload is reasonable for a programming course.

reviews.author: Alan Guo
reviews.comment_content:
Basic python programming:
1. Getting started with Python
2. Beginning to program Python (Input and Output)
3. Introduction to turtle graphics
4. Making decisions (if-elif-else structure, nested if statements)
5. Loops (while loops)
6. Using loops with turtle graphics
7. Using for loops
8. Using for loops with turtle graphics
9. Lists and tuples
10. Handling repeating patterns (using modulus)
11. More on loops (continue, break)
12. Slicing
13. Handling of data types
14. More on lists and strings
15. Functions
16. Turtle shapes
17. Creating turtles
18. Clicking and dragging turtles
19. Handling key presses
20. Clicking on the turtle window
21. More on functions
22. More on operators
23. Using Timers
24. Dictionaries
25. File handling
26. Recursion
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is great as David is very passionate in the lectures as he often exceeds the lecture time of 50 minutes. He is very logical throughout the lectures and provide a lot of examples to help understanding.

The TA Jimmy is also very helpful. He has been giving timely feedbacks on labs, grades, and updates on the course website. Videos and detailed instructions are very helpful to finish the labs.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two grading schemes, and the higher one is automatically chosen.
1. 3*12% labs + 23% Mid-term + 41% Final
2. 3*14% labs + 0% Mid-term + 58% Final (weird numbers)

I am not exactly sure the percentage of each letter grade, so I cannot make a very decent comment in the section. The following numbers are for your reference:

1. First hand-in lab: Mean = 97.5, SD = 10.5, Max = 100
2. Second hand-in lab: Mean = 96.2, SD = 9.1, Max = 100
3. Third hand-in lab: Mean = 95.7, SD = 9.7, Max = 100
4. Mid-term: Mean = 75.2, SD = 15.2, Max = 100
5. Final: Mean = 41.1, SD = 13.8, Max = 81.4
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not quite heavy to be honest. There are six labs in total but only three are hand-in labs for submission. So just take some time to finish the labs, they are by no means hard. And in fact, the mean for every lab is crazily high. The TAs will also help you finish the labs, and there are very detailed instructions on the website.

Also, the exams are open-book, and they do not require memorising a lot. Understanding the content is more than enough to deal with the exams. But the final this semester is super hard :(

Full marks for first assignments
98% for second assignment

reviews.author: GDX_01
reviews.comment_content:
The course is about python program, using some basic coding.
In this course, you will learn how to use turtle graphics to draw different pictures, commands.
The content is appropriate even you did not learn ICT in secondary school.
You will learn how to make a simple game in the end which is satisfying.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lectures are great, Gibson teaches slow with examples to make sure everyone understands what he is doing. While Lam, Ngok uses some examples outside the textbook to explain some hard concepts.
Both teachers are willing to answer your questions and explain briefly after lessons or through email.
The labs are useful, as the TAs would teach you step by step to write some programs which will be useful for your homework. They are patient with your query.
reviews.comment_grading:
The assignments are not hard, most people get full marks. So you have to do well in the midterm and final exam.You need to be careful to get good result,
There are two grading method, and you will take the better one. If you did not do well in your midterm, your final exam will count more if you do better.
You need to get 90% or more in total to get into A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is appropriate, there are 2 assignments,
midterm and final exam,and the exams are open book.
Parts of the assignments are taught in the lab, and leave you about 2-3 weeks to finish, which you will have plenty of time.
There is no attendance taking, in both lab and lectures. You don't need to hand in the code you write in the labs, but you might need the in your assignments.
There might be so bonus questions in the lectures, and the lecturers will choose students to answer some simple questions and the might even give you hints when you are wrong.
The bonus questions counts bonus points in your assignments if you don't get full marks in them.

reviews.author: dna
reviews.comment_content: Really basic coding content that explains the concepts which can be used in complicated algorithms later. The turtle graphics section helps visualise various statements and types of coding concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Sung is an exciting professor who is passionate about his teaching and also gives various examples in class to explain different concepts.
reviews.comment_grading: The final exam was cancelled and a short quiz had to be completed. Two programming assignments were really fun and could be easily completed. Really competitive grading. Challenging midterm.
reviews.comment_workload: Manageable workload if you can attend classes regularly and follow the different examples and practice the different concepts taught.

reviews.author: MICHAEL YU WANG
reviews.comment_content: Quite ez not hard things basically things about the basic syntax you will learn when first studying computer science. Doesnt cover much though, cause this is just an introduction course
reviews.comment_teaching: Kim sung hun is pretty decent, typical korean professor with korean accent. Interested so much in AI and show interesting things
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is pretty good and lenient. Altough you get mean for the midterm, good grade at online test for final can get you an A-
reviews.comment_workload: Workload only 2 big assignments which you can do together with your friends. No other task.

reviews.author: Monky
reviews.title: Epic
reviews.comment_content:
Very straightforward yet comprehensive course that vastly covers the fundamentals of programming.

The basic structure of the 2019-20 Fall semester was as follows:

Assignment #1
Assignment #2
Mid-term Exam
Final Exam

The course covers various concepts such as variables, lists, loops, if conditions, functions, recursion, etc.. If you have prior knowledge of programming, this course should be a piece of cake.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Lam is an enthusiastic teacher who incorporates humour in all his lectures. His upbeat tone is sure to motivate even the most demotivated students.

Every lecture is based on one main programming concept; the presentation files for each lecture can be found on the designated COMP 1021 website, so attending lectures is not necessary as class content can be viewed whenever and wherever.

It does however become important to attend labs when working on assignments, as you will cover almost 80~90 % of your assignments during the labs.
reviews.comment_grading:
I'm not really sure about the grading scheme of this course, as I was expecting to receive an A+ but have received an A overall, despite attaining three 100s for my Final Exam, Assignment #1, and Assignment #2, and only one 95 for my Mid-term Exam.

The grading of this course seems appropriate nevertheless. Expect to be studying with peers who also have prior knowledge in the course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Little to no workload for this course if you attend all lab sessions to work on your assignments. The labs virtually cover the assignment entirely, so it's best to attend them and get the assignments over with.

If labs are not attended however, one may have to stay up late to work on their assignements, albethey not difficult, but lengthy.

reviews.author: jeff k.
reviews.comment_content: Basic programming using python such as turtle, functions, if loops, while loops, etc. If you already have some background knowledge of programming, you will find this course easy.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor teaches really well and tries to answer as many questions as possible. He tries to make sure those who are not familiar with programming to understand. The pace of the lecture was adequate, and if you already have some background knowledge of programming, you may even find the lecture as boring. However, even if you miss out on the lectures, it is recommended that you do not miss out on the lab sessions. During the lab sessions, the tutor does a demo so that you can try using the code yourselves with a computer. The lab session is basically copying the code that the tutor writes, but it does help you understand the content much more easily. Also, the tutor does the demonstration of the lab really quickly, so if you do not review your course material or daydream during the lab sessions, you may miss out on an important part that may affect your program overall. Moreover, the tutor does not go back and tell you what the code was even if you ask them, so you should be vigilant at all times. Because the pace is really quick, the lab session ends really quickly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Distribution of grading:

Assignment 1 25%/35%
Assignment 2 25%/35%
Midterm 35%/10%
Online assignment 15%/20%

There are two ways of calculating the final grade, so even if you mess up on the midterm you can do well on the final exam (which was replaced with an online assignment this semester) and get a good score. Also, the assignments were basically giving you free points, so getting a full mark on the assignments and the online assignment was not a big problem. However, because it is easy for you, it is also easy for everyone else, so if you are aiming for an A or an A+, you may have to get nearly full marks for every assignment and the test.
reviews.comment_workload: There is very little workload, but it is almost necessary to attend the lab sessions. The assignments were based on the lab sessions, so if you do not attend the lab sessions you may fall behind. There were a total of 2 assignments but if you attended all the lab sessions and are comfortable with the content, you will find no difficulty and will easily get a full mark.

reviews.author: joseph14wkh
reviews.comment_content: The content is quite easy. The content of lecture notes is well organised. However,  MT is quite difficult and is totally different level compare with lecture notes.
reviews.comment_teaching: Gibson is quite funny. He explains the content of lecture notes very well and  can teach us in a funny way.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment1: 97/100
Assessment2: 100/100
midterm:45/100
online assessment(replacement for final exam): 92/100
grade: B+
it is good that there is two methods to calculate your grade.
Method1: 15%assessment 1
                15% assessment2
                 35% midterm
                 35% final
method2: 15% assessment 1
                15% assessment 2
                 5% midterm
                 65% final
so if you did not do well in MT, you will still get a good grade if you pay more effort and do well in final exam.
reviews.comment_workload: there is only two assessment in this course and it is very easy to finish it as about 80% of the assessment is already done in the lessons. what you need to do is to add a few code by yourself in order to get full mark.

reviews.author: JOEdric
reviews.comment_content: Essentially, python beginners course. The course covers basic programming constructs, functions, variables, loops, etc, and turtle api. This course is great for anyone without experience in programming.
reviews.comment_teaching: Kim's english is a little bit stuttery, but still manages to explain concepts clearly. He is also very passionate about cs, as he would often times show videos of the latest trends in cs and invite us out to talk about python. Overall decent lecturer.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading should be fine, as long as you're able to understand the concepts. Sd can get quite big, so its important not to lag behind.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is pretty light. There are only 2 assignments, which are pretty easy to finish if you follow the labs

reviews.author: Iphoooooone
reviews.title: 有program底A+完全無難度
reviews.comment_content:
python入門野

syntax可以唔使死背，因為系open book exam

sit過其他lecturer堂，都好輕鬆
