reviews.author: issac lo
reviews.title: Easy course but with a very harsh grade
reviews.comment_content:
This course teaches some primary python language stuff while using it to teach you some basic concepts about computer science, including:
1. if-else logic
2. while loop
3. for loop
4. computer data type such as integer, string, list.....etc.
5. function
6. recursion
And it mainly uses the stuff called turtle graphics to teach you about these concepts.

Please be noted that the textbook is mainly useless since the lecture slides can provide a better understanding than the textbook.....so expect you are wealthy and want to spend money on some extra stuff. save that money and have a coffee.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor David's Teaching is outstanding, one of the best at HKUST. He is chilling, and his teaching style is quite funny, which makes getting the concept relatively easy. In addition, lecture notes are well structured, so you can quickly get ideas. Finally, assistants by TAs in the lab are handy. One-on-one assistance is provided with good homework content so that you can quickly locate your missing concept and resolve it with the TAs in the lab. So I think you should attend this section.
reviews.comment_grading: I have to give a D on the grading since the grading has become quite tight this year; I don't trust the senior who said this is a good grade course since the grading has been changed. You will face some of the masters in python taking this course, and YOU WILL BE Fed if you are a newbie. So I suggest you take the code camp before taking this course.
reviews.comment_workload: This course has a reasonable workload since very few lab projects have to be submitted in this course. Moreover, the projects are easy since the templates are given, and you must fill in the fixing code. Assistants are also provided so you can get help if you are trapped. But I give a B grade since you will have tremendous pressure by having zero mistakes in the homework so that you will not miss a lot of marks and get a poor grade since the mean is relatively high and the SD is relatively small. You also have to take a lot of past papers to get familiar with the exam mode.

reviews.author: hehehe6
reviews.comment_content:
For business students:
The content up to midterm is pretty much similar to what you learn at ISOM 2020.
But after midterm, everything else is new. So you'll need to spend more time revising the material.
reviews.comment_teaching: Since all classes are recorded, you have a choice to watch the recording of other professors' lectures. I watched Prof Rossiter's and really enjoyed them. He made the classes fun and interesting.
reviews.comment_grading:
1st way:
midterm - 24%
lab projects - 36%
final exam - 40%

2nd way:
midterm - 0%
lab projects - 42%
final exam - 58%

The grade is super flexible, so there is much less pressure on the midterm exam. Unlike other courses, you will be able to make up for your midterm grade.

midterm - mean
lab projects - 100% for all
final - mean
I got a B- in the end.
reviews.comment_workload: There's not much workload. Only three lab projects need to be completed throughout the semester. But make sure you have everything correct in the lab because the mean is high. Small mistakes can really affect your grade. Same for the exams: since there are no partial credits in the questions, it's either you get 8 marks or you lose everything.

reviews.author: alsdkfjlask
reviews.comment_content:
Python turtle is easy for beginners to learn about programming, although little or none practical uses.
Nevertheless, basic programming concepts including i/o, functions, recursion etc. are introduced which are crucial for later COMP courses.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. Alex Lam taught well with the interactive examples. Even if he missed certain concepts of one lesson, he will always explain the next lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading methods.

24% midterm + 36% lab + 40% final
OR
42% lab + 58% final

Very high mean. If you don't make any careless mistakes, you should be able to get 100%. Test your lab's code with the lab's code accordingly.



Total score: 99.3%
Final grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Three hand-in labs in total, with guidance provided.
The burden for this course is actually rather low, so you have plenty of time and resources to learn everything, even solely through self-study and PowerPoint presentations.

I completed all of the self-tests and practice exams for the midterm and final. Although it may take a while, it is really beneficial! (I strongly advise you guys to do everything because the questions are fairly close to the tests.)

reviews.author: randust
reviews.comment_content: Some basic python programming, including turtle graphics, functions, lists, classes, for/while loops and recursion.
reviews.comment_teaching: My first impression of him is that he is quite funny, but I have skipped most of the lessons, so there is nothing more to talk about.
reviews.comment_grading: It seems to be a good grade course before but not for this semester. The final is so easy that the mean is around 70, with 20 sd. Each mistake in the final will cost a subgrade. I got one question wrong, so I only got an A with an overall 95%. There are two grading systems: 1) lab 42%, final 58% 2) lab 36%, midterm 24%, final 40%.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite light. It only contains 3 submission labs, but I recommend finishing all labs, as they might appear in the exam.

reviews.author: sengSL4Y
reviews.title: Pretty good course even with no programming experience
reviews.comment_content:
I personally have no text programming background at all (only block programming experience). The first few topics were all fundamental, so if you didn't fully understand it, you wouldn't be able to understand the succeeding lessons. Most of the lessons after the midterm just build on your fundamental knowledge by making it more complex.

There were 31 PowerPoint Presentation files (including introductory ones) and each PPT usually corresponds to one topic.

There are both explanations and examples provided in the PPTs. They oversimplify many terms and make analogies to help better understand the topics (which is extremely helpful if you do not have any experience with programming, but it might seem too easy to those who have experience).

However, the midterm and final exams are completely different from the labs and interactive examples. They are much longer and usually don't have much examples to refer to in the PPTs. I STRONGLY RECOMMEND doing pass papers AND the interactive examples to strengthen your knowledge and become comfortable with the exam format.

Many questions can be overwhelming and complicated that require you to read long lines of code and try to critically interpret it without putting it into python.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I attended almost all of the lectures and I can say that this course can definitely be learned alone. The lecture did help to supplement my learning but because most of the information about each topic are thoroughly explained in the PPTs, it's easy to learn on your own.

Professor Li does a good job at teaching the course as it was made to be taught - as an introduction to computer science for those who have no background knowledge on it. She can be a bit repetitive sometimes, but they can also serve as important reminders for beginners. She rarely talks about things that are not included in the PPT and she entertains questions well. She is very responsive and easy to approach.
reviews.comment_grading:
(not sure about the mean scores per lab)

Lab 1: 100/100
Lab 4: 95/100
Lab 5: 79/100

Practice Midterm: 70/100
Midterm: 59/100 (Mean: 62)

Final: 84/100 (Mean: 71)


I'd say the grading is quite good. They give you two options for course grading:

1. Midterm 24%, Lab 36%, Final 40%
2. Midterm 0%, Lab 42%, Final 58%

After the final exam, they will automatically choose the best grading option for you, so there is some reassurance when taking the midterm.
reviews.comment_workload:
Interactive Examples in the Website
7 Labs
1 Midterm Exam
1 Final Exam

I recommend doing the interactive examples after every lecture to test your understanding of the topic. You can also use them to help you review for the midterm/final exam.

Not all labs were hand-in/graded so the workload wasn't that bad. However, sometimes doing the lab alone can be tricky, especially the labs towards the end of the semester before the final exam.

i went to only the first lecture. Rossiter is a fun person but as i didn't go to much lessons i can't judge if he teaches well.

//
24% midterm + 36% lab + 40% final
OR

reviews.author: APKB
reviews.title: Basic Python
reviews.comment_content:
It is all about Python 3.10 and aim to build up your programming mindset. From basic programming to the programming logic and the turtle drawings. It would be a great advantage if you have studied ICT (compulsory) or self-learnt any programming stuff before.

I took Elective A (Database), instead of Elective D (Software Development), in my DSE ICT and got a 5* (in fact 0.5% to 5**) in 2022 but I didn't find this course tough to study.

But please be noted that this course does not require you to have a programming background and it starts from zero. Therefore, I don't think that it is difficult to catch up if you have no ICT knowledge.

However, I think that there is too much content about turtle drawings in python instead of real problem-solving algorithms. This is the only minus point I think about the content of this course.

Overall content rate: A-
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Rossiter is passionate in teaching and he speaks English with native American (or British?) accent, which is clear, humorous and easy to understand his teaching. He does not follow the slides as always but tell you all the thing with a variety of in-class practice. He will provide some in-class questions can invite us to answer. Also, he is okay with answering questions after lecture.

Despite of his sometime unfriendly personality, he is one of the best professors in HKUST.

Overall teaching rate: A
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading systems as follows,
Plan A: Midterm 24%, Lab 36%, Final 40%;
Plan B: Midterm 0%, Lab 42%, Final 58%,
automatically pick the highest score among two plans.

The exams are open-note and open-book, with plenty of past papers officially provided so that you can have enough practice before exams

Midterm exam: average 62.1, standard deviation 24.1, maximum 100, minimum 7
Final exam: average 71.3, standard deviation 20.7, maximmum 100, minimum 4

My scores: Lab + Midterm + Final = All full marks 100
Total score (Grade): not yet announced til writing, but I guess A+

But actually online exam, we can use python idle during exams, the short time allowance force me to just type the code. Most questions you can just type as fast as you can and generate the answers :), not very able to test your understanding in fact.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are two lectures (each 50 minutes) and one voluntary lab session (110 minutes) per week.

No attendance is taken, you can skip all the lectures and lab sessions if you can handle it. Video recording of lectures is available. Lab sessions are just for you to ask questions about the lab work while actually the website of the lab has already given you plenty of guidelines.

The only workload is the weekly lab work, only _ out of _ need submission, with marking scheme provided before submission deadline. The only tough stuff are some lab works like designing a game with python requiring you to think a lot.

Overall workload rate: A (about 2.8 credit)

reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload.

Labs are quite straightforward and with clear instructions, as long as you check your work clearly according to the marking scheme it's easy to score full marks.

Midterm and Final require you to be very careful and not make stupid mistakes, otherwise, it's not that hard. They test your understanding of the questions and how to use appropriate coding skills and logical thinking to tackle them.

reviews.author: mading18
reviews.title: turtle
reviews.comment_content:
Basic programming course that uses Python language

Turtle graphics (basically a graphic-based visual output of Python code, designed for beginners)
Decision making (if/else)
Operators
Loops (while/for)
Data handling(lists, strings, tuples, text files, dictionaries)
Functions and variables
RGB
Objects and classes
Robot thinking
Recursion

As a SSCI student with zero programming experience, the content towards the end got really complicated but overall was generally manageable
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gibson teaches really well; his lectures are very entertaining and actually gets you to engage in the things that he is doing; I saw myself trying to do some of the things he demonstrates on my own computer during his lectures

IDK about the other lecturers, but Gibson speaks very fluent English so it's easy to re-watch his lectures without being confused

I recommend doing the interactive examples on the website soon after the lecture ends so that you can gain your own experience, and around 2 weeks before both exams go onto the past paper website that they provide and start doing practice exams.

Unless you're really struggling in doing some of the labs, feel free to skip lab sessions; TA's will only let you stay in those Zoom meetings if you have an actual question otherwise they'll kick you out
reviews.comment_grading:
They offer flexibility to give you the optimal grade for this course

Option 1:
Midterm 24%
Labs 36%
Final 40%

Option 2:
Midterm 42%
Final 58%

They will base your score on the best result of these two calculations, so if you mess up on midterms it's okay

My recommendation: Do as well as you can on the midterms, try to aim for full marks for each lab, and try your best on the finals.
Most people in Fall 2022 scored 70% average for both midterms and finals(which is actually unusually high) and 80%-85% average for labs

I have to add that this semester's final exam was not at the same difficulty and style of questions compared to other COMP1021 finals; there were ZERO questions where you wrote your own code to answer the question and there were a lot of questions that were basically "freebies"; therefore the curve this year was a lot harsher and mean higher

My scores:
Midterm: 76/100
Labs:
100/100
100/100
88/100
Final: 100/100
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Light to normal workload (depending on how experienced you are at programming; if you're a CS student who has experience you'll breeze though these, if you have no experience you may struggle a bit)

Every week normally has a "lab" that is a series of activities related to the content taught in the past few weeks of that time; a total of 7 labs were taught with 3 of them being hand-in labs.

LAB CONTENT:
0: Turtle graphics introduction (EASY)
1: Guessing game (HAND-IN) (EASY)
2: Turtle "sketchbook" (EASY)
3: Turtle "fireworks" (INTERMEDIATE)
4: Jigsaw puzzle (HAND-IN) (INTERMEDIATE)
5: Music System (HAND-IN) (ADVANCED)
6: Robot game (ADVANCED)

Although just 3 out of those 7 labs are hand-in, still try to get all 7 finished; they will ask questions in the midterms and finals that share the same type of content as the lab, and knowing what the labs talked about would be a benefit

reviews.author: HCccc
reviews.comment_content: An introduction course for python and let students have more interactions with python through learning using turtle, which is a drawing programme offered by python. Also, students could learn the logic behind the python language and improve the thinking skills. Sometimes, the course seems to be a mathematical course since you have to use some math knowledge. Overall, it is an interesting course for all students even though you have zero coding experience.
reviews.comment_teaching: Alex is a good teacher since his spoken English is quite fluent and clear and thus it is easy to be followed by all students. For each lecture, he will give a short review and then move on to talk about the new content. Also, when he is trying to explain the logic behind some codes, it is quite clear and accurate.
reviews.comment_grading: A good grade course since there are two grading methods. One is 24% MT + 36% Project + 40% Final The other one is 42% project +58% Final  The highest grade within these two methods will be automatically chosen as your final grading method
reviews.comment_workload: There is  no homework instead of 3 hand-in Projects. No need to spend many time on doing assignments

Another one who lost marks because I stupidly typed the 'yes' in the final instead of 'YES' 🥲 (Surprised to see there is someone else as well in the reviews who had the same experience 🤔) I did so in two questions but thankfully prof Rossiter awarded me marks for one of the two questions.
I ended up getting a B because of this even when my lab assignments were full marks and my midterm was above mean, which means that the grade curve is high and small mistakes can cost a lot!
TLDR: So do be careful of answering exactly as is written in the question!!

LAB 1 = 100/100 (AVG = 97.8)

reviews.comment_teaching: Honestly, I can't comment much on this since I skipped out on a lot of the classes (I already knew the content so I just submitted the labs and did the exercise). For the classes that I did go to, I thought the teaching was good, clear and engaging so I'll give this an A

reviews.comment_workload:
the workload is quite low. Only need to do 3 lab assignments. There are clear guidelines for each of them that you can copy part of the codes and there is step-by- step explanation in some videos.
For the midterm and final exam, the cheatsheet is given and they are open-book so you don't need to memorize the syntax but know how to use them.

reviews.author: lpyocoia
reviews.title: good grade
reviews.comment_content:
A programming course for python. Go check other reviews for details.


Just a Leng grade course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
As it doesn't take attendance, you can attend any other prof's lecture as you want. (It is also recommended by the prof)
I attended two lessons only then skipped the remaining  (i need more sleeep)
So it might not be accurate. Gibson's lessons are fun and his tone isn't boring. You won't fall asleep easily. :)

All sessions are using the pdf prepared by Prof. Rossiter (should be) And the sample codes/ contents in the notes can actually make you laugh. The notes might skip some details but it is still fine as it covers up everything tested in the exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
Scheme I: midterm 24%, final 40%, lab projects 36%
Scheme II: midterm 0%, final 58%, lab projects 42%

Lab 2,5,7: 100/100
Tbh just follow the TA's videos then you will get a 100.

Mid term: 67/100

Maximum: 100
Minimum (except zero): 10
Mean: 71.9
SD: 21.4


Final: 75.78/100

Maximum: 100
Minimum (except zero): 4
Mean: 47.57
SD: 18.98

Grade: A
Spend half a day to finish all the notes before final. Just make sure you can understand what the code in notes actually does.

For the final it is not that hard but the time constrain is tight.
Past papers and practice exams are provided with explanations. Finishing them can probably guarantee you an A ?!

I didn't do revision for the midterm so it's kinda screwed up.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are Labs to do but only three of them count to the grade.
It is easy to score 100 if you follow steps by steps to the TA's video.

The Lab sessions are for you to seek help if you encounter any problem. (normally won't)
(Not a physical lab work but just a few programming tasks )

reviews.author: copper_star
reviews.title: Good course for beginners
reviews.comment_content:
Learning Python code along with Turtle Graphics

Turtle Graphics, Loops (while, for, nested), Decision making (if, elif, else), Lists, Tuples, Strings, Slicing, Dictionary, Functions, Operators, Colors, Recursion, etc.

No need to purchase the book. PPT Slides are given.
There are two lectures every week, 50 minutes each.
Used Python IDLE 3.9.5 during the lecture and the exams.
8 lab projects in total. 3 projects are hand-in.
reviews.comment_teaching: My lecture (L02) was a mixed-mode, so I could attend the lecture both in-person and Zoom. I think Professor Rossiter is good. This course was one of the courses that I didn't sleep during the lecture. Professor Rossiter passionately conducted the class. He taught with an excited tone, not being monotonous. He usually uses his own examples and other things, rarely using Powerpoint slides.
reviews.comment_grading:
Scheme I: midterm 24%, final 40%, lab projects 36%
Scheme II: midterm 0%, final 58%, lab projects 42%

midterm: 100/100 (mean: 71.9, s.d: 21.4)
final: 57.67/100 (mean: 48.57, s.d: 19.29)
lab: 100/100
total grade: A-

No attendance. I had never experienced programming before I came to HKUST. I didn't take computer science in IB. Labs are easy to get 100 unless you don't submit the assignment on time or make plagiarism. The midterm exam was relatively easy while the final exam was a nightmare. Professors reveal plenty of past papers before the exam, so you can practice the exam with them.
reviews.comment_workload: There were 8 lab projects in total and 3 of them were hand-in assignments. As this course was the first time in my life to do programming, it took some time for me to fully understand what I learned in the lecture and apply it to the lab projects. For each hand-in lab project, it took at least 3 hours for me to completely finish and submit the project. Other than that, the workload is not high.

reviews.author: Ho Woon
reviews.comment_content: This a programming course for python, where you will learn I/O,  basic logics, loops, turtle graphics(including using turtle's event handler), data type (list, tuple, string, dictionary), slicing, function, python operators, very basic oop (just talk a little bit on creating class and methods), recursion, coordinate system and state diagram.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Lam, Ngok will use slides and mainly the examples released on the web site for teaching. If you want more example you can join other sessions. The course is tailor-made to allow students to join other professors session, because all session are in the same pace. Prof. Lam session is not boring and he answers all questions after lecture. Also, the lab session is not mandatory to join, you only have to join if you have question to ask about the lab.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two grading methods:

36% lab
24% midterm
40% final

or

42% lab
0%  midterm
58% final

The course will choose the method with the higher score for you.

There are 7 labs + one intro lab, but only 3 of them are graded assignments and the 3 of them have the same weighting in lab.

The labs are easy if you already learn a bit of programming beforehand and they shouldn't be too hard for those who don't.

The midterm is also easy if you already learn a bit of programming beforehand, just double-check your answers when you have time.

The final exam is hard, because the time constrain is pretty tight. Also, double-check the answer and don't fall into some traps. Then, you will be fine.

Grade:
100% lab 2
100% lab 5
100% lab 7
100% midterm
96% final (when multiplying strings for n times in python, a string with copy and concatenate to itself for n-1 times, so if its "12" *2, its "1212", not 24)
Final Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
There are only three mandatory labs, which are lab 2, lab 5 and lab 7. Hence, you can skip other labs if you deemed them
unnecessary.

The midterm and final exam are open-book, where you are free to use the internet, but you are not allow to communication through the internet, so you can search the syntax if you forgot the syntax.

reviews.author: Zachary260325
reviews.title: Easy course for those with programming basics
reviews.comment_content: Nice for beginners, but a bit too easy for those who learned any programming languages before.
reviews.comment_teaching: Easy to understand and has recordings in every lecture, very convenient.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading methods.
1. Mid 24%, lab 36%, final 40%
2. Mid 0%, lab 42%, final 58%

For me:
Lab 100/100
Mid 100/100 ( Mean: 71.9 SD: 21.4 )
Final 93/100 ( Mean: 47.57 SD: 18.98 )
Although I made a stupid mistake in the final and didn't get full marks, it's still easy. I learned c++ before I entered university so it's not difficult.
And obviously, I got an A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Actually quite small.
You just need to finish the labs if you already understood the things taught in class. That's not very much.

reviews.author: gordonmeng
reviews.comment_content:
Actually, I think the content is pretty easy, if you work hard you can get a good grade.

Content:
basic programming knowledge,
turtle programming,
for/while loop,
if / else / elif statement,
nested loop/if statement,
data type handling
file handling
function
dictionary
object
recursion
and a lot of small stuff (e.g. slicing,timer)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Interesting.
Daivd's lessons explain all of the concepts while trying to make the lesson much more interesting. He often jokes about himself with the programs.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is good.
2 methods: (automatically choose the best method)
method 1:
3 labs: 12%@ 36%total
mid term: 24%
final: 40%
method 2:
3 labs: 14%@ 42%total
mid term: 0%
final:58%
reviews.comment_workload: Low workload

reviews.author: Davidwangzy
reviews.title: Basic but not that basic programming course
reviews.comment_content:
Basic programming knowledge:
Conditional Statement
Operators
Loops
File handling...;
and use the above knowledge in Python turtle programs.
Basic introduction course.

It will be quite easy to handle if you have a programming background, e.g. HKDSE ICT.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kim uses PowerPoint slides a lot in the class but also has his own illustrations. However, sometimes he didn't know what the slides is talking about?! and needed to ask TA for help.

Overall he is a fair professor, but I would prefer Rossiter more.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is quite good with a large A range.

2 schemes for grade calculation:
3 hand-in labs: in total 36%/42%
Midterm: 24%/0%
(Maximum: 100
Minimum (except zero): 10
Mean: 71.9
SD: 21.4)

Final: 40%/58%
(Maximum: 100
Minimum (except zero): 4
Mean: 48.57
SD: 19.29)

I've got full marks in all 3 labs and midterms, got 77/100 in the final.
My final grade is A+ (91%), which is better than I expected. I was expecting 95% to get an A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite a low workload.

The only workload is the labs. Each lab will need 0.5-3 hours to finish. I strongly suggest you finish all the labs, no matter if it's a hand-in one or not. Even non-hand-in labs will appear in the exams.

Make sure you revise carefully and answer the questions carefully in the final, the difficulty is very different from the midterm.

reviews.author: xqcL
reviews.comment_content:
basic python programming up to recursion

and the course uses a lot of python turtle
reviews.comment_teaching:
good, easy to understand and follow

since this sem is online learning and the course provide all the zoom link for different prof, you are free to join whatever session you like
I would recommend you to try out all of them in the first class to find out which is the most suitable for you
reviews.comment_grading:
grading method:
1.Midterm 24%, Lab projects 36%, Final exam 40%
2.Midterm 0%, Lab projects 42%, Final exam 58%

the lab are very easy and the majority of student got full mark, so try to double check the code before submitting to avoid lost mark

since the final is extremely difficult, work hard in the midterm to secure at least b range

both midterm and final exam are very time limited, so try to use past paper to practice the speed
reviews.comment_workload:
very low workload

no attendance required

only 3 lab are hand in lab that you are required to submit
and almost all the task in the lab are being guided by the TA so you just need to follow the instruction and finish the last part by yourself

reviews.author: Brnchun
reviews.title: COMP1021
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Python knowledge and concepts, with python turtle.
-Input/output(Including event handlers)
-For/While loop
-List/tuples/dictionary
-Data types
-Turtle
-Text and file handling
-Coordinating system
-RGB colour scheme
-Function
-Objects
-Recursion
reviews.comment_teaching: David is a really funny and nice guy. The TA named Jimmy is also very nice because he is willing to answer all your questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
The midterm exam is really simple. The mean is 75 and the SD is 15.
HOWEVER THE FINAL EXAM IS HELL. YOU CANNOT POSSIBLY FINISH THE EXAM BECAUSE THE TIME IS VERY SHORT AND THE QUESTIONS ARE VERY VEEEEERY LONG AND IT REQUIRES YOU TO DOWNLOAD MANY FILES. YOU WOULD NOT EVEN BOTHER TO THINK BY THE END OF THE EXAM BECAUSE YOU WOULD FEEL SO NERVOUS AND DESPERATE AND WANT TO KILL YOURSELF.
reviews.comment_workload: Really little workload. The labs are counted as assignments and you only need to submit 3 of them. The labs are taught step by step. The TA almost gives you everything except for a few lines of code every time.

reviews.author: Nopaynogain_hk
reviews.title: Poor grade
reviews.comment_content: Python programming with turtle graphics, should be easy for those who have learned python programming before, but it is actually quite hard for me as i haven't learnt any. So, take your time to learn some basic programming skills before jumping in to this course
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite interactive but sometimes a little bit long in explaining some details
reviews.comment_grading: Acceptable based on my peer's comment as I think my friends scored 2.0 SD above mean and they are quite happy about it.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not really high as there are only 3 labs which need to be submitted. But it takes time for you to complete those interactive examples

reviews.author: attempt0
reviews.title: Good course for beginners
reviews.comment_content:
This course teaches python. Python is a rather easy programming language as it has less syntax sugar when compared to other languages. Besides, the standard library is also quite easy to use.

Topics include: Variables, Loops, Functions, Recursions
reviews.comment_teaching: Didn't attend the lectures as I already have programming experience. But I've heard that the teaching is good.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is pretty good. The assignment mean is very high and the second assignment median is 100 so you need to be careful to not make mistake in assignment.

The exams mainly contain some tricky question that you again need to be careful. The time is also quite tight! 9 question 40 minutes for each part and there is a lot of text to read. Typing speed can help A TON in the exam. Some questions if you type them out can be much easier to do.
My scores:
Lab 2: 100%
Lab 5: 100%
Lab 7: 100%
Midterm: 100%
Final: 94/100

There is 2 grading schemes, if you didn't do well in the midterm it will not be included in the grading.
reviews.comment_workload: The assignment has all the instructions to guide you step by step. They will even provide the setup code for you so you don't have to start from scratch in the assignment.

reviews.author: Chris Li
reviews.comment_content:
Some basic Python knowledge, really easy
This course teaches us how to draw some stuffs and programming syntax with python 3.9.
lecture notes are provided with examples and common errors. The labs will help you familiar with programming syntax and some logic.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very patient, but a bit too slow
reviews.comment_grading:
Not bad
I got 100 in Midterm exam and the mean is 70
reviews.comment_workload: Really little workload. The labs are counted as assignments and you only need to submit 3 of them. The labs are taught step by step. The TA almost gives you everything except for a few lines of code every time.

reviews.author: Great Dragon
reviews.title: Have fun!
reviews.comment_content: A course that introduces a basic programming language called python.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nice professor. Able to deliver course materials and knowledge clearly in the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: Two types of grading. One type counted midterm in the final but another type does not. This is really nice because this gives a chance.for students to choose whether attempting the mid term. If you are confident in getting high mark in final, you may even skip the midterm, nice!
reviews.comment_workload: Low. But the last lab is a bit tough. The robot game program is quite long. But overall the workload is low.

reviews.author: 清水灣董詠培
reviews.title: 黎個prof.教得好正上堂都好開心
reviews.comment_content:
第一堂就講明會用好多唔同例子去講解note
每一堂都講到好有趣同埋將啲好悶既cs野講到好簡單又輕鬆

lab方面係online上 入佢個website就有lab既教學

mid term都好輕鬆 有個practice mt唔計分但比你熟習點考

reviews.comment_grading:
有兩套計分方法

MT唔趕同埋啲人都好大路 你有做過LAB有上堂佢基本上都出曬
2122Fall sem唯一唔伏既course

reviews.author: Leo11222948

reviews.comment_content:
其實d野真係好簡單（目前來講）
就算系無接觸過programming 的人，只要肯去聽lecture同埋做lab溫ppt就一定會識
如果有接觸過programming的話，基本上去到midterm都完全唔需要聽書（lecture 可以全部skip），臨考前溫一下past paper同埋ppt，就應該會有唔錯分數

值得一提系，佢個d資源都幾充足。佢自己有一個網站，上面可以好清楚找到以往堂上ppt。同埋呢個course系我報左第一個sem入邊唯一一個提供past paper的course，中有d系interactive添。

個final真係嚇親我，其實內容就唔係好難，只不過題目太多，強烈提醒所有人記得做快d，唔好系一條題目浪費太多時間，唔好好似我一開始瘋狂對答案，check真d，搞到後面題目完全唔夠時間。

reviews.author: 川董
reviews.comment_content:
the basic concept of python.
Perfect course for beginners. But be aware of that, this is the easiest course in Comp courses, please don't choose 2012H without a proficiency background.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher has fluent speech, so it is easy to catch up with the concept.
reviews.comment_grading:
it has 2 grading policies, you can choose either one.

midterm and final are easy but you should pay attention to the question with great care.

You can easily get an A range if you pay attention to the class.
reviews.comment_workload:
very small.
basically, you can finish the lab within an hour. and the project is quite easy.

reviews.author: lmacchch
reviews.title: Good！
reviews.comment_content: I don't want to give any comments to the content because I can't say whether it's good or not, because I only know a little about CS.
reviews.comment_teaching: I can't comment whether Kim's teaching is good, because I don't know what a good teacher should be.
reviews.comment_grading:
My own thoughts: That's something most important and I'd like to say a lot about that.
I think getting an A in semester can be a little easier for truly master, as this semester's test is obviously much more difficult than previous year. Therefore, truly master can distinguish themselves with common people more easily.
Two grading scheme: A: 36% lab(12*3)+ 24% midterm+40% final
B:42% lab(14*3)+58% final, whichever is higher
My grade: full in all labs(in fact, almost everyone got full marks)
92/100 in midterm( mean is 71 while sd is 21)
73/100 in final(mean is 48 while sd is 18)
And I got A in the end.
As my senior students said, getting above mean 1 sd can get A is normal grade in UST. Therefore, I'd like to say the grading for the course is normal
reviews.comment_workload: Workload isn't very huge. Only 3 hand-in labs in total and every week, there will be a lab for you to practice.

reviews.author: Re
reviews.comment_content: This is indeed a introductory course to Computer Science. However, Python is not very useful for your study in COMP2011 if you aim to study in ELEC, CPEG, COMP, and any other major/minor with COMP2011 as their major requirement. Yes, Python is more beginner friendly for learning how to programming, but it is not helpful for you to understand languages like C++ and Java. The turtle library is used just for you to understand the basics of programming more easily.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Generally speaking, The notes provided by the course is simple, easy to understand and universal for all lecture sessions, and the student enrolled into the course can access to other sessions recording.

Personally prefer Cecia’s teaching as I found her teaching style is more lively.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is actually not that bad, but not that good either.
reviews.comment_workload: There were only 6-7 labs throughout the year, and only 3 of them are actually assessed assignments. Theoretically speaking, you can skip all lectures and use the Python IDLE/VSC to run the codes or example in the lecture slides to learn all the content of the course at your own pace.

reviews.author: hw1
reviews.title: Good Grading Course
reviews.comment_content: Very simple programming concept in Python. Very easy if you have learnt programming before. If you have not, I do feel like it is still relatively easier than other Year 1 Courses.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecturers teach quite slowly and mainly just read off the lecture slides. It is highly recommended to just study the lecture slides yourself, and if you need further explanation, join the lectures or watch the lecture recordings.
reviews.comment_grading:
Relative to other year 1 courses, COMP 1021 has better grading

CGA Booster for Major Selection
reviews.comment_workload:
Throughout the whole term, there is only three labs, however the assignments might take up quite some time to finish if you have no background knowledge in programming.

If there is a problem you can always go to the Labs and ask the TAs who are very friendly and are eager to help you out.

reviews.author: mzzZ
reviews.title: Good intro to python
reviews.comment_content: Basic introduction to python ( turtle, loops, class, recursions...)  half of the course content is taught in ISOM2020, so having taken it before does help with understanding and getting good grades.
reviews.comment_teaching: Basically reading the ppt but all the instructors share their class videos so you can not go to class and watch different professor's videos.
reviews.comment_grading:
rather competitive but professors try to scale it up. (e.g. choose best 6 questions out of 7)

Two grading plans:
1. 24%midterm, 36%labs, 40%final
or
2. 0%midterm, 42%labs, 58%final

Labs: 100% (basically everyone gets 100%)
Midterm: 91.67% (mean: 64.4%, SD: 21.5%)
Final: 95.71% (mean: 55.9%, SD: 20.5%)
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: Just 3 out of 8 are hand in labs, only need to watch lab videos to do it. Course provides additional exercise that is useful for revision.

reviews.author: Qiu
reviews.title: good grade course
reviews.comment_content:
basic of Python, like variable, if statement, for/while loop, list, string slice, dictionary, function, recursion
the courses also included Turtle module
reviews.comment_teaching:
good, he makes jokes in the courses, and he will put some in-class questions for students to help for understanding(questions do not count any mark).

His English is easy to understand,
reviews.comment_grading:
100% Assignment
91% Midterm
91% final
A+

very good grade for CC courses
reviews.comment_workload:
7 lab works but only 3 of them need to be submitted, all of them are easy.
the midterm is easy, but the final exam is much harder than the midterm.

reviews.author: legasov
reviews.comment_content: Basics of Python or I guess you can say the basics of programming if you have learnt other programming language before. Not very hard to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: I have only attended a few lessons, but instructors can explain the concepts clearly so seems to be fine.
reviews.comment_grading:
With this semester being online, mid-term and final are online as well which personally I think is terrible because you are not allowed to go back to the previous question on Canvas and questions are harder than past years.

2 grading methods which you can view from many other reviews.
reviews.comment_workload: 3 assignments - everyone seems to be getting full marks.

reviews.author: Cqt
reviews.title: A good programming for beginner course ,a pretty good grade course in general imo
reviews.comment_content:
Most of the content taught in the lectures aren't like hard to understand (like pretty much all of them except maybe recursion), there's detailed instructions for labs too, so even if you are a beginner you should be able to handle them just fine if you try.

Content (I don't bother spending much time on this one part, literally most other reviews has it but eh here you go) :
-Turtle Graphics
-Comments, Variables and Text, Variable Types and Operators
-If condition; for ,while loop
-Lists(Array), Tuples and Strings
-Functions
-Turtle Window Event Handling
-File Handling
-Programming with Objects
-Recursion

And some other stuff but eh that about sums up the main things

{recursion is the last thing taught, so you technically have a lot of time to self study that 1 topic before they actually teaches you that. Studying that beforehand might make things easier for you in finals(?)}
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gibson is humorous and entertaining. Jimmy is a good TA that is willing to answer questions if you have some (and would try his best to keep up if like so many people are asking him questions at the same time)

Good prof+ good TA= good learning experience :D
reviews.comment_grading:
2 formulas for grading, where they will take the highest mark that they get from one of the formulas as your overall grade.

1. 24% Midterm, 36% Labs, 40% Finals
2. 0% Midterm, 42% Labs, 58% Finals

From what I've read there used to be bonus grade given (?) but we don't have that this sem.

As you can see, if you are able to score well in the finals, even if you messed up in midterm you can still clutch back and get a good grade.


From what I've observed A range should be around above mean + 1 standard deviation
(What the mean and the standard deviation are would be announced in email after they have finished marking the midterm/final)

For lab most people get full marks for all of them so (mid term and) final is pretty much what decides your grade.

I know I just said mid term grade technically can be excluded but I have to say mid term is definitely easier than finals. Unless you have prior knowledge on programming and you are confident that you will do good in the exam I highly recommend you to take the mid term seriously and try not to mess up.

The finals in recent years are harder because they have been pressured to make the finals harder.

My score for your reference:
-Full mark for all the labs
-Mid term:88.92% {mean:64.4%,standard deviation:21.5%}
-Final:95.71% {mean:55.9%,standard deviation:20.5%}

Final letter grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Word load: Only your lab, which is not a lot
Even if you don't know how to do your lab you can just go to any lab session (Yes, even if ur not from that lab session)

And even if u include the amount of time you spend to self study, its still not a lot

reviews.author: South
reviews.title: good introductory programming course, you will get good grades if you have already known something about programming
reviews.comment_content: introduction to programming with python, in my opinion that's quite good.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor is very passionate about teaching, very humorous. But what he taught weren't in-depth enough so that I didn't do well in exams.
reviews.comment_grading: the mt was quite easy but final was hell. Maybe the level of difficulty was just at that point so that I did very bad. I got mean+0.8sd in mt, 100% lab project, mean-0.5sd in final and finally got a B grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Three hand-in labs this semester, almost every week there was a lab (you don't have to hand in them but they were helpful). I finished all the labs.

reviews.author: 021ESA
reviews.title: GOOD GRADE COURSE
reviews.comment_content: Basic knowledge in programming by using Python. It mainly includes turtle graphics, if-then-else, loops, lists, functions, dictionaries, objects and recursions.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Rossiter is really good. His teaching is interesting and making the class funny. He not only read the powerpoint, but use programs to explain concepts clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 2 ways for grading. It will use the method that have higher mark for you.
Method1: 24% Midterm, 36% Labs, 40% Finals
Method2: 0% Midterm, 42% Labs, 58% Finals

For midterm and final, it is open book exam. So you can use Python to run code in the exam.

For labs, there are 8 labs in total but just need to hand in 3 labs.

Statistics for MT and Final:
MT:
Mean: 64.4%
SD: 21.5%
Max: 100%
Min: 2.5%

Final:
Mean: 55.9%
SD: 20.5%
Max: 100%
Min: 8.6%

My Results:
MT: 100%
Labs: 100%
Final: 100%
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light workload. Only 3 labs out of 8 need to be submitted. All labs have videos to guide you to do, so it's easy to handle. Exams are open book so the workload is low also.

It is a easy course although you don't have programming background before. Pay attention to lectures so you can spend less time to revise.

reviews.author: ljdjlalb
reviews.comment_content: Contents are easy and fun.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Class is fun.
Explanations from TA and professors are clear.
But, I will say there are not enough exercises for self-revision. And the level of the difficulty of exercises given is quite different from the final exams.
reviews.comment_grading: Reasonable but not as good as the version I heard before. The level of difficulty of this course is generally increased a lot compared to the past. If you are talented in programming, it will be quite possible for you to get an A grade. But for people who are totally new to programming, you need to put a great effort into it.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is reasonable.
Only 3 compulsory labs which are easy and fun.
Requires extra self-learning. It is quite impossible to get good grades if you only relied on the given materials in class.

reviews.author: Rohan
reviews.comment_content: The content is fairly easy, and mainly speaks about the basics of python programming, turtle graphics etc. If you have done any level of programming before ( need not be in python), you should be fine.
reviews.comment_teaching: David Rossiter is one of the best profs i have had here at UST, he is really experienced and believes in teaching by doing, which i find really helpful.  He is also a bit funny, which i think can help to some extent, but overall he does a really good job of teaching the content, and making it enjoyable as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
- The grading is fairly straight forward, and has 3 main components in its grading
1) The midterm - 24 %
2) Lab Home-works - 36 %
3) Final Exam - 40%

The exams were a bit tricky, but overall manageable. As long as you study from the notes and understand the logic behind it, the exams should go fine.

This course also offers an alternate pathway, where if you screw up your midterm, they will not take that into account, and only count your labs and final exam, which i find is quite helpful.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is hardly anything, especially if you know some programming prior to taking this course. The workload does increase as we move towards the end of the semester, but still relatively less compared to other courses.

reviews.author: fdjlpsat
reviews.comment_content: Python programming language. The basic concept of programming such as variable, operator, assignments, expression, function, array, iteration. also some graphics stuff , the turtle. You need to learn how to use the turtle to draw different pattern on the turtle window.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good teacher. Using different example to explain the abstract concepts. Hilarious and fun lecture. But prof. KIM's Korean accent makes me don't understand him well. this is a minor problem as long as you are used to the accent.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade depends on the mid-term, assignments and the final exam. The course provides two way to calculate your course score. Depend on your performance on mid-term and final exam, the two calculating way has different weight on the mid-term and final. Therefore, if you fail in the mid-term, don't worry. You can performance better in the final exam to save your score and grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Low workload.
The assignments are so easy.
You follow the instruction in the lab and
you can finish the assignments.
Most of the codes can be copied from the lab.
Therefore, a large part of the assignments is done for you as long as you attend the lab and pay attention.

reviews.author: Icespirits
reviews.title: Good grade
reviews.comment_content: Basic elements of programming that you can learn in  one day in the internet. There is absolutely no use studying this course if you know something in programming. Basically this is a course just for people who know programming to get a good grade or you can come and learn something about programming and get around B.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Although the content is basically useless, the professor are quite lenient and don't really force you to go to the lecture if you know what you are doing unlike some other courses like COMP2011 and more.
Although I didn't really apply any lecture other than the first two, professor's explanation and flow are fluent and easy to understand, I think he teach it quite well.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite good at grading.
The instructor is quite generous and provides a lot of As I think.
got around 70-80 marks in final and still get A+
reviews.comment_workload: I think it depends on people because the lab is quite easy to me, I just spent around 30 minute for each lab and basically all it remains are mid-term and final. However, I know some people who doesn't know programming well do struggle on lab so...

reviews.author: SunnyGuan
reviews.comment_content: The content is pretty easy if you know programming, and you will be very easy to fit in even if you don't know anything about programming.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is very humorous, and the class is fun, but sometimes you have to spend time to understand what he actually teaches.
reviews.comment_grading: Reasonable, and you will know where you lost your points, and if you don't know, the tutor is very willing to tell you which part is wrong.
reviews.comment_workload: Fair, there are usually two projects in the course, and you can do most of your job in the lab session, but it might be heavy for the one who don't know programming.

reviews.author: wjy
reviews.title: Best David&Jimmy in the world
reviews.comment_content: The content is about the basic knowledge of python, which is a very nice introduction course for those who haven't get in touch with coding before.
reviews.comment_teaching:
David is so experienced at teaching in several aspects:

1. As a British, he's certainly aware of the English level of the students may not be very high, and in the lectures, he controls the range of words he used carefully and also repeat and stress whenever it comes to the key point.

2. He's quite familiar with where the beginners might feel confused and would explain thoroughly in class.

3. The topic of examples relate closely to the social focus, and it works effectively in waking us up at 9
:00 in the morning


As for the TA Jimmy:

Jimmy is so nice! Best TA in the world!
As we have full-online teaching this semester, I can only tell about the advantages I feel in this mode of teaching.Whenever you come across problem in class, Jimmy is always waiting in the zoom chat box to answer. (Always precise and clear, and you can take a screenshot to save those answers in case forget.) At this level I really appreciate the online mode, it makes learning more accessible.
Besides, I'd like to thank Jimmy for replying email so timely and answer my question so carefully! Next time you have a course with Jimmy as TA, don
t hesitate, just enroll in it.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading scheme and automatically choose the higher one, including midterm, final, and 3 labs taken into account

Not as good as the normal semester on campus. The final exam was too difficult for most people with limited time and the restriction to get access to the former questions you skip.

Labs are released with a marking scheme and is not difficult with tutorial vedios. Not difficult to get full marks.
reviews.comment_workload: Light, but for those who want to major in CSE, practice makes perfect. Coding more in your spare time would get you better familiar with this language.

reviews.author: 诞简
reviews.title: A good course for beginners
reviews.comment_content: This course is about Python, which is very friendly to programming beginners. It introduces basic programming skills and brief introduction of some programming architecture. Most of them will based on Turtle Graphing, and they are really fun, such as making a Tetris on your own. The contents are all based on the lecture slide, but it is better to buy the textbook as reference. You can also find the code used in every lecture and lab in the course website.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor LAM is very experienced and funny. You can fell that he is working really hard to make the course interesting. Most of the important codes will be programmed during the lecture, instead of telling the theory directly. I tried to email him about some problems before, and the response was in detail and fast.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is pretty good and fair, you get what you should have. As the material the quite easy, quite a lot people got full mark in the midterm, it is important to be careful enough. The assignment will be graded as well, but they will help you finish most of them at lab each time. It is also suggested to answer the bonus questions in the lecture, which will give you 0.5 each time.  Personally speaking, as long as you can review the important contents carefully and write the taught codes yourself, it is really easy to get an A.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fine. During the basic week time, you only need to attend the lecture and lab on time. However, when you are working on an 'assignment', it takes a lot of time to debug.

reviews.author: Eleanor444
reviews.comment_content: Basic programming, teaches the python language, including loops, turtle windows, functions, different types of variables and more, if you have learnt programming this would be very easy
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Lam is very helpful lecturer, he will answer your after class or send him a email and he will reply very soon.
But his teaching speed is slightly slower than the other teachers
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment1: 100/100

midterm:26/100
online assessment(replacement for final exam): 92/100
grade: B-

                15% assessment2
                 35% midterm
                 35% final
method2: 15% assessment 1

                 65% final
reviews.comment_workload:
Almost no workload if you attend all lab section
ASM will be easy because lab section will help you finish around 80% of the assignment.
midterm and final exam will be open book.

reviews.author: 武智阳
reviews.title: 好龟又简单
reviews.comment_content: As stated in the title, this course is just a basic introduction to computer science. The content is quite easy and suitable for beginner. Python is a very user-friendly language and easy to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: Gibson is really humorous and gives detailed explanation about course content.
reviews.comment_grading: Quite good, but as many excellent students are in this course, it becomes really competitive. Meaning that some simple mistakes may course serious deduction in your final grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Just some normal assignment. Usually takes 1-2 hours to finish. Most of them are some interesting games.

reviews.author: YIN.
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers some basic computer programming using Python, from loops to some basic of object-oriented programming. Also, this course uses a lot of Turtle Graphics (a kind of GUI).

This is not a difficult course if you have studied any programming language before, you just need to learn some syntax of Python. Even if you have never learnt any programming before, I still highly recommend you to study this course. You do not need to spend too much time to understand the code in the course. However, if you want to get a higher mark in this course, I suggest you to write some small program as practice each week to have a better understanding of the material taught in the course. You may also learn more about Python from other online material ( such as learnpython.org ) if you are really interested.

[General Course Schedule]
Week 1: Introduction to Python and Turtle Graphics
Week 2: If, then, else & Loops
Week 3: For loops
Week 4: Lists and Tuples
Week 5: Functions
Week 6: Stacks & Slice Notation
Week 7: Midterm
Week 8: Data Types Handling
Week 9: Turtle Window Events
Week 10: Dictionaries & Timers & Turtle Screen Event
Week 11: More on Operators & Colors & File Handling
Week 12 & 13: Object & Recursion

[Assignment 1 & 2]
Assignment 1 is to write a program that create a "L-system", while the second one is to create a Tetris Game.

If you follow the lab material well, you can complete 80-90% of the assignment. The remaining parts need to be programmed on your own.

[Midterm]
Midterm examination is a open book / open notes exam, but you cannot use a calculator during the exam. You can bring as much notes as you like, or even print out some code you wrote before. However, it does not help you much as the exam is mostly testing your logical thinking.

The exam may have some tricky part, such as:
- Data type (ex: integer and floating point)
- Functions (ex: global variable and local variable)

Therefore, be very careful when doing the midterm exam and try to avoid making any mistake. It is possible to attain full mark in the exam.

[Online Assignment]
This part is a special arrangement for this semester. I believe the coming semesters will use the original arrangement.

In the online assignment, there are more tricky questions than those in the midterm. For example, only part of the program is given and some content in the variable is hidden. However, you will have sufficient time to complete this assignment. You can try think of different case and run them on your computer. It is not that difficult if you can work with a computer rather than pen and paper only.
reviews.comment_teaching:
[Lectures]
Sung is funny and kind teacher. He demonstrated the program in a clear and simple way. You can following his teaching easily .

I also recommend Gibson for this course. He is also nice and funny.

[Labs]
There is a 2-hour lab session each week that write some programs using what have taught in the past weeks. No attendance will be taken. The lab teaches you to write a program step by step.

I did not attend all the labs expect the ones that taught you how to do most of your assignment. As the lab material is uploaded to the course website in the beginning of each week, you can choose not to attend the lab if you find lab (or the lab teacher)  is boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
The original course weighting is:
Assignment 1: 15%
Assignment 2: 15%
Midterm: 25% / 5%
Final: 45% / 65%
Bonus: 3%
The highest mark of the two methods will be chosen as the final mark of the course.

However, due to special course adjustment in this semester, the weighting is changed as following:
Assignment 1: 25% / 35%
Assignment 2: 25% / 35%
Midterm: 35% / 10%
Online Assignment: 45% / 65%
Bonus: 3%

This course have penalty for late submission of assignment. 10 marks will be deducted if you submit up to 1 hour late and 5 marks will be deducted for each further hour late, up to 12 hours. Therefore, DO NOT SUBMIT YOUR ASSIGNMENT UNTIL THE VERY LAST MOMENT!

[Statistics]
Assignment 1: Max: 100, Min: 3, Avg: 92.5, Std. Dev.: 29.6
Assignment 2: Max: 100, Min: 20, Avg: 92.6, Std. Dev.: 28.6
Midterm: Max: 100, Min: 1, Avg: 57.9, Std. Dev.: 25.1
Online Assignment: Max: 100, Min: 8, Avg: 87, Std. Dev.: 14.77

As I have learnt programming before and submitted all the assignment on time, I almost got full possible mark in the course (103%).
Final Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is light. You do not need to take much notes in the lessons as most of the course material can be found on the course website.

You only need to complete 2 assignment in the course. The assignments are not difficult and you can complete them within a few days.

You can get a good grade easily if  you study the notes well, do little bit of revision each week and complete the past exam paper.

reviews.author: 飞沙走石
reviews.title: Online semester with online final
reviews.comment_content: Learned the basics of python including for loops, lists, functions, stacks, l system, slice notation, data types, dictionaries, window events, timers, objects, recursion, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: Pretty good teaching, Professor Lam reads off the slide but also points out and explains more on the important parts. When we switched to online mode, Prof was also really quick to share the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was standard. There's nothing objective really. But overall, many students already know programming before from high school so the curve was pretty high.
reviews.comment_workload: No much, under normal circumstances it will be two assignments, a midterm, and a final. But once we switched to online mode, the final became an online multiple-choice like assignment.

reviews.author: namreh
reviews.title: If you've learnt programming and want to skip lectures, DO NOT take this course.
reviews.comment_content: The content is ok but definitely not very good. The content is too easy even for an introductory course. It mostly teaches Turtle graphics for the whole course, together with some basic programming knowledge.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is excellent. I am confident to say he is one of the best lecturers in HKUST. You will love having his lectures. He is also very willing to answer students questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is unacceptable.
1. The mid term and final is way too easy. How it differentiates students is using traps to see if you are meticulous enough. If you're not careful enough, prepare for a not-very-good grade.
2. If you are the type of person who attend all lectures, this course is for you. But if you have learnt even little programming before, you may find it boring to go to his lectures. For me, I skipped most of his lectures. The PROBLEM is there is a policy: if you are able to answer his question correctly during the lecture, you can get a bonus 0.5 mark of the course. Some students get around 6, 7 marks total, and get an A+.

For me, overall: 98.155/100, and I get an A.
reviews.comment_workload: Almost none workload. Very easy lab assignments. There is a lab session with a good TA. He will help you out if you encounter any difficulties.

reviews.author: Manan
reviews.comment_content:
Python
Basic programming logic and make use of turtle library to draw or make "animations".
reviews.comment_teaching:
TEACHING
If you can manage to understand contents in the lecture notes without any help, you don't really have to go to lectures.
Just basic programming stuff
For me, I found lectures kind of useless because he was just reading the lecture note word to word
reviews.comment_grading:
GRADING
2 Marking scheme:
2x5% from Assignments + 90% finals
2x15% from assignments + 30% midterm + 40% finals (not sure about the exact percentage)
reviews.comment_workload:
WORKLOAD
2 Assignments, Mid-term, Final
The assignments don't take too much of your time. They are do-able.

reviews.author: Kim Woo Kyung
reviews.title: 2017-18 Fall
reviews.comment_content: Basic Programming course. Even if you haven't studied Computer Science before, you will get to learn it. It's quite useful. It's easy, at least for me.
reviews.comment_teaching: He tries to make not to bored, and he is organized. Lecture videos are provided.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading was alright. But the exams are easily, so most of students got high scores. And most of students do there all assignments, so u should be careful.
I got A+ easily.
reviews.comment_workload: There are two assignment, not too hard, but it  takes some time.

reviews.author: 芋頭
reviews.title: People who cannot code just cannot
reviews.comment_content: All intro topics for Python. A lot of emphasis on Turtle graphics. The most difficult part should be recursion and L-system.
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite good. Use examples to demonstrate concepts. Helpful. A bit hard to follow after midterm.
reviews.comment_grading:
It depends on whether your brain has got logic or not. Nothing to memorize but has to understand the new situations in exam questions. Very flexible exam questions with loads of traps. Sometimes, I feel that it is not to test whether one can code but whether he or she can identify traps.

Still hard for a beginner. Many people got programming background and can easily get high marks. This is the first time I learn programming and I found out that I just cannot understand even if I worked hard. A good course to try out whether you are suitable for CS or not.

Two assignments full mark. Midterm and final both below mean 0.5 SD. B-

Good and fair grading I guess.
reviews.comment_workload:
Two Assignments. Go to lab!!! Lab will show the most part of the assignments. Might take quite a lot of time if you are a beginner. The second assignment is about making a game, quite fun.

Lab, lecture no attendance. If you answer questions in class, you can get bonus points.

But if you are a beginner and have no programming mindset at all just like me. You will suffer .....a lot.

reviews.author: Mesguerra
reviews.comment_content: Knowing how to code helps a lot with the content of this course, still it is not a very difficult course. By the end of the course you learn some useful information
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is pretty decent though nothing exceptional.
reviews.comment_grading: Passing this course is easy but having an A is not that simple since the content is not difficult the average grades
reviews.comment_workload: If you know how to code the workload is minimum though if you don't you might end up spending way more time than others on the projects.

reviews.author: grqm
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Python
if statements; while/for loops; turtle graphics; data types; functions; recursion; stacks; objects

Assignment 1: Music Player
which I thought was quite easy
Assignment 2: Collision Game with Turtles
Despite a much higher mean, I personally think it was actually harder than the Music Player.

This had been largely an interesting course but the exams were't really easy.

The ability to memorise won't help much. I guess being able to think logically and mathematically is way more important.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He taught really well (by HKUST standards.)
The lecture slides were well prepared; the lectures were just 50 minutes long but still nicely paced.

I didn't go to the labs.
reviews.comment_grading:
22% Assignment 1
22% Assignment 2
22% / 0%* Midterm
34% / 56%* Final Exam
* if performed better in the final exam

The assignments were heavily weighted! But the mean scores were *very* high. So nothing to worry really.

The exams were open book.

The 1-hour midterm had 10 short questions. Easier than the final exam, but there could be time pressure.

The 2.25-hour final exam had 18 questions - with a style similar to the midterm - but considerably harder.

I got full marks in both assignments and slightly less than 0.5 sd above the mean in both exams. This got me an A-! Probably one of the best (meaning lenient) courses in terms of grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
The assignments would take at least a day or two.

Before the exam it would be a good idea to try and run the codes mentioned in class; modify/write some lines and see what happens.

reviews.author: Gian
reviews.title: Relatively easier course for students with programming background
reviews.comment_content:
This course teaches basic programming concepts through Python 2.0. These concepts include, but are not limited to, the following:
-> Variables
-> Functions
-> Classes
-> Recursion
-> Operators
-> For/While loops
-> Dictionaries, tuples and lists
-> Stacks
-> If/Nested-if statement

These concepts are mostly taught using the built-in turtle graphics to help visualise the aforementioned concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Gibson Lam is an enthusiastic instructor, and knows how to explain the materials to students with little to no programming background. He also thoroughly prepares for each lecture, as he always makes simple programs before the lecture to illustrate its contents more easily to students. He is also willing to help you if you have any questions regarding programming.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two types of grading. One is where your mid-term exam's result is counted while the other is where that result is not counted. This depends on how well you did for your mid-term exam. If your final grade will be brought down as a result of your exam when compared to counting it out of the final grade calculation, then it will be omitted.

You can also get bonus points for your assignment by answering Prof. Gibson Lam's questions during the lecture. However, your total assignment grade cannot be brought above 44% total when including the bonus points.

Grading with mid-term exam result:
22% Assignment 1
22% Assignment 2
22% Mid-term Exam
34% Final Exam

Grading without mid-term exam result:
22% Assignment 1
22% Assignment 2
56% Final Exam

If your final grade is at the mean, plus or minus 1 SD, you will lie in the B-range. Getting 1 SD above mean will give you a grade lying in the A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
The two assignments given will have 80% of its contents covered during the lab sessions. In other words, the lab sessions are a great way to go through the assignments if you need assistance in them. Also, you are given a few weeks to complete the assignments, which should be ample time to get them done.

Both exams are 'open-note, open-book' exams, which means you can bring as many materials as you like to the exam as long as they are not electronic or smart devices. You may print out all the lecture slides and bring them to the lecture. A summary of all the contents covered will also be given just before each exam.

reviews.author: LSJU
reviews.title: The worst class I've taken this semester
reviews.comment_content: The content of the class is very simple. It is the basic content of computer, so students without computer foundations can understand it.
reviews.comment_teaching: rossiter speaks very vividly and passionately. However, the difficulty of the content of the class and the content of the exam are too different. The exam is very unfriendly to students who have no computer foundation at all. Since you made the exam questions so difficult, shouldn't the class be more difficult? In the end, I just had to study on my own for the final based on the questions from previous years.
reviews.comment_grading:
This is the most sb part of the class. A fucking bunch of people have studied computers before. The result is a particularly bad grade given. Don't you fucking call a basic computer class supposed to be for students with no computer skills? This course is required for many non-SENG students. As a result, it's mixed with a bunch of students who have the basics and those who eventually want to major in computer science. How can we compare this class together when we all place different levels of importance on it?
It is difficult for non-SENG students or students with basic knowledge to do well in this course. And more importantly, the way the grade is given in this class is also very retarded. There are two ways to give grades, one counts as a midterm grade and one does not, but the final grade and the usual work will account for a much larger percentage. These two ways seem to give us more opportunities. But in reality, there is only one way to get a good grade. That is to get a high grade at the end of the period. To be clear the grade for this class is basically just the final. Even if your midterm and regular assignments are high, once you don't play well at the end of the semester your grade in this class is bound to suck. Because no matter how you do the math, the percentage at the end of the period is the largest. Also the grades in this class are too damn concentrated. A- and B- are less than ten points apart. Even if you can get a few points above MEAN, you can only get a B-. To put it bluntly, the grades given are really fucking outrageous.
Finally, students without basic knowledge are advised not to enroll in this course in the fall. There are too many students and seniors who have taken computer science. It is recommended to enroll in the spring and you should be better off.
reviews.comment_workload: It doesn't look very big. There are only a few times the lab has to be completed. But because the class lectures are too easy, you have to find a way to study on your own in order to cope with the exam. Do past topics or study python related videos online. This will increase the workload substantially.

reviews.author: scyeung
reviews.title: Typing Exam
reviews.comment_content:
Basic python programming stuff including classes, dictionaries, etc.
No algorithmic skills required.
I attended 0 lecture and 0 tutorial so I'm not exactly sure about the syllabus. However, you'll be pretty well off if you have some programming experience.
reviews.comment_teaching: 0 attendance throughout the semester so there really isn't much I can say about the teaching. But from feedbacks from other classmates, it should be pretty good.
reviews.comment_grading:
Haven't got the grading yet but the mean can fluctuate a lot. Last year fall semester mean is 45ish but in this year the mean is 70 something.

The difficulty of exams is very low even for beginners. A competent primary school student will have no problem getting full marks in all assignments and exams.

Typing skills and reading speed will be of great importance since you're unable to copy some of the code from exams, but you're allowed to type them out and run them. It's kind of a reasonable setting but also kind of retarded in the way it gives advantage to students with good typing skills. I guess there are two rationales behind. The first reason is that if you can type with fast speed, you will be more or less experienced in coding. The second is that they want the exam to mimic actual programming setting instead of bland written exam. But to be honest, it's not that difficult to include more problems where typing out the entire code will not suffice for getting the correct answer.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is pretty light, especially for those with programming background. However, even for programming beginners, you'll be pretty well off in this course as there are only 3 compulsory assignments which take around 1 hour each, probably.
